<h2>Results from Winter 2023</h2><div class="info-updated"><p>This information was last updated at Friday, December 30, 2022 at 6:05 PM</p><div class="openCloseAll"> <img style="margin:0 auto; display:none;" src="https://timetable.dawsoncollege.qc.ca/wp-content/plugins/timetable//assets/images/ajax-loader.gif"/> <a class="openAll btn btn-sm btn-default" href="#">Open All</a> <a class="closeAll btn btn-sm btn-default" href="#">Close All</a></div></div><h2>3D Animation and Computer Generated Imagery</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-222-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Principles of Animation II</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-570-K</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will continue the exploration of animated movement using 2D techniques and will specifically focus on the principles of human and animal mechanics, posing and body language. Students will observe and analyze various examples in animated films. A variety of exercises will be used to help the student explore emotional states and their effects on human and animal movement. Topics include: bio mechanics, posing, walk cycles, anticipation, and emotionally driven antics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-570-K</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will continue the exploration of animated movement using 2D techniques and will specifically focus on the principles of human and animal mechanics, posing and body language. Students will observe and analyze various examples in animated films. A variety of exercises will be used to help the student explore emotional states and their effects on human and animal movement. Topics include: bio mechanics, posing, walk cycles, anticipation, and emotionally driven antics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-232-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">3D Animation Techniques</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-570-K</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course builds on Introduction to 3D Animation and explores the technical fundamentals of animation using 3D software. Students will learn the physics and controls used in 3D software including physical simulation. Through assignments and exercises, the students will gain experience, setting the stage for more advanced topics and exercises in the third semester. Topics include: posing, timing, IK vs FK, key-framing, interpolation and animation curves, transformations and secondary animation, and physical simulation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kelly Hynes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-241-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Digital Video and Photography</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alison Loader</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to still and video photography. Students will use digital and video cameras to gather images. The proper lighting setup for acquiring reference and texture art will be explored. Students also will learn the aesthetics and theory of lighting for film, video and animation. The goal is to give the student animator a look at some of the professional techniques and theories necessary to conceive and create images for the screen and games. Topics include: seeing light, colour, framing the composition, selective focus, shooting actors as reference, and rotoscoping</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alison Loader</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to still and video photography. Students will use thumb-nailing techniques to explore a large variety of design and action possibilities before making final decisions. The role of thumb-nailing as a quick form of visual communication and the importance of a sketch book will also be covered. Topics include: layouts and posing, environmental design, breakdown of complex movement, and character design and props.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Meinert Hansen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will focus on the role of thumb-nailing in animated film. Methods and techniques for creating highly interactive spines and simulation of skin deformation will be explored. Topics include: complex facial rigs, lip syncing, morph targeting, muscles, and facial deformation animation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Josef Sy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course delves deeper into the creative and technical world of character setup. Methods and techniques for creating highly interactive spines and simulation of skin deformation will be explored. Topics include: complex facial rigs, lip syncing, morph targeting, muscles, and facial deformation animation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-453-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Storyboard</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoff Carley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will expand upon students' skills and understanding of the art and practice of storyboarding. Students will use their storytelling and film making skills in order to create storyboards.  In addition the storyboards will portray emotion and mood through lighting and camera angles. Students will become well versed in storyboard terminology and technical directives, film structure, hooks ups and spacial continuity. Topics include: composition, continuity, line of axis, lighting and atmosphere to create mood, strong posing, and cinematography and film structure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoff Carley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will expand upon students' skills and understanding of the art and practice of storyboarding. Students will use their storytelling and film making skills in order to create storyboards.  In addition the storyboards will portray emotion and mood through lighting and camera angles. Students will become well versed in storyboard terminology and technical directives, film structure, hooks ups and spacial continuity. Topics include: composition, continuity, line of axis, lighting and atmosphere to create mood, strong posing, and cinematography and film structure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-472-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Character Modelling</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew McIver</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course emphasizes anatomical construction and digital re-creation of believable characters. Students develop and construct digital 3-D character models intended for their animation. The course covers advanced topics in 3-D character design and modelling using the latest 3D modeling and digital sculpting software, with an emphasis on anatomy as it applies to predetermined movement requirements. Topics include: polygon modeling, advanced smoothing algorithms, edge loops, biped and quadruped characters, and displacement mapping.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew McIver</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course emphasizes anatomical construction and digital re-creation of believable characters. Students develop and construct digital 3-D character models intended for their animation. The course covers advanced topics in 3-D character design and modelling using the latest 3D modeling and digital sculpting software, with an emphasis on anatomy as it applies to predetermined movement requirements. Topics include: polygon modeling, advanced smoothing algorithms, edge loops, biped and quadruped characters, and displacement mapping.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-473-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Character Rigging</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Khadija Boulazhar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Character setup is one of the most important steps in the character building process. A good character rig will allow you to get the most out of your characters. This course will cover basic and advanced rigging solutions. This course is designed to run in conjunction with the Character Modelling course. This course covers the major concepts and techniques for successful 3D character rigging. Topics include: fundamentals in biped rigs, custom rigs using an internal bone systems, mechanics of a walk cycle, and mechanics of other character joints.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Khadija Boulazhar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Character setup is one of the most important steps in the character building process. A good character rig will allow you to get the most out of your characters. This course will cover basic and advanced rigging solutions. This course is designed to run in conjunction with the Character Modelling course. This course covers the major concepts and techniques for successful 3D character rigging. Topics include: fundamentals in biped rigs, custom rigs using an internal bone systems, mechanics of a walk cycle, and mechanics of other character joints.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-482-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Lights, Camera and Rendering II</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nabil E. Kachaami</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students explore advanced techniques in realistic lighting and rendering of images. The course will focus on shader networks, caustics, global illumination, and mental ray rendering techniques. The practice of lighting set up and camera control will be a constant theme throughout the course. Time will be spent on how to split scenes into separately rendered passes, and then composite renders into final footage. Topics include: practice lighting scenes with final gathering, advanced global illumination, ambient occlusion, rendering systems and separate component rendering, and HDRI.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nabil E. Kachaami</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students explore advanced techniques in realistic lighting and rendering of images. The course will focus on shader networks, caustics, global illumination, and mental ray rendering techniques. The practice of lighting set up and camera control will be a constant theme throughout the course. Time will be spent on how to split scenes into separately rendered passes, and then composite renders into final footage. Topics include: practice lighting scenes with final gathering, advanced global illumination, ambient occlusion, rendering systems and separate component rendering, and HDRI.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-602-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Postproduction of Visual Effects</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Raymon Fong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Continuing from the course Visual Effects this course will teach students to seamlessly integrate multiple visual components for effects to be used in animation, films, commercials, and television, along with more advanced particle system control. Students will use Adobe After Effects and Discreet Combustion in a post-production environment to solve design challenges and create special effects and motion graphics. All the key elements that make up the concept of compositing and motion design are covered. Topics include: keying, creation of mattes, color correction, stabilizing, and tracking, and fluid dynamics, such as smoke creation and liquid and water.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Raymon Fong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Continuing from the course Visual Effects this course will teach students to seamlessly integrate multiple visual components for effects to be used in animation, films, commercials, and television, along with more advanced particle system control. Students will use Adobe After Effects and Discreet Combustion in a post-production environment to solve design challenges and create special effects and motion graphics. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-636-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Character Animation II</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Omar Morsy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This 3D animation course will focus on advanced control systems including the creation of scripting as an animation time saver. Motion Capture and interpretation of MoCap data with be introduced. The key element of the course is for the student to give expression to an animated character. The course will link to the final production project and focus on the student's characters and the acting. The underlying principles that make a character work expressively will be covered. Students will further develop their character's lip synchronization, and facial expressions. The student will focus on the fundamentals of creating characteristic movement and personality. Topics include: scripting, motion and expression, acting, and working with MoCap data.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:30 AM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Omar Morsy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This 3D animation course will focus on advanced control systems including the creation of scripting as an animation time saver. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Anthropology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">7 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Katarzyna Wolfson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course provides an overview of what anthropology encompasses from the history of anthropological thought to the major subfields of study including linguistics, biology, social and archaeology. The unique vision and  social scientific perspective that anthropology brings to the social sciences will be discussed. This course will present an approach designed to introduce students to main areas of the discipline that may be explored more profoundly in the higher level courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Katarzyna Wolfson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course provides an overview of what anthropology encompasses from the history of anthropological thought to the major subfields of study including linguistics, biology, social and archaeology. This is the classic “bones and stones” course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maciej Domanski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The biological and behavioural evolution of humans will be studied with the aim of understanding man's place in nature and the source of his unique culture-creating capacities. This is the classic “bones and stones” course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-210-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Anthropology of Parenthood</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Cornelia Howell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course deals with the concept of parenthood by investigating how different cultures define motherhood, fatherhood and parenthood in practical terms. With this cross-cultural perspective, parenthood in the Western context will be explored by re-examining ideas about biological and social parenthood.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Cornelia Howell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course deals with the concept of parenthood by investigating how different cultures define motherhood, fatherhood and parenthood in practical terms. With this cross-cultural perspective, parenthood in the Western context will be explored by re-examining ideas about biological and social parenthood.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-313-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Contemporary Anthropology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Culture and Environment</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maciej Domanski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Globalization is a complex process that is integrating people, along with what they produce and how they consume, into an emerging world culture. This is being accomplished by the exchange of consumer goods and ideas as well as technologies that interconnect us. What evidence is there of globalization in our daily lives? How is globalization changing the relationship between the developing and industrialized world? Are traditional cultures threatened by globalization, and can they resist it? This course explores these questions from the perspective of anthropology and the use of ethnographic examples.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-319-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Perspectives in Anthropology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Anthropology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Katarzyna Wolfson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The topic for this course will be visual anthropology. The main interests of visual anthropology are: 1) production of visual documentation of people, practices, and cultures in an ethnographic context, and 2) analysis of visual representations of people, practices, and cultures. How we see things and how what we see is understood will be examined using anthropological concepts, theories and methods. This course is concerned with the study of visual systems and material culture. An analysis of visual and material processes such as photography, film and new media will allow students to consider how visual representation is constructed, interpreted and contested.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Studies in Anthropology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Material Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maciej Domanski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The topic is the anthropology of material culture – a broad range of material phenomena that emerge through human cultural activity. Examples include artifacts, buildings, landscapes or environments. The extent to which humans interact with these “objects” is one of the features that set them apart from other species. Besides their purely utilitarian functions, “objects” are also meaningful and play an active role in various areas of social life such as economic exchanges, the exercise of power, the construction of identities, institutions, and relations. The complexities of these processes will be considered over the semester. We will focus on what material culture is, what it does and what it means to us. We will explore the major conceptual and analytical frameworks in which the research in material culture is situated. Using a hands-on approach, students will also plan and complete a project that involves an analysis and display of a selected aspect of material culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-BXS-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social Science, Ensemble 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Culture on Display (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sabrina Smofsky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the ways in which museum displays shape our understanding of culture. A museum is a place where we can be exposed to cultures of different peoples, times, and aspects of culture. However, what we see in museums is curated, chosen in order to tell a specific story. Selective stories of culture are thus created, where some narratives are emphasized and others are excluded. We will have guided visits to local museums as well as virtual visits to museums elsewhere in the world with the goal of exploring how museum displays are curated. Using comparative analysis we will examine how stories about culture are created and how each story leaves us with a different understanding of the culture we are exploring. The cost of this course is around $36, to cover guided tours at the museums. To offset this cost, there will be no textbook to buy. All readings for this course will be available to the students without charge via the Dawson College library website.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Friday, June 2, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">May 31, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">May 31, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 02, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 02, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 05, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 05, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 05, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 05, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 06, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 06, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 06, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 06, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 07, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 07, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 07, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 07, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Biology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-920-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Anatomy and Physiology 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brid Nic Niocaill</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is the second of two courses designed to introduce the student to the fundamentals of anatomy and physiology of all human body systems. The main focus of this course is both the physiology and three-dimensional anatomy (with respect to locations, surface landmarks, vasculature and surrounding structures) of the skeletal, muscle, cardiovascular, respiratory and lymphatic systems. The students will also cover the basics of genetics and immunity. The final part of the course focuses on the major milestones of fetal development.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Medical Ultrasound Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-921-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Human Biology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Man-Tze Mabel Chong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course begins with an introduction to anatomical terminology, a discussion of the various levels of structural organization thatmake up the human body, and a brief overviewof each system's contribution to homeostasis.  The course emphasizes control systems(nervous and endocrine), reproduction, and classical genetics. The material covered in this course provides a useful background for nonscience students planning to study psychology in university. This course can be used as a concentration course in Social Science, but cannot  be used in the revised Science programs.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Richard Calvé</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course begins with an introduction to anatomical terminology, a discussion of the various levels of structural organization thatmake up the human body, and a brief overviewof each system's contribution to homeostasis. The emphasis will be on the concept of homeostasis and the role the various organ systems play in the maintenance of homeostasis. The anatomical positions of organs for imaging purposes will also be emphasized. Organ systems that are the focus of the course include: nervous, endocrine, cardiovascular, lymphatic, respiratory, digestive, urinary, and reproductive.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Diagnostic Imaging</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Wieczorek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to provide an introduction to human anatomy and physiology to students in the Diagnostic Imaging program. The main topics are nervous system; muscle physiology; endocrine system; and interconnections of the organ systems.  Throughout these courses students are encouraged to appreciate that life processes have a molecular basis and that despite obvious differences, all living things have much in common.  Laboratory exercises, including computer simulations, complement class work. 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-BWT-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Science and Technology: Introduction to the Science of Biology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Biology of Nutrition</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Suzanne Kunicki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to teach students how to make good nutritional choices using scientific knowledge and reasoning. The nature, function, and biological processing of nutrients, along with the physiological and social aspects of eating will be covered. Students will also learn how to use food labels and the Canadian Food Guide to make healthy food choices. Several disorders linked to nutrient consumption and processing (intolerances, allergies, eating disorders) are included in the syllabus. Some of the more controversial topics to be covered include fad diets, alternative sweeteners, supplements, food safety, and genetically modified foods. This course is designed for non-science students.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.23</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Biology of Nutrition</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Suzanne Kunicki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to teach students how to make good nutritional choices using scientific knowledge and reasoning. It offers the opportunity to develop an understanding of the human body and its organ systems from the point of view of structure-to-function relationship. A series of laboratory exercises serve to complement the lecture material. The student may elect to complete a project for this course as part of the Comprehensive Assessment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rami Hanna</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an optional course for students in the Science program. The relationship between biological structures and their function will be examined. How cell activities are organized and controlled, as well as cell reproduction and basic genetic principles, will be studied. The structure of ecosystems and the flow of chemicals through the environment will be examined. This course will require students to complete an independent scientific research project, to acquire and analyze data using computerized systems, and to communicate effectively using electronic media. This research project is a compulsory component of the Comprehensive Activity.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Enriched Science</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Richard Calvé</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn to recognize the characteristics of life and how evolution gave rise to the great diversity of life forms. The relationship between biological structures and their function will be examined. How cell activities are organized and controlled, as well as cell reproduction and basic genetic principles, will be studied. The structure of ecosystems and the flow of chemicals through the environment will be examined. This course will require students to complete an independent scientific research project, to acquire and analyze data using computerized systems, and to communicate effectively using electronic media. This research project is a compulsory component of the Comprehensive Activity.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Suzanne Kunicki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn to recognize the characteristics of life and how evolution gave rise to the great diversity of life forms. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-211-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Microorganisms and Disease 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Penny Smith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The competencies attained in this course focus on the anatomy and physiology of prokaryotic (bacteria) and eukaryotic (parasites and fungi) microorganisms which may cause infection in the human body. The mechanisms of host defense and immunity will be introduced. The competencies addressed in this course include the use of appropriate methods of disinfection and sterilization, principles and application of various forms of microscopy, the art of making media, the preparation and staining of bacteria, and the application of aseptic technique when isolating and identifying microorganisms by biochemical methods. Students will also begin to write a Standardized Operating and Procedures manual which will serve to complement their laboratory manual in subsequent microbiology courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Penny Smith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The competencies attained in this course focus on the anatomy and physiology of prokaryotic (bacteria) and eukaryotic (parasites and fungi) microorganisms which may cause infection in the human body. The mechanisms of host defense and immunity will be introduced. The competencies addressed in this course include the use of appropriate methods of disinfection and sterilization, principles and application of various forms of microscopy, the art of making media, the preparation and staining of bacteria, and the application of aseptic technique when isolating and identifying microorganisms by biochemical methods. Vescio</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus of this course is techniques used in immunological analysis, including agglutination, precipitation, ELISA,  flow cytometry, and immunoassays. Cells of the immune system are enumerated and identified, by staining techniques and immunohistological methods. Techniques for identifying antigens and antibodies, antigen-antibody reactions, and variables affecting immunological reactions are covered. Organs and cells of the immune system, as well as mechanisms underlying both maintenance of immunity and immune-related diseases, are investigated.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel P. Vescio</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus of this course is techniques used in immunological analysis, including agglutination, precipitation, ELISA,  flow cytometry, and immunoassays. Proper choice, use, and maintenance of microscopes are covered. Basic concepts of slide preparation and staining are discussed. Histological detection of select pathologies are also investigated.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Wieczorek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students learn microscopic and macroscopic techniques for examining and identifying cells, tissues, and organs, according to anatomical, morphological, and physiological characteristics. Proper choice, use, and maintenance of microscopes are covered. Basic concepts of slide preparation and staining are discussed. Histological detection of select pathologies are also investigated.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-241-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Clinical Chemistry 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Hannah Heath-Engel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will learn to perform and understand techniques used in the clinical chemistry laboratory for the determination of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and enzymes in biological fluids, and to correlate results with disease processes. Students will learn about the physiological roles, metabolism and clinical significance of each substance, and about methods used for determination in biological fluids. Emphasis is placed on: principles of sample and reagent preparation, handling and storage; appropriate instrument preparation, use, and maintenance; calibration and quality control; accuracy and precision of results; turn around time; recording and interpretation of results; potential interferences; follow-up testing; troubleshooting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Hannah Heath-Engel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will learn to perform and understand techniques used in the clinical chemistry laboratory for the determination of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and enzymes in biological fluids, and to correlate results with disease processes. Students will learn about the physiological roles, metabolism and clinical significance of each substance, and about methods used for determination in biological fluids. Emphasis is placed on: principles of sample and reagent preparation, handling and storage; appropriate instrument preparation, use, and maintenance; calibration and quality control; accuracy and precision of results; turn around time; recording and interpretation of results; potential interferences; follow-up testing; troubleshooting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-411-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Diagnostic Microbiology 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Penny Smith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will be introduced to standardized protocols for processing clinical specimens and reporting results. They will learn to differentiate clinical pathogens and normal flora per specimen type: urine, stool, respiratory, genital, wound, blood culture, cerebrospinal fluid, and tissue. Students will also identify and apply laboratory methods to identify parasites in formalized stool and to identify fungi in both cutaneous and systemic infections. Students will update and maintain their Standardized Operating and Procedures manual which will serve as their laboratory manual in the Diagnostic Microbiology 2 course in Term 5.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Penny Smith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will be introduced to standardized protocols for processing clinical specimens and reporting results. Students will also identify and apply laboratory methods to identify parasites in formalized stool and to identify fungi in both cutaneous and systemic infections.
