Topics include immunological principles in antigen-antibody reactions, blood group systems, antibody identification techniques, and routine pre-transfusion and compatibility testing and problem-solving. Students adhere to rigorous standards as applied to technical work and record-keeping, interpretation and reporting of results, and quality control in the transfusion service laboratory.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heleni Siandris</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus of this course is for students to learn basic concepts and practices involved in blood transfusions. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-441-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Clinical Chemistry 3</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Hannah Heath-Engel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will develop further expertise in the clinical chemistry laboratory, through the performance and interpretation of assays for serum iron and related parameters, therapeutic drugs, toxic substances, drugs of abuse, tumor markers, hormones, vitamins, physical and chemical characteristics of body fluids other than blood and urine, kidney function, and physical, chemical and microscopic characteristics of urine. Students will learn about the biochemistry, roles and clinical significance of each substance, and about methods used for determination in biological fluids. Emphasis is placed on: principles of sample and reagent preparation, handling and storage; appropriate instrument preparation, use, and maintenance; calibration and quality control; accuracy and precision of results; turn around time; recording and interpretation of results; potential interferences; follow-up testing; troubleshooting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Hannah Heath-Engel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will develop further expertise in the clinical chemistry laboratory, through the performance and interpretation of assays for serum iron and related parameters, therapeutic drugs, toxic substances, drugs of abuse, tumor markers, hormones, vitamins, physical and chemical characteristics of body fluids other than blood and urine, kidney function, and physical, chemical and microscopic characteristics of urine. Emphasis is placed on: principles of sample and reagent preparation, handling and storage; appropriate instrument preparation, use, and maintenance; calibration and quality control; accuracy and precision of results; turn around time; recording and interpretation of results; potential interferences; follow-up testing; troubleshooting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-451-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Clinical Hematology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Vincenza C. Pascale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students study analysis of blood specimens and other biological fluids in the hematology laboratories. Hematology cell counts are performed using both manual and automated methods, along with staining, microscopy, and other routine techniques. Results are validated, recorded, reported, and monitored, and quality control standards are applied. This course focuses on hematological disorders, including anemias, thalassemia and leukemia. Emphasis is placed on correct interpretation and follow-up of normal and abnormal results, and the precise correlation of results with clinical information. The application of hematology case studies further students’ understanding of the discipline.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Vincenza C. The goal is to obtain the practical experience necessary to ensure that students perfect their skills, integrate their knowledge, and complete their training in the actual environment where most medical technologists choose to work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-663-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Core Lab Internship</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel P. Vescio, Vincenza C. Pascale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will intern in affiliated hospitals in biochemistry, hematology and hemostasis. The goal is to obtain the practical experience necessary to ensure that students perfect their skills, integrate their knowledge, and complete their training in the actual environment where most medical technologists will work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-664-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Transfusion Sciences Internship</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heleni Siandris</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will intern in affiliated hospitals in transfusion science. The goal is to obtain the practical experience necessary to ensure that students perfect their skills, integrate their knowledge, and complete their training in the actual environment where most medical technologists choose to work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-665-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Pharmacology for Biomedical Technologists</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel P. Vescio, Luigi Bruno</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course prepares biomedical laboratory technologists to administer medications and other substances in the context of performing certain types of laboratory analyses. This course provides students with a foundation for understanding principles of drug administration, usage of drugs, the mode of actions of drugs as well as their interactions and toxic effects. Students will learn how to intervene in the case of an adverse reaction following the administration of a medication or other substance. Also, the students will be introduced to Point of Care Testing (POCT), which consists of medical diagnostic testing performed outside the clinical laboratory. This course is partially web-based. The materials, assignments and discussions related to pharmacology are given through the internet.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered on-line. Students are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">140-923-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Microbiology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heleni Siandris</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Microbiology course is given in the fourth semester of the Laboratory Technology Program. This course introduces students to the fundamental principles related to microorganisms and basic laboratory techniques used in an industrial context. The competencies attained in this course focus on the isolation and identification of microorganisms and their potential risks especially with respect to potable water, food and pharmaceutical products. This course will also deal with methods to control microorganisms, the safe-handling and management of contaminated materials and emergency action in case of exposure to dangerous microorganisms.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">LabTech<br>COMPRESSED: January 18 to April 19, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Thursday, February 2, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Business Administration</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; International business has undergone dramatic changes in the past decade, and the academic discipline has evolved  in response to these changes. The course aims to introduce students to the fundamentals of international trade and investment and to expose students to the complexities of the international business environment (economic,  legal, political, cultural and technological). It will also familiarize students with the influential players on the international business scene (multinational corporations, governments and international organizations) and develop an  international perspective.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kayrod Niamir</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The International Business course offers a small window to the expanded world of international business. develop a knowledge of Accounting standards; define relevant Financial Accounting terminology; develop a knowledge of different accounting reports (Income Statement, Balance Sheet, Statement of Owner’s Equity); analyse and prepare business transactions using journal entries; analyse and prepare adjusting entries; prepare closing entries; prepare an income statement, balance sheet and statement of owner’s equity; apply the case method in solving specific accounting problems; analyse financial reports using key performance Indicators (financial ratios).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. International business has undergone dramatic changes in the past decade, and the academic discipline has evolved in response to these changes. As the first course in the international business concentration, the course is introductory in nature. It covers a wide range of topics, and aims to help students develop a foundation for further detailed studies in the field. The course aims to (1) introduce students to the fundamentals of international trade and investment; (2) expose students to the complexities of the international business environment and its major agents; (3) familiarize students with the influential players on the international business scene; and (4) develop an international perspective.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Vimala Naidoo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course offers a small window to the expanded world of international business. This course is designed to assist students in developing an understanding of the elements involved in services marketing, an appreciation of the challenges that are unique to service marketers, and the ability to evaluate and recommend services marketing strategies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: January 18 to April 20, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">410-409-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Consumer Behaviour</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carmen Kuczewski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Why do consumers behave as they do? Drawing upon material from marketing, anthropology, sociology and psychology, this course investigates the factors that affect buyer behaviour. This course reviews the role of financial management and the decision-making processes required to achieve the major goal of the firm: the maximization of shareholders wealth. It includes the utilization of financial statements for the analysis of company performance. Detailed analysis will be made of working capital components such as cash, accounts receivable, and accounts payable. Corporate Finance reviews approaches and solutions to companies’ need for capital. This course analyzes the optimal capital structure—function of leverage, how to obtain funds and cost of capital. Present value techniques will be used in the analysis of capital budgeting when classifying projects for investment purposes.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. It explores the various facets and nature of negotiations and allows for the translation of theory into practice through role- play and simulations. Topics include: the basic theories of atoms, bonding and the states of matter; a brief review of stoichiometry; and chemical vocabulary. Emphasis will be placed on the role of the periodic table in predicting properties, and on the nature of the covalent bond. Topics include: the basic theories of atoms, bonding and the states of matter; a brief review of stoichiometry; and chemical vocabulary. Emphasis will be placed on the role of the periodic table in predicting properties, and on the nature of the covalent bond. Some discussion of quantum theory, hydrogen-bonding and phase changes will also be included.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.20</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-202-B</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is required for all pre-university Science students. Topics include: the basic theories of atoms, bonding and the states of matter; a brief review of stoichiometry; and chemical vocabulary. Emphasis will be placed on the role of the periodic table in predicting properties, and on the nature of the covalent bond. Topics include solution concentrations, kinetics and equilibrium, pH, buffer solutions, solubility product and free energy. A strong emphasis is placed on laboratory techniques.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Enriched Science</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Roger Machaalani</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The concepts and calculations studied in this course are those associated with chemical equilibrium, especially the aqueous solutions.                 .dc_accordion{ margin: 0 0 20px 0; border: 1px solid #d4d4d4; background: #fff; }
                .dc_accordion br:first-child{ display: none; }
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-title{ position: relative; margin: 0; letter-spacing: 0; text-transform: none; color:#356bae;   }
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-title a { display: block; color: inherit; text-decoration: none!important; padding: 15px 60px 15px 20px; font-family: "Open Sans", Arial, sans-serif; font-weight: 600; font-size: 18px;}
                .dc_accordion.open .dc_accordion-title a {  }
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body { color:#1d1d1d; display: none; padding: 0 20px 15px 20px; border-top: 1px solid #e0e0e0; font-size:13px; line-height:21px; overflow: hidden; }
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body a{ text-decoration: underline;  }
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body p{ font-size:14px; line-height:21px;}
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body li{ font-size:14px; line-height:21px;}
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body table li, .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body table p{ font-size: 14px; }
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body table li{ padding-left: 5px; }

                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-title a:before{ line-height: 0; transition: transform, 0.2s ease; font-family: FontAwesome; content: "\f107"; font-size: 26px; display: block; height: 50%; background: none; position: absolute; right: 25px; top: 50%; }
                .dc_accordion.open > .dc_accordion-title a:before{
                    top:0;
                    -webkit-transform: scale(-1,-1);
                    -moz-transform: scale(-1,-1);
                    -o-transform: scale(-1,-1);
                    -ms-transform: scale(-1,-1);
                    transform: scale(-1,-1);
                }

                .dc_accordion > .dc_accordion-body{ display: none; }
                .dc_accordion.open > .dc_accordion-body{ display: block; }

                .dc_accordion.multiple{ margin: 0; }
                .dc_accordion.multiple + .dc_accordion.multiple{ border-top: none; }
                .dc_accordion.multiple .dc_accordion-title{ }
                .dc_accordion.multiple .dc_accordion-body{ }
                .dc_accordion.multiple.open .dc_accordion-title.highlighta {
                    background: #356bae;
                    color: #fff;
                }

                /* Style Minimal */
                .dc_accordion.minimal{ margin: 0;}
                .dc_accordion.minimal .dc_accordion-body{ border: none; }
                .dc_accordion.minimal .dc_accordion-title{ border:none; border-bottom: 1px solid #d4d4d4; }
                .dc_accordion.minimal .dc_accordion-title a{ padding-left: 10px;}
                .dc_accordion.minimal .dc_accordion-title a.image-bg{ padding-left: 160px; }

                /*.dc_accordion.open .dc_accordion-body{ display: block;}*/
                #content .dc_accordion-body h2 {
                    font-size: 18px;
                    font-family: "Open Sans";
                    letter-spacing: 0;
                    font-weight: bold;
                }
                #content .dc_accordion-body h3 {
                    font-size: 16px;
                    font-family: "Open Sans";
                    letter-spacing: 0;
                    font-weight: bold;
                }


                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body:before{
                    display: block;
                    height: 10px;
                    content: "";
                }



                /* .dc_accordion .accordion-body > :first-child{ margin-top: 50px!important;} */
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body p:empty{ display: none;}
                .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body p:last-child{ margin-bottom: 0;}
                .dc_accordion li a{ text-decoration: none;}

                /*div.dc_accordion:nth-of-type(2n+2) h2 a{*/
                /*background: #f3f3f3;*/
                /*}*/

                .no-js .dc_accordion .dc_accordion-body{ display: block;}
            </style>

            <div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Please note the prerequisites for each course.  Students in doubt of their level must contact the department chairperson at local 4244 or e-mail nlachance@dawsoncollege.qc.ca before registration.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">613-111-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Chinese 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joy Cheng Yu Lin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Chinese (Mandarin), formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab. In this course, students will learn the Pinyin phonetic system as well as Chinese characters.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles EXCEPT Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joy Cheng Yu Lin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Chinese (Mandarin), formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab. In this course, students will learn the Pinyin phonetic system as well as Chinese characters.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles EXCEPT Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">613-211-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Chinese 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joy Cheng Yu Lin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation of Chinese (Mandarin) 1. Among other topics, it considers the impact of various media including oral culture, print, cinema, radio, TV, digital media, and the Internet. Essential elements of fields of cinema and communications will be presented and explained.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Cinema-Communications</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-213-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Cinema and Media History</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Magdalena Olszanowski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In order to better understand the nature of the cinema and media world that surrounds us, this course examines a number of the historical milestones in their development. The historical approach provides a method permitting the student to understand how media, including the cinema, have developed into the diverse and prolific platforms that exist today.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Cinema-Communications</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">George Alexander Milton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In order to better understand the nature of the cinema and media world that surrounds us, this course examines a number of the historical milestones in their development. The historical approach provides a method permitting the student to understand how media, including the cinema, have developed into the diverse and prolific platforms that exist today.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Cinema-Communications</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-292-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">History of Film Production Techniques</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nancy Barnett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will cover the history of film from the formative stages of the series photography of the 1870's up to the present by way of 3D Animation and Digital Cinema. The areas of Fiction, Documentary, Animation and Experimental styles will be considered. Technical and aesthetic developments will be addressed as well as the important notion of cinema as an international medium. Topics include: framing and photographic space, editing, sound, genre and narrative form, acting style, and lighting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nancy Barnett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will cover the history of film from the formative stages of the series photography of the 1870's up to the present by way of 3D Animation and Digital Cinema. The areas of Fiction, Documentary, Animation and Experimental styles will be considered. Technical and aesthetic developments will be addressed as well as the important notion of cinema as an international medium. Topics include: framing and photographic space, editing, sound, genre and narrative form, acting style, and lighting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-313-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Writing Lab</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Myriam Rafla</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The goal of the Writing Lab is to advance writing skills, in a creative and conceptual sense, as well as a formal one. This workshop-based course aims to equip the student with a solid critical and analytical approach to refining texts. Students may produce an original concept and story idea that may include narrative, documentary, interactive and other forms of media-related, journalistic and academic writing. The focus will be on a sharing process that includes regular analysis, critical evaluation and cultivation of student work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Cinema-Communications</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-530-B</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The goal of the Writing Lab is to advance writing skills, in a creative and conceptual sense, as well as a formal one. This workshop-based course aims to equip the student with a solid critical and analytical approach to refining texts. Students may produce an original concept and story idea that may include narrative, documentary, interactive and other forms of media-related, journalistic and academic writing. The focus will be on a sharing process that includes regular analysis, critical evaluation and cultivation of student work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve<br>Cinema-Communications</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-314-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Film Theory</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jesse Hunter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Film Theory and Criticism provides students with the necessary technical, aesthetic and critical vocabulary for viewing, discussing and writing about film of all kinds. It also presents an overview of critical theories that have influenced filmmakers, critics, and spectators, over time. Lectures, group discussions and screenings comprise the content, while assignments include research and creative projects.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Cinema-Communications</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-413-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Media Lab</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Justine McLellan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A course designed to introduce students to the processes involved in planning, designing, and delivering interactive and multi-media projects and events. Throughout the semester the student will develop and conceptualize an idea and create a story structure in order to animate key frames to effectively narrate the story. This course will help to generate and workshop ideas, develop a story and characters and their characteristics, focus on linear or non-linear narratives to present the conflict effectively – with emotions and poignancy. At the end of the semester the students will be able to develop a storyboard for an animated short film. The course will also provide the students with a clear idea of the Principles of Animation. Topics include: idea generation, story development, visual scripting, creation of the three act play, storyboards.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nancy Barnett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course in Storytelling for Animation introduces the students to the art of writing and scripting for animation. Students will use creative techniques and processes that they will apply to the development of original works throughout the term, working independently and in teams.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-916-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Cinema Styles</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Dipti Gupta</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“Create your own visual style... let it be unique for yourself and yet identifiable for others.”  This creative advice from legendary filmmaker Orson Welles underlies this course introducing students to the diversity of cinematic production.  A wide range of filmic expression is examined through a variety of film forms, genres and styles. The class will examine contemporary and past works notable for their aesthetic approach and storytelling techniques, as well as their unique treatment of social realities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Reisa Levine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“Create your own visual style... let it be unique for yourself and yet identifiable for others.”  This creative advice from legendary filmmaker Orson Welles underlies this course introducing students to the diversity of cinematic production.  A wide range of filmic expression is examined through a variety of film forms, genres and styles. The class will examine contemporary and past works notable for their aesthetic approach and storytelling techniques, as well as their unique treatment of social realities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jesse Klein</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“Create your own visual style... let it be unique for yourself and yet identifiable for others.”  This creative advice from legendary filmmaker Orson Welles underlies this course introducing students to the diversity of cinematic production. With the Internet, people expect the interplay between text, graphics, sound and motion. This course immerses students in various approaches to creating and producing multimedia projects that can include print, digital video, audio, installations and/or web-based, interactive components. Students will be encouraged to explore graphics, photo and audio-visual software applications for their commercial applications and creative possibilities. Assignments may be done in groups or individually. Learning activities include workshops, hands-on lab work, discussions, museum and gallery visits.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-919-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Video Basics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Terryll Loffler</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Video Basics provides a disciplined introduction to the principal techniques involved in video production, including the recording and editing of video and sound, as well as the essential baselines for organizing a proper project. The department's labs have up-to-date computers and software for in-class and evening work sessions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Terryll Loffler</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Video Basics provides a disciplined introduction to the principal techniques involved in video production, including the recording and editing of video and sound, as well as the essential baselines for organizing a proper project. Students will view a range of films, from past to present, including foreign and independent films, and learn how to interpret and analyze the cultural values expressed and the films' impact on the social world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Justine McLellan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses the significance and consequence of film and related media practices in the life of citizens. The cultural, historical and artistic origins of these practices are explored, as are the major movements and essential elements within each. Students view, analyze, discuss, and provide critiques of selected works. A theoretical introduction to the creative process is provided through appropriate readings, exercises, group and individual creative projects.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-932-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Animation</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Dipti Gupta</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the art and technique of frame-by-frame filmmaking, or animation, from the earliest innovations to the more recent productions through the theory and practice. Films are viewed and demonstrations given in order to examine specific animators and their ideas and styles as well as their contribution to significant changes in the history of the animated film. The course is designed to initiate a critical, analytical and creative appreciation of the animated film genre and its role in cinema.  Students learn to identify various themes, recognize narrative strategies and stylistic devices and apply them to written and practical assignments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-BWA-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Cinema</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">8 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Film Styles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">John Connolly</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">An introductory film course that exposes students to a variety of film, forms and styles.  The range of films includes narrative and non-narrative. The genres may include film noir, western, gangster, documentary, faux-docs, animation, romantic comedy, melodrama, film nouveau and foreign films. Students will also become familiar with the language and structure of film styles.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Film Styles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">John Connolly</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">An introductory film course that exposes students to a variety of film, forms and styles.  The range of films includes narrative and non-narrative. The genres may include film noir, western, gangster, documentary, faux-docs, animation, romantic comedy, melodrama, film nouveau and foreign films. Students will also become familiar with the language and structure of film styles.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Film and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Dipti Gupta</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an essential, basic course on the cultural significance of film and related media. All societies express important ideas in their art. In the last 100 years, the cinema has been a dominant art form. This course prepares the student to understand the cultural value of the cinema. In viewing films that cover the  range of cinema history, students learn how to interpret and analyze the social and cultural notions found there.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Film and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Dipti Gupta</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an essential, basic course on the cultural significance of film and related media. All societies express important ideas in their art. In the last 100 years, the cinema has been a dominant art form. This course prepares the student to understand the cultural value of the cinema. It includes preparation and layout of construction sites; selection of appropriate construction equipment; concrete , reinforcing and formwork; beams, columns and floor slab systems; material, systems and installation procedures related to roofing for residential and industrial buildings. To understand the construction procedures, students will visit construction sites where a project is in progress.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stephen Hinton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces and demonstrates to the students the principles and practices of construction technology related to structural materials, construction equipment, construction procedures, structural systems and quantity estimates. Students will also become familiar with the methods of taking and recording information gathered from field investigation, interpreting results and evaluating their significance. This course deals with the nature of soils; their engineering properties, classification, compaction, and laboratory testing and techniques. Laboratory tests include classification, atterberg limits, specific gravity, hydrometer analysis, and compaction.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Gloria Colaneri, Xiaolu Jade Lin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the field of soil engineering and to aid them in attaining the proper perspective on the role of laboratory testing in soil investigations. The work term starts with the Victoria Day weekend in May at the end of the fourth semester, and extends into August at the beginning of the fifth semester.  The purpose of this course is to place students in an actual working  environment of one of the fields of civil engineering for a continuous work period. The students will be remunerated during this work stage. Students will learn the basic job search skills of preparing a c.v. in both French and English and how to conduct themselves in a job interview. Students will also use the various  job search tools such as the Internet, job advertisements and specialized directories of companies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">221-648-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Project Management II</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carmelo Curiale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation to project management I in which the framework of project management will be further discussed and applied. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">221-655-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Roads II</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stephen Hinton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to both manual and computer methods of road design. Topics including the historical development of roads, transportation project planning, pedestrian, driver, and vehicle characteristics, vehicle dynamics, stopping sight distance, passing sight distance, circular curve radius, and all stages of a road design project will be introduced. Students will work in groups to undertake a real highway design project from conception to completion, according to the Quebec standards of road design. During the implementation of the project, students will be introduced to all aspects of road design in detail.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">-2H.27</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stephen Hinton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to both manual and computer methods of road design.
