This course introduces students to the fundamental engineering concepts and design principles of building plumbing systems; ventilation systems for pollutant control; heating,  air-conditioning systems; liquid and solid wastes in household; noise pollution and control; fire protection and smoke detection. Students will become familiar with the regulations and standards provided by the plumbing code as well as with the use of SPIPE and DPIPE software to design building water distribution and drainage systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">-2H.27</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sofia Babarutsi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to identify the environmental aspects to design healthy and comfortable building environments. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">332-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to the Classical World</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Egypt, Greece, and Rome</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jiri Tucker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This introductory course develops an appreciation of the myths, legends, history, and forces that shaped the world of ancient Egypt, Greece and Rome. Upon completion of this course, students will be able to demonstrate an understanding of methods, such as recognizing ancient texts, language and archaeology, used in Classics. Students should understand the contribution of Classics to specific situations, problems, and questions, including the establishment of democracy, the republic, philosophy, early religion, cult, hierarchies, the development of early literature as well as the contribution and legacy of the Classical World to other historical periods and ideas. Finally, students will develop the basic skills needed to study the Social Sciences, such as completing assignments that develop the ability to take notes and use a textbook.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Egypt, Greece, and Rome</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Leon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This introductory course develops an appreciation of the myths, legends, history, and forces that shaped the world of ancient Egypt, Greece and Rome. Upon completion of this course, students will be able to demonstrate an understanding of methods, such as recognizing ancient texts, language and archaeology, used in Classics. Students should understand the contribution of Classics to specific situations, problems, and questions, including the establishment of democracy, the republic, philosophy, early religion, cult, hierarchies, the development of early literature as well as the contribution and legacy of the Classical World to other historical periods and ideas. Finally, students will develop the basic skills needed to study the Social Sciences, such as completing assignments that develop the ability to take notes and use a textbook.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">332-302-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Myths in Classical Society</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ancient Gods, Monsters, and Encounters</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jiri Tucker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will examine and contrast the classical mythologies of the Greco-Roman world, including connections to the Near East and Egypt. Evaluation of primary sources in prose, poetry, artifacts, and visual media will be done through an appraisal of these texts. What role does ancient myth really provide? Myth offers many interpretations that apply to ideas and trends in today’s world, as such students must be able to evaluate myths as enduring concepts that help us critique our own world. As students interpret each myth and each taboo, they are expected to solve their meanings and argue how their ideas persist to this day through concepts of mind, ritual, gender, belief, conflict, creation, and heroism.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for Liberal Arts.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Communications</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">391-123-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Fieldwork 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Debbie Resurreccion, Heather Martin, Kyle Zacharie, Lara Falquero, Marc Laurent Sauvé, Myka Taylor, Sarah Cartier, Simeon Pompey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The first of three field placements in the program, this course focuses on the actual planning and leading of recreation activities for an organization selected by the student and approved by faculty. Students will understand the responsibilities and professionalism needed when interacting in the workplace.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Plus 3 hours of fieldwork/week.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.2-4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">391-128-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Fieldwork 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Debbie Resurreccion, Heather Martin, Lara Falquero, Marc Laurent Sauvé, Myka Taylor, Sarah Cartier, Simeon Pompey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students further develop their abilities in creating, planning, organizing and leading recreation activities when working for a recreation agency. Students field test their knowledge of program development, administration and evaluation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Plus 6 hours of fieldwork/week.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.2-4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.2-4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">391-184-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Organization and Management of Recreation Programs</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Marc Laurent Sauvé, Myka Taylor</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Working by committee, students plan, implement and evaluate an outdoor education experience. One of the most difficult and important adjustments for the graduating student to make is the application of academic knowledge to the practical experiences faced in the actual "work world" of recreation leadership. The prime focus of the internship experience for the student is learning by doing. The student acquires experience in recreation leadership, supervision, program planning, and evaluation, by working in an agency under trained agency personnel. The student, the agency supervisor, the agency and the College share the responsibilities for this experience.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Off Campus Location</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Off Campus Location</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Off Campus Location</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Off Campus Location</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">420-240-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Infrastructure II</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Linux I</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mahsa Sadeghi Ghahroudi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will explore the Linux operating system in detail. The student will interact with Linux operating system via command-line interface, with emphasis on bash shell commands, the vi editor, utilities and bash scripts to construct and use command sequences to manipulate data and perform basic system administration tasks. The characteristics of a multi-user, multi-tasking, multi-threaded operating system will be examined. Topics related to networking, security, monitoring, industry best practice authentication and directory services operations will be covered. Aspects of connectivity using TCP/IP protocols, and application services such as DNS, DHCP, SSH, and web servers with HTTP will be introduced. The students will also be introduced to virtual machine concepts and creation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Linux II</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">James Bodzay</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will use Linux to reinforce student understanding of web development and distributed systems. The students will also be introduced to virtual machine concepts and creation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">420-620-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Web Development V</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Web Development Project</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Pomerantz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">During this 10 week capstone course, you will develop a web-based application, as a team, from beginning to end. You will apply agile project management practices to engage in activities such as sprint planning, standups, and sprint retrospectives. For the most part, the application will use existing technologies that you’ve seen in other classes, and now you will have to put them all together.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: January 18 to April 6, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, January 31, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Web Development Project</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jaya Nilakantan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">During this 10 week capstone course, you will develop a web-based application, as a team, from beginning to end. 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Stage</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">420-BWC-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Computer Science</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">6 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Computers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chaviva Lifson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will gain a historical appreciation of the evolution and development of computers and will acquire and demonstrate a basic knowledge of computer concepts. You will be able to illustrate the diversity of systems and will learn to recognize the impact of computers through the direct investigation of software. The MS Word processor and Excel spreadsheet will be described and examined. The relationship between computers and networks will be explored with regard to their impact on society. Security, privacy and computer ethics will be examined in the course readings and discussed in class. You will produce a 750-word paper, based on individual research, exploring one of the topics covered in the course.   **Any Science student (First Choice, Health, Pure and Applied, Environmental, ESP, DSP, etc) planning to take Introduction to Computer Programming in Engineering Science (360-420-DW) as a Science option must not take any Computer Science complementary course such as 420-BWC or 420-BXC.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Computers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mahsa Sadeghi Ghahroudi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will gain a historical appreciation of the evolution and development of computers and will acquire and demonstrate a basic knowledge of computer concepts. You will be able to illustrate the diversity of systems and will learn to recognize the impact of computers through the direct investigation of software. The MS Word processor and Excel spreadsheet will be described and examined. The relationship between computers and networks will be explored with regard to their impact on society. Security, privacy and computer ethics will be examined in the course readings and discussed in class. You will produce a 750-word paper, based on individual research, exploring one of the topics covered in the course.   **Any Science student (First Choice, Health, Pure and Applied, Environmental, ESP, DSP, etc) planning to take Introduction to Computer Programming in Engineering Science (360-420-DW) as a Science option must not take any Computer Science complementary course such as 420-BWC or 420-BXC.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Computers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chaviva Lifson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will gain a historical appreciation of the evolution and development of computers and will acquire and demonstrate a basic knowledge of computer concepts. You will thus develop your capacity for computational thinking, a fundamental, everyday skill. Course problem sets are inspired by a variety of domains such as biology, music, finance, and gaming. By learning a programming language and understanding how software “apps” are created, you will be empowered to shape the technology around you and to take an active role in our information age.
**Any Science student (First Choice, Health, Pure and Applied, Environmental, ESP, DSP, etc) planning to take Introduction to Computer Programming in Engineering Science (360-420-DW) as a Science option must not take any Computer Science complementary course such as 420-BWC or 420-BXC.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Web Site Creation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nasreddine Hallam</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will provide the student with the skills to design and develop an effective Web site. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">365-BWP-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Contemporary Issues Set 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Designing Solutions for a Better World (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Miller</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will allow students to explore a contemporary issue of their choice and examine the beginning phases of solving the issue. Through this weeklong intensive course, students will follow various methodologies, mainly, Design Thinking, to help them problem solve. Students will work in groups to research the contemporary issue by understanding the target market and the macro environment. Students will narrow their research to clearly define the contemporary issue and come to a concrete problem statement. Students will then ideate a multitude of possible solutions and prototype these solutions. Students will end the week with testing which solution is most viable and appropriate to solve their contemporary issue.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Thursday, June 1, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 18, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 18, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - 7:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 02, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 02, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jun 02, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jun 02, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Racism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eliza Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">While few people openly declare themselves racist today, racism—both individual and systemic—continues to haunt communities across the world. It rears its ugly head when we discuss “black on black crime,” mass incarceration, poverty rates, and school funding. We see its deadly impact in George Floyd struggling to breathe, Michael Brown’s body lying on the street in Ferguson, and Sandra Bland languishing in her cell. We watch as citizens and politicians openly espouse values that cloak their racism behind the veneers of “economic anxiety” and “traditional values.” We feel its presence when we see advertising, films, and media which under-represent people of color in a world that is mostly non-white. In this Contemporary Issues course, we will be engaging in a cross-disciplinary approach, using historical sources, literature, films, and other materials to examine the rise of race as a “scientific” concept and racism as a historical and present-day reality.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Peace 365</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Peace 365 is an innovative complementary course that seeks to contribute to peace in the world by exploring peace-building from a cross-disciplinary perspective. Locally and globally, conflicts divide people and communities, and undermine well-being and happiness. Students in this course will learn to identify and understand the fundamental conflicts of humanity. The specific roles of several disciplines in understanding peace will be recognized and explored in panels, lectures, and coursework. Students will acquire and practice strategies for creating peace in their relationships with self, community, and nature. Individually and collectively, we will develop the confidence to apply these strategies in the real world, with the aim of creating a more peaceful world for all.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Foundations in Indigenization and Decolonization</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jocelyn Parr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“This course, co-designed by both settler and indigenous educators, will provide a foundational experience to students interested in decolonization and Indigenization of their studies. • Co-taught by one settler and two Indigenous teachers with workshops led by elders, artists, activists, leaders • Grounded in principles of intersectionality, anti-racism and decolonization • Beginning with the TRC as a point of departure, we go further into understanding power and empowerment through the lenses of settler colonialism, consent, self-determination • An effort in reimagining the classroom, creating a decolonized pedagogical experience  • Deepening our understanding of well-being, accountability and community care as they relate to anti-racist and anti-oppressive principles • In an environment that is collaborative and casual (our room has couches!), we’ll introduce Indigenous ways of knowing and learning through talking circles, beading workshops, Indigenous governance systems and more.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">365-BXP-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Contemporary Issues Set 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Learning Perspectives 2</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jocelyn Parr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is for students to examine programs of education and career options in preparation for the next steps at college and beyond. Through individual and group assignments, hands-on projects, and workshops with professionals from a range of fields, students will explore areas of study and professions best suited for their aptitudes, interests and personality. Students will continue to hone skills in writing, organization and presentations and build strategies essential for jobs, education, community and personal goals including communications, networking, project management and interpersonal relations. By the end of the course, students will have created a tentative plan to achieve their professional goals.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Journeys</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">S.P.A.C.E.: Make Things That Matter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joel Trudeau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Make Things That Matter is part of an integrated learning community. It embraces the notion that all problems, even the seemingly intractable ones, can be solved through human ingenuity and a collective desire to improve the lives of all. The course explores problem solving, innovation, and the future through the application of design thinking, social impact tool sets and related methodologies. A sequence of design challenges and activities linked with innovation initiatives concretize the methods. Students generate, develop and realize their own breakthrough ideas by way of learning basic skills of brainstorming, research, prototyping, and public presentations. Collaborating in groups, they may pursue any problem that aligns with the yearly theme of the course, can be related to a contemporary issue and has the potential for a synthesis of disciplines. Final projects may be presented in a variety of public venues and linked with annual SPACE co-curricular undertakings.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Research in Neuroscience</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Hélène Nadeau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Research in neuroscience is developing at an immense speed and is crucial for understanding a large spectrum of phenomena ranging from our everyday behavior to specific health problems. In this course, students will be introduced to the fundamentals of research in neuroscience by designing, conducting and analyzing their own authentic neuroscience experiment using electroencephalography (EEG). In this context students will enter a quest combining natural sciences, social sciences and computer science. This unique experience emphasizes teamwork and close collaborations between students from a variety of programs with a central objective to develop the ability to participate productively in a multidisciplinary "research" team.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Imaging Violence and Nonviolence</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>12001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kim Simard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus is on an urgent contemporary issue: why is violence so widely accepted in our world and how can we build resistance. The Humanities component questions some of our widely-held ideas about violence and explores how acceptance of violence is socially-constructed, while examining a world view that rejects violence on both ethical and practical grounds. The Cin-Com (contemporary issues) component provides students with the tools to deconstruct the visual language that makes violence possible, and engages them in the creation of a student-led media project that resists violence. This unique educational experience emphasizes close collaboration between students and faculty, and allows students to advance their work in both courses at the same time.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section. Students registering for this course MUST ALSO TAKE 345-102-MQ 12001.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Creative Arts</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-113-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Arts and Culture</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jesse Klein</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This required course will introduce students to the Arts and Culture profile from a multi-disciplinary perspective so as to situate the study of artistic expression within the evolution of art and society.  Focusing on at least three key periods or movements, and through a series of case studies, students will consider such questions as: who produces and has produced art and why; the value and purpose different societies and different artists have attached to artistic creation; the impact of social and technological development on art and of art on society; the distinction between high and popular culture; the impact of “mass” culture; and the multiple perspectives from which an artistic creation can be studied and appreciated.  Students will go on at least two outings so as to encourage their exploration of different modes of artistic expression. They will also have an assignment built around a visit to the library and library research.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kim Simard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This required course will introduce students to the Arts and Culture profile from a multi-disciplinary perspective so as to situate the study of artistic expression within the evolution of art and society.  Focusing on at least three key periods or movements, and through a series of case studies, students will consider such questions as: who produces and has produced art and why; the value and purpose different societies and different artists have attached to artistic creation; the impact of social and technological development on art and of art on society; the distinction between high and popular culture; the impact of “mass” culture; and the multiple perspectives from which an artistic creation can be studied and appreciated.  Students will go on at least two outings so as to encourage their exploration of different modes of artistic expression. They will also have an assignment built around a visit to the library and library research.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-232-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">A Way with Words</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leila Roiter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The main aim of the course A Way with Words is to introduce students to the world of academic writing and research. Students will explore various cultural themes through a variety of information from both academic and non-academic sources. Students will compare and contrast the defining characteristics of each type of information source and learn to evaluate the credibility of a source as well as to conduct appropriate academic/scholarly research.  Students will also develop the ability to think critically, to extract the main ideas from the source material, and to establish connections between these ideas. The course will also help students express their ideas clearly and coherently in conformity with the conventions of academic writing.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nathalie Lachance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The main aim of the course A Way with Words is to introduce students to the world of academic writing and research.
