Students will explore various cultural themes through a variety of information from both academic and non-academic sources. Students will compare and contrast the defining characteristics of each type of information source and learn to evaluate the credibility of a source as well as to conduct appropriate academic/scholarly research.  Students will also develop the ability to think critically, to extract the main ideas from the source material, and to establish connections between these ideas. The course will also help students express their ideas clearly and coherently in conformity with the conventions of academic writing.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-496-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Integrating Activity (IA)</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christina Chough</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is part of the Languages Profile Comprehensive Assessment which all students must pass in order to receive their DEC. In this course, under the guidance of a teacher, students will work on a major project related to their studies in the Languages Profile. The project will consist primarily of the development, production, and evaluation of a creative or critical work. The project will provide them with opportunities to demonstrate their creativity, and their ability to integrate the knowledge and skills they have attained in their program of study. Research and interpretation skills, innovation and critical thinking skills, as well as English language skills will also be assessed in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nathalie Lachance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is part of the Languages Profile Comprehensive Assessment which all students must pass in order to receive their DEC. In this course, under the guidance of a teacher, students will work on a major project related to their studies in the Languages Profile. The project will consist primarily of the development, production, and evaluation of a creative or critical work. The project will provide them with opportunities to demonstrate their creativity, and their ability to integrate the knowledge and skills they have attained in their program of study. Research and interpretation skills, innovation and critical thinking skills, as well as English language skills will also be assessed in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-498-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Integrating Activity (IA)</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stefanie L Buxton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Integrating Activity is the required fourth-term course in the Arts and Culture Profile. Students in this course will have the opportunity to evaluate and build upon their learning experiences in the ALC Program.  The Integrating Activity course will be approached as a project-driven workshop requiring students to consolidate the knowledge they've acquired studying in the various disciplines associated with the Arts and Culture profile at Dawson College. The project may be executed in the medium/media of the students' choice, including (but not limited to) creative writing, (such as poems, plays, short stories, etc.) and visual art forms (drawing, painting, collage, sculpture, film, photography, dance, etc.). The course will culminate in a gala or related event presented by the graduating class that serves as the Arts and Culture Profile’s major contribution to the Arts, Literature and Communication’s spring festival.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leslie Baker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Integrating Activity is the required fourth-term course in the Arts and Culture Profile. Students in this course will have the opportunity to evaluate and build upon their learning experiences in the ALC Program.  The Integrating Activity course will be approached as a project-driven workshop requiring students to consolidate the knowledge they've acquired studying in the various disciplines associated with the Arts and Culture profile at Dawson College. The project may be executed in the medium/media of the students' choice, including (but not limited to) creative writing, (such as poems, plays, short stories, etc.) and visual art forms (drawing, painting, collage, sculpture, film, photography, dance, etc.). The course will culminate in a gala or related event presented by the graduating class that serves as the Arts and Culture Profile’s major contribution to the Arts, Literature and Communication’s spring festival.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-914-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Focus on Culture</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leila Roiter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">How does language affect and how is it affected by contemporary culture? Is texting really bringing us to the end of the world as we know it?  How do new words get created? How do ads manage to make us buy things we don’t need? Why do young people say “like” all the time? How does your linguistic baggage shape who you are? Why do people use words from different languages in the same sentence (or switch languages at will)? Why do we all prefer to count and/or swear in one of our languages but not in another? Can language be sexist? These are the kind of mysteries that this course will attempt to shed light on, through discussions, readings, audiovisual presentations (documentaries, podcasts, blogs), individual and group projects, etc. Eavesdropping on people’s conversations around Dawson and analyzing one’s own text messages may be part of the fun!</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-917-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Multiculturalism Through the Looking Glass</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francisco Goire</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will take a closer look at the social and personal realities of living with two (or more) cultures and languages. We will analyze the concepts of multiculturalism and multilingualism and the way they have shaped state policies and social attitudes in selected areas around the world. On a more personal level, we will discuss the relationship between language and culture, examine what life with two or more languages/cultures feels like, how cultures combine in an individual, and how (together with language) they affect perspectives, behaviours, and feelings. Students’ understanding of these issues will be enhanced through readings, discussions, audiovisual presentations, guest speakers, individual research, and other learning activities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-942-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Journalism: Writing Feature Articles</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Gilbert</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Writing Feature Articles, offered in the second term and open to all students in the ALC program, can be taken as a stand-alone course or as part of the Journalism minor, along with Writing News Stories, Journalism and the Web, and The Ethics of Journalism. This course will introduce students to feature writing as a genre of journalism. Students will learn the step-by-step process for writing features, including generating ideas, crafting the pitch, researching, interviewing, structuring, and polishing the final draft. Students will analyze published feature articles for structure and style, acquire specific writing skills through in-class exercises, and develop their own feature articles. Class time will consist of journalistic writing exercises, peer-editing, story meetings, discussion, and other activities. Students will be encouraged to submit their feature articles to the school newspaper, The Plant, and to other publications.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-944-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Journalism and the Web</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Filtz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn how to conceive, produce and publish creative forms of news stories using a variety of electronic media such as blogs, social media platforms, discussion forums, newsgroups, citizen journalism, podcasts, email chains, messaging apps, and newsletters.  The course may include a collective thematic as well as an individual orientation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Filtz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn how to conceive, produce and publish creative forms of news stories using a variety of electronic media such as blogs, social media platforms, discussion forums, newsgroups, citizen journalism, podcasts, email chains, messaging apps, and newsletters.  The course may include a collective thematic as well as an individual orientation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Diagnostic Imaging</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B21-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Radiographic Procedures 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn the standard and specialized radiographic positions/projections of the upper extremity from fingers to clavicle, for both adult and pediatric patients. From the prescription form, students will obtain the history and provisional diagnosis for the patient. Students will prepare to perform the examination by evaluating the patient’s body habitus and selecting the technical parameters. Students will learn how to execute the examination using radiographic and accessory equipment, as well as how to evaluate the radiographic images and post processing techniques. This will involve the identification and description of the radiographic anatomy and various pathologies related to the upper appendicular skeleton. Finally, students will learn to apply patient care, communication, and organizational skills as well as radiation protection, as an integral part of the radiographic procedure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn the standard and specialized radiographic positions/projections of the upper extremity from fingers to clavicle, for both adult and pediatric patients. From the prescription form, students will obtain the history and provisional diagnosis for the patient. Students will prepare to perform the examination by evaluating the patient’s body habitus and selecting the technical parameters. Students will learn how to execute the examination using radiographic and accessory equipment, as well as how to evaluate the radiographic images and post processing techniques. This will involve the identification and description of the radiographic anatomy and various pathologies related to the upper appendicular skeleton. Finally, students will learn to apply patient care, communication, and organizational skills as well as radiation protection, as an integral part of the radiographic procedure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn the standard and specialized radiographic positions/projections of the upper extremity from fingers to clavicle, for both adult and pediatric patients. From the prescription form, students will obtain the history and provisional diagnosis for the patient. Students will prepare to perform the examination by evaluating the patient’s body habitus and selecting the technical parameters. Students will learn how to execute the examination using radiographic and accessory equipment, as well as how to evaluate the radiographic images and post processing techniques. This will involve the identification and description of the radiographic anatomy and various pathologies related to the upper appendicular skeleton. Finally, students will learn to apply patient care, communication, and organizational skills as well as radiation protection, as an integral part of the radiographic procedure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B22-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Radiographic Procedures 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heidi Gumbley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn the standard and specialized radiographic positions/projections of the lower extremity for both adult and pediatrics, from toes to pelvis. From the prescription form, students will obtain the history and provisional diagnosis for the patient. Students will prepare to perform the examination by evaluating the patient’s body habitus and selecting technical parameters. Students will learn how to execute the examination with the use of the radiographic and accessory equipment, as well as how to critique and evaluate radiographic images and post processing techniques. This will involve the identification and description of the radiographic anatomy and various pathologies related to the lower appendicular skeleton. Finally, students will learn to apply patient care, communication, and organizational skills as well as radiation protection, as an integral part of the radiographic procedure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heidi Gumbley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn the standard and specialized radiographic positions/projections of the lower extremity for both adult and pediatrics, from toes to pelvis. Finally, students will learn to apply patient care, communication, and organizational skills as well as radiation protection, as an integral part of the radiographic procedure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heidi Gumbley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn the standard and specialized radiographic positions/projections of the lower extremity for both adult and pediatrics, from toes to pelvis. From the prescription form, students will obtain the history and provisional diagnosis for the patient. Students will prepare to perform the examination by evaluating the patient’s body habitus and selecting technical parameters. Students will learn how to execute the examination with the use of the radiographic and accessory equipment, as well as how to critique and evaluate radiographic images and post processing techniques. This will involve the identification and description of the radiographic anatomy and various pathologies related to the lower appendicular skeleton. Finally, students will learn to apply patient care, communication, and organizational skills as well as radiation protection, as an integral part of the radiographic procedure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B23-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Patient Care and Health & Safety 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will integrate and build on the knowledge and skills acquired in the Patient Care and Health & Safety 1 course. They will become versed in applying the pharmacology of drugs and contrast agents used in medical imaging. Students will learn to calculate drug dosage, and documentation protocol of administrated medication, as well as the legal, ethical, and safety principles of drug administration. This course will also introduce students to the delivery of care in emergency situations. Simulation labs will complement theoretical concepts provided in the classroom setting. The skills and knowledge learned in this course will be utilized during the Clinical practise.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will integrate and build on the knowledge and skills acquired in the Patient Care and Health & Safety 1 course. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B2A-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Clinical Practice 1 (Intensive)</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-142-A, Christina Papathanasopoulos, Heidi Gumbley, Ho-Git Chan, Maria Motta, Mary Ann Hoskin, Peter Mikhail</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will set the foundation for the subsequent Clinical Practice Intensive courses.  It aims to introduce the students to the hospital clinical environment. Students will apply the knowledge acquired in the first-year courses and perform imaging of the upper and lower extremities. The student will enhance their communication skills and professional approach as healthcare team members. The student's ability to integrate theory and practice in a dynamic clinical environment will be assessed under the supervision of the Clinical Instructor or the medical imaging technologist(s).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">INTENSIVE</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, May 31, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">May 29, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">May 29, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Hospital</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B41-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Computed Tomography 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Computed Tomography 2 course continues with imaging of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis. In this course, the student will identify cross-sectional images, anatomy, and pathologies of these anatomical areas. The student will analyze the cross-sectional images for diagnostic quality and adapt imaging parameters to the patient and the pathology. The patient examinations covered include acute care, trauma exams, and the patient care skills that are required for these cases. The student will develop skills to assist the radiologist with interventional procedures performed in CT. Also, the student will develop advanced CT Scan imaging skills such as multiplanar reformatting, virtual and 3D imaging. The radiobiology and protection element will apply advanced radiation reduction software applications and dose reduction guidelines</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Computed Tomography 2 course continues with imaging of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B42-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Magnetic Resonance Imaging 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christina Papathanasopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) 2 will integrate the concepts and skills acquired in MRI 1 with advanced imaging procedures, methodology, quality control, and post-processing techniques as seen in professional practice. MRI safety will be thoroughly examined as well as artifacts and the mechanisms used to eliminate them. Quality assurance tests for an effective QC program will be discussed. MRI procedures of the musculoskeletal, abdominal, and pelvic regions will be studied theoretically and demonstrated by simulation with an emphasis on cross-sectional anatomy, pathology, routine protocols, RF coil, and pulse sequence optimization. Interpretation and analysis of images will also be emphasized.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.19</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christina Papathanasopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) 2 will integrate the concepts and skills acquired in MRI 1 with advanced imaging procedures, methodology, quality control, and post-processing techniques as seen in professional practice. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B44-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Radiographic Procedures 4</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the fourth Procedures course of the program, and it is designed to enable students to integrate all aspects of radiographic examinations of the skull, sinuses, facial bones, and abdomen with adult and pediatric patients. Labs are conducted as exercises in simulation and the skills of communication, organization, patient positioning, handling of equipment, and in applying radiation safety are integrated as part of the complete examination. The student also learns to apply the concepts of physics, skeletal anatomy, pathology, and image quality during the production and evaluation of the diagnostic images.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the fourth Procedures course of the program, and it is designed to enable students to integrate all aspects of radiographic examinations of the skull, sinuses, facial bones, and abdomen with adult and pediatric patients. Students continue to perform, as entry level technologists, all the tasks associated with radiological examinations of all the anatomical systems of the human body, for all age groups. Students are also prepared to participate, at an entry level, in the specialized imaging modalities of angiography, computed tomography, bone mineral densitometry, and magnetic resonance imaging.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">INTENSIVE</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Friday, January 13, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 04, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 04, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Hospital</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Drama</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">560-914-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Plays and Playwrights</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matt Holland</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course involves analyzing plays from different periods from Sophocles to Shakespeare to Modern and Contemporary. Students will analyze style, theme and characterization in plays and explore the playwrights, their philosophies and reactions to world events. The process of playwriting itself will be scrutinized including an examination of structure, plot, dialogue and scene development. Students will visit a working theatre, attend a theatrical performance and will have the opportunity to learn some fundamentals of acting and/or playwriting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">560-915-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Acting Workshop</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Arianna Bardesono</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn fundamental acting techniques and text analysis through monologue and scene work, while also exploring major training areas such as character development, voice, movement and improvisation. The student actor will gain valuable experience in elements of stage craft such as physical presentation, stage business and blocking. Plays from the modern or contemporary repertoire will be selected for scene work. This course will equip the student with basic acting skills as well as an understanding of the rehearsal process from the first reading of the text to the performance. The class will visit a working theatre and each student will also attend at least one theatrical performance with the focus of relating this field assignment to the themes and content of the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-560-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn fundamental acting techniques and text analysis through monologue and scene work, while also exploring major training areas such as character development, voice, movement and improvisation. The student actor will gain valuable experience in elements of stage craft such as physical presentation, stage business and blocking. Plays from the modern or contemporary repertoire will be selected for scene work. This course will equip the student with basic acting skills as well as an understanding of the rehearsal process from the first reading of the text to the performance. The class will visit a working theatre and each student will also attend at least one theatrical performance with the focus of relating this field assignment to the themes and content of the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve<br>Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Economics</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Economics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">21 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlo Catino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media.  For students in the Social Science program, this course is a pre-requisite to all other Economics courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlo Catino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media.  For students in the Social Science program, this course is a pre-requisite to all other Economics courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studiies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Duclos Alegue Feugo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media.  For students in the Social Science program, this course is a pre-requisite to all other Economics courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Duclos Alegue Feugo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media.  For students in the Social Science program, this course is a pre-requisite to all other Economics courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michel Mayer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media. The assumptions of each theory will be clearly stated and the weaknesses of the theory pointed out. Topics covered in the course include market structures, supply and demand, consumer behaviour, behaviour of the firm, production and costs, and the determination of equilibrium price and output in different markets. Using concepts and theories, students will analyze how individuals and companies react to government interventions in the market such as subsidies, minimum wages, and price controls.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for Commerce.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sacha Des Rosiers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course presents concepts and theories that explain how households and firms behave in different markets.
