text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-218-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Economic Analysis</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Economics of Personal Finance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlo Catino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course analyzes the issues facing the consumer, such as overspending, indebtedness, personal investments, intergenerational wealth transfers, and public policy.  It introduces students to concepts relevant to the analysis of consumer choices, such as personal finance, budget planning, personal income tax, insurance, credit, and retirement planning. Students will have a broad understanding of the basic concepts of supply and demand, scarcity, opportunity cost, and other concepts as they relate to consumer decisions. They will also learn how macroeconomic conditions influence the decisions of individuals. The course familiarizes students with the different types of investment available in the financial market. They will analyze the advantages and disadvantages of the major types of financial products. Students will apply cost-benefit analysis to assess the decision of consumers.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-302-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Macroeconomics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michel Mayer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to theories that explain the determination and evolution of macroeconomic aggregates such as GDP, the rate of unemployment, the rate of inflation, and the rate of interest. It discusses macroeconomic theories and models, specifies their assumptions, presents their applications, and identifies their limitations. Relying on historical and current data, the course examines the changes that have taken place in the Canadian economy over the last few decades. Topics discussed in the course include economic cycles, sources of economic growth, fiscal and monetary policies. Students will learn how different schools of thought, namely the Classical and Keynesian schools, approach these topics. The course enables students to apply macroeconomic concepts to specific cases and to critically assess economic policies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for Commerce and International Business Studies.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Philippe Ghayad</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to theories that explain the determination and evolution of macroeconomic aggregates such as GDP, the rate of unemployment, the rate of inflation, and the rate of interest. It discusses macroeconomic theories and models, specifies their assumptions, presents their applications, and identifies their limitations. Relying on historical and current data, the course examines the changes that have taken place in the Canadian economy over the last few decades. Topics discussed in the course include economic cycles, sources of economic growth, fiscal and monetary policies. Students will learn how different schools of thought, namely the Classical and Keynesian schools, approach these topics. The course enables students to apply macroeconomic concepts to specific cases and to critically assess economic policies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for Commerce and International Business Studies.<br>This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-383-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to theories that explain the determination and evolution of macroeconomic aggregates such as GDP, the rate of unemployment, the rate of inflation, and the rate of interest. It discusses macroeconomic theories and models, specifies their assumptions, presents their applications, and identifies their limitations. Relying on historical and current data, the course examines the changes that have taken place in the Canadian economy over the last few decades. Topics discussed in the course include economic cycles, sources of economic growth, fiscal and monetary policies. Students will learn how different schools of thought, namely the Classical and Keynesian schools, approach these topics. The course enables students to apply macroeconomic concepts to specific cases and to critically assess economic policies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-330-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">International Economics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">James Roberts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course helps students understand the economic dynamics of the increasingly integrated world economy and its consequences for countries. The course introduces students to the concepts and theories that explain the patterns of international trade, investment, and migration. It analyzes how the increase in the flow of goods and services and capital across countries over the years - globalization - has created an interdependent world economy, with various challenges and opportunities for countries.  It examines the impact of globalization on the domestic stabilization policies of countries, including Canada. The course also discusses trade policies, balance payments problems, different exchange rate regimes, the political economy of trade agreements such as NAFTA, and the role of international organizations, namely the IMF and the WTO.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-BXS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social science: applications in economics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Economics of Sex and Drugs</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ahmad Banki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will explore a series of social problems from an economic perspective. Students will discover how economic analysis provides useful insights into social problems. In the first quarter of the term, students will learn some of the basic economic concepts and theories that are essential in understanding social problems. They will apply these concepts and theories to examine a selected number of issues. The course discusses selected social issues, including prostitution, drug abuse, addiction, crime, and illegal organ transplant. The instructor may also cover one or more of the major global issues such as climate change, international conflicts, technological change, and income inequality. Students will understand how to apply economic analysis to a wide range of topics and how to assess the decisions of individuals, groups, firms, and governments. The course provides the theoretical framework for social and public policy to address the issues covered in the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Electronics Engineering Technology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">243-212-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sequential Circuits</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sharon Shasha</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will incorporate the basic logic elements from the Combinational Circuits course and utilize them in a clocked environment. 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.22</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">243-416-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Power Supplies</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sharon Shasha</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This lab oriented course introduces students to the fundamentals of power electronics and the power conditioning process.  Experiments will be performed using various power devices, and the knowledge obtained will be utilized to design and construct various circuits such as DC motor controllers and switching power converters. Students will also learn how to interface such power circuits to various elements. Furthermore, proper assembly and soldering techniques will be introduced using copper printed circuit boards.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2H.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-243-B</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This lab oriented course introduces students to the fundamentals of power electronics and the power conditioning process. Students will also learn how to interface such power circuits to various elements. Students learn how to configure a router and a switch for basic functionality. By the end of this course, students will be able to configure and troubleshoot routers and switches and resolve common issues with RIP, RIPng, single area OSPF, virtual LANs, and inter-VLAN routing in both IPv4 and IPv6 networks.  In addition, access control lists (ACLs), Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) for IPv4 and IPv6 networks, and Network Address Translation (NAT) operations will also be explored. Practical laboratory experiments will be performed with a variety of networking components and software.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2H.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2H.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-243-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course describes the architecture, components, and operations of routers and switches in a small network. Furthermore, additional skills learned in other courses such as producing a quality plan, cost estimates and technical document generation will also be included in the overall project completion.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2H.7</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">-2H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2H.7</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>English</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>All students are required to pass an English language exit test in order to receive a D.E.C.  Students are eligible to write the English Exit test once they have completed at least 2 of English 101, 102, 103 and are in the process of taking the third.</p>
<p>Therefore, we recommend that students take 101, 102 and 103 before BXE.</p>
<p>If the last English course you passed was 603-001, your next course is 603-101-MQ Writing English.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-101-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">I.C.E.</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">22 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing English</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-Thérèse Blanc</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Designed for students whose first language is not English and who have been educated in English for less than five years, this course introduces students to the study of literature at the college-level, with special emphasis on vocabulary-building, correct sentence structure, grammar, idiom and critical thinking. 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-102-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literary Genres</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">56 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Irene Ogrizek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Crime and Punishment</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Paul Hawkins</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Often considered among the best novels ever written, Crime and Punishment is a phenomenal introduction to the genre of the novel and to the works of one of the world’s great writers, Russian novelist Fyodor Dostoevsky. His hero Raskolnikov commits what he believes is a fully rational murder, but is unprepared for the consequences. A murder story told from the point of view of the murderer, it’s a harrowing psychological portrait and an intense experience for any reader, as we journey with Raskolnikov through the depths of human depravity. The novel is a brick – 550 pages (approx.). Students should be prepared for a reading challenge. But if you put in the effort, it becomes a page turner, and reading it can be a memorable life experience. We will finish the course by reading a shorter work by a second Russian novelist, Leo Tolstoy’s The Kreutzer Sonata.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry Now</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Bryan Sentes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims at introducing students to  the study and appreciation of poerry, in this case the most recent poetry by today's celebrated poets, both Canadian and international, in both English and translation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry Now</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Bryan Sentes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims at introducing students to  the study and appreciation of poerry, in this case the most recent poetry by today's celebrated poets, both Canadian and international, in both English and translation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Seyed-Gholamreza Shafieesabet</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Modern and Contemporary Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Arsenault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce the student of drama to various plays from the modern and contemporary periods. The five plays that are studied vary each term and are chosen for their challenging topics, innovative structures and compelling language. This course is meant to encourage the reading of plays out loud in the classroom as well as a group presentation of a scene in lieu of an oral. The student will develop a deeper understanding and respect for the genre and hopefully develop a continued interest in theatregoing. The attendance at a play and its written review are mandatory.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">George Slobodzian</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores how poems develop their effects and meanings.  It focuses on lyric poetry—poetry that maps subjective human experience from the perspective of an individual consciousness. We will be looking at some early examples of lyric poetry, as well as the evolution of some key poetic forms over the centuries, but for the most part we will be reading, discussing, analyzing and interpreting poems from the 20th and 21st centuries.   Students can expect to improve their close-reading, analytical and interpretive skills and to put them to use in in-class discussions, short compositions, and essays.   No previous experience with poetry is required, only an open and willing mind.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Contemporary Short Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Gossage</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this genre course, we will study the short story in general, contemporary short stories in particular. We will begin by tracing the history and development of the short story and exploring the elements and techniques short story writers use. Then we will apply this knowledge to a collection of contemporary short stories published in various magazines and journals in the past 15 years. Classes will consist of lectures, grammar/vocabulary/reading quizzes, discussions, group and individual work. Writing and grammar will be done both in and out of class and will take the following forms: e-journals, grammar exercises, short writing assignments, a process written essay, a mid-term in-class essay and a final formal critical essay. Students will also give a group oral presentation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Contemporary Short Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Gossage</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this genre course, we will study the short story in general, contemporary short stories in particular. We will begin by tracing the history and development of the short story and exploring the elements and techniques short story writers use. Then we will apply this knowledge to a collection of contemporary short stories published in various magazines and journals in the past 15 years. Classes will consist of lectures, grammar/vocabulary/reading quizzes, discussions, group and individual work. Writing and grammar will be done both in and out of class and will take the following forms: e-journals, grammar exercises, short writing assignments, a process written essay, a mid-term in-class essay and a final formal critical essay. Students will also give a group oral presentation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Our Stories, Our Voices</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lorne Roberts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Journeys</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Modern and Contemporary Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Arsenault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce the student of drama to various plays from the modern and contemporary periods. The five plays that are studied vary each term and are chosen for their challenging topics, innovative structures and compelling language. This course is meant to encourage the reading of plays out loud in the classroom as well as a group presentation of a scene in lieu of an oral. The student will develop a deeper understanding and respect for the genre and hopefully develop a continued interest in theatregoing. The attendance at a play and its written review are mandatory.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Irish Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyson Grant</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The literature in this course is from critically-acclaimed writers and is varied, complex and rewarding. The first two weeks will be dedicated to a crash course in Irish history with the goal of empowering students and setting them up for a more sophisticated and satisfying engagement with the literature. Please note aspects of the material touch on violence (including sexual violence) and other sensitive topics and could be triggering to some. Rest assured that nothing is sensationalized or superfluous, however, and classroom discussions are premised on respect.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Irish Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyson Grant</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The literature in this course is from critically-acclaimed writers and is varied, complex and rewarding. The first two weeks will be dedicated to a crash course in Irish history with the goal of empowering students and setting them up for a more sophisticated and satisfying engagement with the literature. Please note aspects of the material touch on violence (including sexual violence) and other sensitive topics and could be triggering to some. Rest assured that nothing is sensationalized or superfluous, however, and classroom discussions are premised on respect.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Novella</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew Taylor</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Novellas are works of prose fiction of intermediate length, shorter than novels but (by most definitions) longer than short stories. In English the word novella has come to denote longer stories of the type that enjoyed a boom in nineteenth-century Europe. Novellas offer a more sustained exploration of character and theme than do short stories, but with a unity and focus usually not found in full-length novels (described by Henry James as “large loose baggy monsters, with their queer elements of the accidental and the arbitrary”). As Judith Leibowitz puts it, "Whereas the short story limits material and the novel extends it, the novella does both in such a way that a special kind of narrative structure results, one which produces a generically distinct effect: the double effect of intensity and expansion.”  Students will read some major novellas from the last hundred years and will discuss the cultural and historical contexts of these works, their formal features, and their themes.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Novella</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew Taylor</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Novellas are works of prose fiction of intermediate length, shorter than novels but (by most definitions) longer than short stories. In English the word novella has come to denote longer stories of the type that enjoyed a boom in nineteenth-century Europe. Novellas offer a more sustained exploration of character and theme than do short stories, but with a unity and focus usually not found in full-length novels (described by Henry James as “large loose baggy monsters, with their queer elements of the accidental and the arbitrary”). As Judith Leibowitz puts it, "Whereas the short story limits material and the novel extends it, the novella does both in such a way that a special kind of narrative structure results, one which produces a generically distinct effect: the double effect of intensity and expansion.”  Students will read some major novellas from the last hundred years and will discuss the cultural and historical contexts of these works, their formal features, and their themes.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Shakespeare's Comedies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matt Bergbusch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will explore the genre of dramatic comedy through William Shakespeare’s plays As You Like It, Twelfth Night and The Tempest. We will use Shakespeare’s plays to come to a broad understanding of the key aspects of dramatic comedy. We will explore the plays in the historical context of their production/staging and with a view to understanding their enduring appeal. Historical background texts and other useful sources will be made available online and in class. In this course we will read and discuss literature critically, closely, and sensitively and learn to develop effective spoken and written arguments. The course will include instruction in the revision and editing of texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Shakespeare's Comedies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matt Bergbusch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will explore the genre of dramatic comedy through William Shakespeare’s plays As You Like It, Twelfth Night and The Tempest. We will use Shakespeare’s plays to come to a broad understanding of the key aspects of dramatic comedy. We will explore the plays in the historical context of their production/staging and with a view to understanding their enduring appeal. Historical background texts and other useful sources will be made available online and in class. In this course we will read and discuss literature critically, closely, and sensitively and learn to develop effective spoken and written arguments. The course will include instruction in the revision and editing of texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Crime Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Frank Runcie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Is the crime novel simply a “whodunit”? This familiar term for the genre implies that such novels are simply plot-driven. Is there more to the genre than resolving a mystery, finding the culprit and bringing him to justice? This course offers examples of the crime novel that show both the diversity and the depth of this genre, including hard-boiled detective fiction (and noir aesthetics in general), novels of the Golden Age with literary pretensions, and the thriller. At the same time, the question of social commentary arises in each subgenre of crime fiction. Required readings in this course include Dorothy L. Sayers' The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club, Chester Himes' Cotton Comes to Harlem, and Batya Gur's Literary Murder.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Greek Tragedy and the Modern World</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert J Rose</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course considers the enduring influence of Greek tragedy in the modern world. We will read a selection of plays by the three great Athenian tragedians – Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides – as well as several modern adaptations that relocate the action of the original texts in a range of 20th - and 21st-century settings. Through these works, we will engage with some of the important political crises of our time and in so doing examine the ways that certain prevailing tensions in human civilization (the clash of freedom and tyranny; the allure of military conflict; the resilience of patriarchal domination; the trauma of migration; the terror of plague) can be traced back to the ancient world. One of the principal objectives of our investigations will be to learn what the ancient texts can tell us about our world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Detective Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rita Much</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">After a brief consideration of the origins of detective fiction in Godwin, Poe and Collins, we will evaluate the contribution of the short story form of this sub-genre by a close reading of A.C. Doyle's "The Adventure of the Speckled Band" and short stories by G.K. Chesterton and D.L. Sayers. The main focus is the period between the two World Wars, the Golden Age of the classic English detective novel. We will pay particularly close attention to the influence of the Detection Club, founded in England in 1928, on the conventions of detective fiction in the work of Agatha Christie. Throughout the term, you will be learning the techniques used to create the "puzzle" of "whodunit". This means texts must be read more than once. Theoretical work will consist primarily of lectures and class discussions based on the primary texts as well as relevant secondary sources. Practical work will include film analysis and written analyses of the material, including revisions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts Poetry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan Elmslie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will develop students’ understanding and appreciation of poetry, poetic forms, devices, and strategies. We will practice close reading and recognizing devices and structures with the aim of writing clearly and thoughtfully about poetry in a critical essay. Learning activities may include reading or reciting poetry aloud, reading essays, doing poetry-writing exercises, listening and responding to lectures/discussions, participating in smaller group discussions, and writing informal/formal (analytical) responses to poems. Literary terms will be introduced/reviewed so students improve their comprehension of poetry and can skillfully apply terms of literary analysis. Students will submit an original sonnet for consideration for the Liberal Arts Brick Books Poetry Prize and may be asked to attend a poetry reading and to write a collaborative essay. Each student will make a Favourite Poem video in response to their choice of poem on the Poetry Foundation website.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">American Prose and Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anna-Maria Kibaris</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we study American literature from the end of the nineteenth century until the present. While the main focus of the course is on prose fiction and drama by authors such as Jewett, Crane, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Parker, Faulkner, and Williams, we distinguish the main characteristics of the shifts in sensibility from realism through modernism to contemporary literature. We also discuss the historical, philosophical, and literary background out of which the texts arise, examining, where relevant, gender-related issues. The course includes a close look at the idea of the American dream. There will be lectures, class and group discussions, quizzes, and, occasionally, the presentation of audio-visual material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">American Prose and Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anna-Maria Kibaris</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we study American literature from the end of the nineteenth century until the present. While the main focus of the course is on prose fiction and drama by authors such as Jewett, Crane, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Parker, Faulkner, and Williams, we distinguish the main characteristics of the shifts in sensibility from realism through modernism to contemporary literature. We also discuss the historical, philosophical, and literary background out of which the texts arise, examining, where relevant, gender-related issues. The course includes a close look at the idea of the American dream. There will be lectures, class and group discussions, quizzes, and, occasionally, the presentation of audio-visual material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Postcard Poem</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Burgoyne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">What is prose poetry? Since its inception in nineteenth-century France, writers and scholars have struggled over the definition of prose poetry as a hybrid genre. This course examines Mallarmé’s suggestion that “poetic language itself […] become the main object of investigation of modern poets” (“Crise de Vers”). In this course, we will discuss various effects of poetic language and the spirit of the prose poem by examining its evolution from the nineteenth century until now. This course is designed to improve the student's critical thinking and writing skills about language in general, as the prose poem opens the reader up to devices and techniques common to literary texts. A combination of in-class writing, lectures, group discussion, presentations, field trips, research and audiovisual components will be used in the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Gelineau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will explore the language of drama, analyzing the complex of theatrical signs--language, movement, gesture, setting, music, etc.--that dramatists use to create and tell stories. Students will learn to identify, compare and contrast the dramatic conventions of different periods and societies with particular reference to the origins of ritual drama in ancient Greece and to the theatre of Shakespeare. And we will survey Western drama up until the twentieth century.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Tragedy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Todd Starke-Meyerring</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Tragedy explores the often subtle relationship between an individual and the societal rules that govern everyday life. For many reasons, the tragedic protagonist finds such rules restricting and acts against them. It becomes a question of whose values/ideas/practices are right—those the tragedic protagonist rejects or those he/she embraces. The answer to that question brings about tragedy’s most analyzed generic convention: catharsis. Catharsis is the process by which the emotions elicited by the tragedic protagonist are purged—the initial sympathy for protagonist as well as the later fear of the change that the protagonist represents. Throughout the semester we will read a number of tragedic texts, focusing not only on the narrative form of tragedy, but also the typical conventions involved in a tragedy. We will examine both classical examples or tragedy as well as more modern examples to see how the genre addresses social issues relevant to contemporary audiences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Tragedy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Todd Starke-Meyerring</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Tragedy explores the often subtle relationship between an individual and the societal rules that govern everyday life. For many reasons, the tragedic protagonist finds such rules restricting and acts against them. It becomes a question of whose values/ideas/practices are right—those the tragedic protagonist rejects or those he/she embraces. The answer to that question brings about tragedy’s most analyzed generic convention: catharsis. Catharsis is the process by which the emotions elicited by the tragedic protagonist are purged—the initial sympathy for protagonist as well as the later fear of the change that the protagonist represents. Throughout the semester we will read a number of tragedic texts, focusing not only on the narrative form of tragedy, but also the typical conventions involved in a tragedy. We will examine both classical examples or tragedy as well as more modern examples to see how the genre addresses social issues relevant to contemporary audiences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Contemporary Short Story</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ursula Misztal</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is perfect for students new to comparative literature who are interested in relating fiction to contemporary world events and the modern forces that shape our fluid and unfolding global culture as it emerges. Identity is forged through a dialogue between self and world, and is a reflection of how we have resolved the dilemmas in our lives. Students will try to situate our writers in both social and political contexts. Examining short stories from a wide range of international writers should convey the incredible spectrum of possibilities over which the short story genre can unfold. The course will employ a participatory, hands-on approach to learning about the formal aspects of short stories and familiarizing students with the conventions of literary criticism. Emphasis is placed on essay structure and argumentation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Classical Myth and Modern Imagination</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00029</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne Thorpe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Though the culture that produced them is long gone, classical myths have enjoyed a rich afterlife, surviving and even thriving to this day. But why do we turn to these old stories— endlessly transplanting and adapting them to our own times? What roles do these myths play for us? How can we explain their continued popularity and resonance? This course will give students the opportunity to explore the nature and function of mythic narratives, both for the ancients and for ourselves. We will begin with a brief overview of ancient Greek culture, to better understand the role these myths played for those who originally produced them. Then, we will examine a number of classic myths: reading them first as they were told in the ancient world and then analyzing some of the many creative retellings we find in contemporary literature and popular culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Classical Myth and Modern Imagination</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00030</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne Thorpe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Though the culture that produced them is long gone, classical myths have enjoyed a rich afterlife, surviving and even thriving to this day. But why do we turn to these old stories— endlessly transplanting and adapting them to our own times? What roles do these myths play for us? How can we explain their continued popularity and resonance? This course will give students the opportunity to explore the nature and function of mythic narratives, both for the ancients and for ourselves. We will begin with a brief overview of ancient Greek culture, to better understand the role these myths played for those who originally produced them. Then, we will examine a number of classic myths: reading them first as they were told in the ancient world and then analyzing some of the many creative retellings we find in contemporary literature and popular culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Short Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sabine Sautter-Leger</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines short fiction from different parts of the world. Most of the works on the syllabus were originally published in English; a few are translations.  While paying attention to the formal characteristics of the genre of the short story, students do close-readings, reflect on different writing styles, consider cultural and historical contexts, and evaluate critical responses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Short Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sabine Sautter-Leger</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines short fiction from different parts of the world. Most of the works on the syllabus were originally published in English; a few are translations.
