While paying attention to the formal characteristics of the genre of the short story, students do close-readings, reflect on different writing styles, consider cultural and historical contexts, and evaluate critical responses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry Face-Off: Eliot and Larkin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tijana Stojkovic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will explore the basic elements of the poetic literary genre. We will start with the general question of what poetry is and how it is different from other literary genres, and then focus on the language and form of poetry by studying the works of two major poets from the world of English literature. Both T.S. Eliot and Philip Larkin wrote in the 20th century, but represent two very different poetic traditions: Eliot’s work is the key example of Modernist experimentation in poetry in the first half of the century, while Larkin’s poems revive an older poetic approach but within a new post-war England, and a post-Modernist literary context. By looking at such divergent writing traditions side by side, we are hoping to get a more comprehensive idea of poetry in general, its different manifestations, and the specific social and cultural environments around them.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry Face-Off: Eliot and Larkin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00034</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tijana Stojkovic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will explore the basic elements of the poetic literary genre. We will start with the general question of what poetry is and how it is different from other literary genres, and then focus on the language and form of poetry by studying the works of two major poets from the world of English literature. Both T.S. Eliot and Philip Larkin wrote in the 20th century, but represent two very different poetic traditions: Eliot’s work is the key example of Modernist experimentation in poetry in the first half of the century, while Larkin’s poems revive an older poetic approach but within a new post-war England, and a post-Modernist literary context. By looking at such divergent writing traditions side by side, we are hoping to get a more comprehensive idea of poetry in general, its different manifestations, and the specific social and cultural environments around them.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Lyrical Ballads</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shalon Nicole Noble</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an intensive study of Lyrical Ballads, the landmark collection of poetry published in 1798 as a collaboration by two friends, the famous British Romantic poets William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge. Students will use this work to consider poetry as a concept and the various styles of poetry that comprise Lyrical Ballads. We will study Lyrical Ballads both for its importance in its own time and for its influence upon our own. By the end of the course, each student will be able to read poetry closely, recognize its different forms, theorize the forms’ histories and significance, and demonstrate these abilities both through a term paper and a creative class presentation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Modern Short Story</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00036</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tavish McDonell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A survey of short fiction written over the last 100 years. Authors can include Franz Kafka, James Joyce, Raymond Carver, Toni Cade Bambara, Alice Walker, Flannery O’Connor, William Faulkner, Joyce Carol Oates, Alice Munro, George Saunders, James Baldwin or Shirley Jackson. This course features lots of homework, lectures, discussions, assignments, group work, writing workshops, rewriting workshops, quizzes, koans and essays.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Weird Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00037</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neil Hartlen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Weird fiction overlaps with horror fiction and dark fantasy but distinguishes itself by moving beyond traditional tropes of the supernatural towards more radically undefined — and unsettling — versions of the unknown. Pioneered in the early 20th century by writers like H.P. Lovecraft, weird fiction has been revisited by 21st-century writers including Jeff VanderMeer, Kelly Link, China Miéville, N.K. Jemisin, Victor LaValle, Rebecca Roanhorse, Alice Sola Kim, and many more.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Shakespearean Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00038</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Amanda Cockburn</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Short Story</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00039</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tracie Gemmel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn about the genre of the short story by looking at three remarkable short story writers. Starting with Russian Anton Chekhov, who was writing in the late nineteenth century, and moving on to American Raymond Carver who was influenced greatly by Chekhov, to the sometimes subtle, but accessible Canadian writer Alice Munro; students will observe the development of the short story both historically and stylistically. The class will be made up of close readings, class discussions, writing activities, and the viewing of documentary and feature films. Required texts include Anton Chekhov’s Selected Stories, Cathedral by Raymond Carver and Dance of the Happy Shades by Alice Munro.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Crime Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00040</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Frank Runcie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Is the crime novel simply a “whodunit”? This familiar term for the genre implies that such novels are simply plot-driven. Is there more to the genre than resolving a mystery, finding the culprit and bringing him to justice? This course offers examples of the crime novel that show both the diversity and the depth of this genre, including hard-boiled detective fiction (and noir aesthetics in general), novels of the Golden Age with literary pretensions, and the thriller. At the same time, the question of social commentary arises in each subgenre of crime fiction. Required readings in this course include Dorothy L. Sayers' The Unpleasantness at the Bellona Club, Chester Himes' Cotton Comes to Harlem, and Batya Gur's Literary Murder.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Coming of Age Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00041</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robin E. Feenstra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The literature and films we will explore in this course are all concerned with the momentous, joyful, painful, awkward, epiphanic, and traumatizing experience of growing up. The coming-of-age narrative relates an adolescent’s initiation into adulthood against the backdrop of the loss of innocence, the confrontation with the “real” world, moral dilemmas, rites of passage, individual desires and dreams versus external expectations and norms, failures and disappointments. While this process of maturation and a new awareness of the self can be comedic and liberating, it can also be tragic and painful as the protagonist must accept the complexities of existence and the consequences of their choices and how they affect other people.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Authurian Romance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00042</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charlotte Hussey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">How did an obscure 6th Century Welsh chieftain named Arthur, hero of the even more obscure Battle of Badon, become one of the most enduring figures of Western literature? Attempting to answer this question, the course will examine the earliest literary and historical sources of the Arthurian legend. Variants on the adventures of Arthur, the sorcerer Merlin, the wayward Queen Guinevere and her paramour Sir Lancelot, along with other Avalonian characters will be enjoyed. We will trace how Arthurian literature grew from sketchy historical chronicles into the literary genre called Medieval Romance. Some of the genre characteristics to be looking for are (1) A hero-knight superior to others (2) Courtly Love; a knight’s Love Service to his Lady (3) Imaginary, vague settings (4) Supernatural elements: enchanted weapons & animals, ogres, faeries, druids (5) Disguised identities & kept secrets (6) Faithfulness and courage in adversity & especially on quests, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Postwar Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00043</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chad Lowe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Literature and the arts were forever altered by history’s most cataclysmic event, World War II. This course focuses on how that change manifests itself in the novels, stories and poems of the generation of writers that came of age in the late 1940’s to 1960’s, and how their altered worldview informed their work. Readings will be international in scope, with possible authors including Graham Greene, Kurt Vonnegut, Carson McCullers, John Updike, Muriel Spark, Don DeLillo, Primo Levi, Thomas Pynchon, Kazuo Ishiguro, and Joan Didion.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Autobiography</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00044</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Payne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In recent years, the autobiography/memoir has experienced a resurgence in the publishing industry and today is one of the most popular forms of nonfiction writing. Its success as a genre is not surprising given William Zinsser’s comments that “No other form of fiction goes so deeply to the roots of personal experience.”  As we will see, the urge to ‘confess’ is deeply rooted in the human psyche. In this course, we will explore the personal and social ramifications of this form of writing. Class time will consist of short, focused lectures, writing exercises on ideas related to the memoir form, group and individual workshops.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Autobiography</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00045</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Payne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In recent years, the autobiography/memoir has experienced a resurgence in the publishing industry and today is one of the most popular forms of nonfiction writing. Its success as a genre is not surprising given William Zinsser’s comments that “No other form of fiction goes so deeply to the roots of personal experience.”  As we will see, the urge to ‘confess’ is deeply rooted in the human psyche. In this course, we will explore the personal and social ramifications of this form of writing. Class time will consist of short, focused lectures, writing exercises on ideas related to the memoir form, group and individual workshops.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00046</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kathryn Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an introduction to poetry and so, in this course, we will read a variety of poems (mainly contemporary poems). By reading closely and asking questions about the poems and how they work, we will learn about word choice, figurative language and various poetic structures. Through class discussions and different types of written assignments (both creative and analytic), we will look at how the poems function: how language is at work in the poems and the effects it creates. We will read poems by: Emily Dickinson, Elizabeth Bishop, Ezra Pound, Adrienne Rich, Seamus Heaney and T.S. Eliot (just to name a few). We will also read a few short essays by poets writing about poetry and take an in-depth look at Canadian poetry by examining the work of 10 contemporary Canadian poets. No advance knowledge of poetry is required — just your curiosity and willingness to pose questions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Domestic Gothic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00047</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luke Reid</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Recent cultural production has looked to the Gothic genre as a means of representing the “haunting” traumas of oppression and marginalization. More often than not, these depictions concentrate their horror within the space of the family home. This course contextualizes this resurgence, examining the genre of Domestic Gothic. It interprets the notion of domesticity broadly — from the familial to the architectural, from homemaking to house building. Using the figure of the haunted house, this course tracks the Gothic genre’s evolving treatment of evil from an abstraction that, in the words of Henry James, “cannot be explained away” to a psychological effect deeply situated within history, culture, and systems of power. Texts include James’s The Turn of the Screw (1898), Shirley Jackson’s The Haunting of Hill House (1959), Carmen Maria Machado’s memoir In the Dream House (2019), and Ari Aster's Hereditary (2018).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Domestic Gothic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00048</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luke Reid</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Recent cultural production has looked to the Gothic genre as a means of representing the “haunting” traumas of oppression and marginalization. More often than not, these depictions concentrate their horror within the space of the family home. This course contextualizes this resurgence, examining the genre of Domestic Gothic. It interprets the notion of domesticity broadly — from the familial to the architectural, from homemaking to house building. Using the figure of the haunted house, this course tracks the Gothic genre’s evolving treatment of evil from an abstraction that, in the words of Henry James, “cannot be explained away” to a psychological effect deeply situated within history, culture, and systems of power. Texts include James’s The Turn of the Screw (1898), Shirley Jackson’s The Haunting of Hill House (1959), Carmen Maria Machado’s memoir In the Dream House (2019), and Ari Aster's Hereditary (2018).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Detective Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00049</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louisa Anne Hadley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines detective fiction through the analysis of a range of detective stories from the genre's emergence to more contemporary examples. Through reading these stories, students will come to understand the key features of the detective genre and how different authors have engaged with them. Discussion of these stories will rely on close-reading skills that involve the analysis of literary techniques such as plot, setting, characterization, symbolism, and metaphor.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00050</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kathryn Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an introduction to poetry and so, in this course, we will read a variety of poems (mainly contemporary poems). By reading closely and asking questions about the poems and how they work, we will learn about word choice, figurative language and various poetic structures. Through class discussions and different types of written assignments (both creative and analytic), we will look at how the poems function: how language is at work in the poems and the effects it creates. We will read poems by: Emily Dickinson, Elizabeth Bishop, Ezra Pound, Adrienne Rich, Seamus Heaney and T.S. Eliot (just to name a few). We will also read a few short essays by poets writing about poetry and take an in-depth look at Canadian poetry by examining the work of 10 contemporary Canadian poets. No advance knowledge of poetry is required — just your curiosity and willingness to pose questions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Greek Tragedy and the Modern World</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00051</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert J Rose</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course considers the enduring influence of Greek tragedy in the modern world. We will read a selection of plays by the three great Athenian tragedians – Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides – as well as several modern adaptations that relocate the action of the original texts in a range of 20th - and 21st-century settings. Through these works, we will engage with some of the important political crises of our time and in so doing examine the ways that certain prevailing tensions in human civilization (the clash of freedom and tyranny; the allure of military conflict; the resilience of patriarchal domination; the trauma of migration; the terror of plague) can be traced back to the ancient world. One of the principal objectives of our investigations will be to learn what the ancient texts can tell us about our world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature into Film</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00052</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christian Charette</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The act of storytelling is not only just about as old as humanity itself, it’s also one of the core components of the human experience. We tell stories to share wisdom, give warning, or simply to provide entertainment. This course will take a look at several forms of storytelling – including film, stories, biographies, and photography, among others - in an effort to discover exactly what it is that makes it such an integral part of our lives. We will perform both analytical and creative work. Interspersed throughout the study of these various forms of storytelling will be a study of approaches that are essential to the act of telling stories, and that can also be useful in researching and preparing a formal research paper.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Postwar Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00053</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chad Lowe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Literature and the arts were forever altered by history’s most cataclysmic event, World War II. This course focuses on how that change manifests itself in the novels, stories and poems of the generation of writers that came of age in the late 1940’s to 1960’s, and how their altered worldview informed their work. Readings will be international in scope, with possible authors including Graham Greene, Kurt Vonnegut, Carson McCullers, John Updike, Muriel Spark, Don DeLillo, Primo Levi, Thomas Pynchon, Kazuo Ishiguro, and Joan Didion.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00054</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-603-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Signifying Nothing: Pessimism and the Tragic World View</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Jay Shea, Mikaela Bobiy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">With fools and philosophers as our guides, we’ll read tragedies about suffering and playing human in a world of mysterious machinery, spinning fates, and grinning gods. We’ll explore themes related to time, fate, force, meaning, and human agency in a world-as-stage.    We’ll read Schopenhauer and Camus, run around in circles with the Theatre of the Absurd, talk about robots, play with puppets, listen to Norwegian Black Metal, and read work by techno-, queer-, cosmic-, and Afro-pessimists. We’ll consider the creative possibilities and, perhaps, ethical necessity of keeping it real in a world devoid of meaning, or half-empty at best.    Humanities texts include works by Arthur Schopenhauer, Albert Camus, Sigmund Freud, and Sara Ahmed. English texts include Sophocles’s Oedipus, Shakespeare’s Macbeth, selections from Samuel Beckett, and films Throne of Blood (Kurosawa) and Get Out (Peele).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The unseen world: Magic in Ritual, Fairy Tale, and Fantasy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles, Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Not so long ago, most humans lived in a world where substance was changeable and the natural world — indeed the very air around them -- was inhabited by unseen beings and spirits. They felt connected to that unseen world and believed that it could be made manifest and even manipulated, if they only knew the way to do it. That way was Magic.    This course will seek to understand the role that Magic has played (and continues to play) in the human journey, tracing the story of Magic through the work of historians, anthropologists and sociologists. At the same time, we will explore the ways in which Magic has always lived: in Fairy Tale and Fantasy, stories where the veil between the unseen world and the world of substance grows thin and then dissolves…with a sprinkling of Starstuff, an incantation, a wave of a wand -- or a fervent wish.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-103-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literary Themes</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">27 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Drama of Ibsen and Strindberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Roy Cartlidge</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will explore six plays by Ibsen and Strindberg, two of the most important and innovative figures in the history of world theatre. Special emphasis will be devoted to their choice of themes and range of dramatic styles (realism, naturalism, symbolism, expressionism) and to the social and philosophical climate of the period in which they produced their works. We will also focus on the parallels to be drawn between these two great Scandinavian playwrights, as well as their notorious rivalry. The written work in the course will be focussed on giving clear expression to our personal reactions to these plays. We will also see film versions of at least two works.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Drama of Ibsen and Strindberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Roy Cartlidge</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will explore six plays by Ibsen and Strindberg, two of the most important and innovative figures in the history of world theatre. Special emphasis will be devoted to their choice of themes and range of dramatic styles (realism, naturalism, symbolism, expressionism) and to the social and philosophical climate of the period in which they produced their works. We will also focus on the parallels to be drawn between these two great Scandinavian playwrights, as well as their notorious rivalry. The written work in the course will be focussed on giving clear expression to our personal reactions to these plays. We will also see film versions of at least two works.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Jane Austen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Wendy Thatcher</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will be reading three novels by Jane Austen as well as excerpts from Austen’s letters and commentaries by other writers. In addition to this primary material, there will be discussions and research on the social, cultural, economic and domestic realities of her day – Austen lived between 1775 and 1817 – in order to understand Austen’s fictional universe: her characters, settings, plots, themes, and language. Of particular interest will be the protagonist and the resolution of the conflicts she experiences. Other topics for discussion include Austen’s life, the rise of the woman novelist, gender issues in her fiction, critical reaction to Austen’s work, her influence on literary history and the various film adaptations of her work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Gender Issues in Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Arsenault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the various gender issues that are addressed in four or five highly acclaimed plays that challenge gender role constructs and stereotyping. Plays will be selected from the modern and contemporary periods and students will be encouraged to explore their historical and social contexts. The class will read aloud from the plays and act out a scene in a group. Attendance at a relevant play is mandatory as well as a written review of it. Personal opinions and insights are welcome.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Family Dramas</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyson Grant</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Family Dramas will explore contemporary plays written in or translated into English that have as their primary focus family in all its various forms. Dark themes such as the corrosive effect of secrets, the potentially suffocating burden of parental expectations and the soul-destroying effect of emotional and physical violence will mingle alongside the more hopeful, though often quite complicated, themes of loving parental sacrifice and familial affection. Playwrights are from different countries and are of varying races, ethnicities and genders so we can appreciate differences and overlapping concerns. All of these plays are critically acclaimed and have enjoyed long runs and, in some cases, adaptation into film.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Themes in Shakespeare</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matt Bergbusch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will explore aspects of theme in Shakespeare’s As You Like It (comedy),Othello (tragedy) and The Tempest (romance). We will study the plays in the historical context of their production/staging and with a view to understanding their enduring appeal. Historical background texts and other useful sources will be made available online. In this course we will read and discuss literature critically, closely, and sensitively and learn to develop effective spoken and written arguments. The course will include instruction in the revision and editing of texts. All major assignments will adhere to MLA guidelines re. format, references, and presentation</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">21st Century Novels and Contexts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Slater</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will read three 21st-century novels alongside a range of non-fictional material contextualizing the subjects the novels explore. Though the different novels develop different themes, they all offer, as good novels do, a deep experience of other lives and situations. In doing so, the novels invite us to reflect on a range of human experiences, including our own. Themes explored (and occasionally overlapping) may include the Indigenous experience in Canada; the Black American experience; imagined futures, as explored in speculative fiction; and contemporary women's experience.  Varied assignments will allow you to focus on the aspects of the novels that interest you most.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Drama, Tragic to Absurd</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rita Much</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A close study of the social, historical and philosophical concerns of drama from classical Greek theatre to 20th c. modern theatre. We will consider the origins of drama as an art form and the cultural context in which Sophocles wrote. Then we'll examine Shakespeare's roots in medieval religious drama and Senecan tragedy and how and why the slice-of-life realism of Chekhov was constructed in the late 19th c. Finally, we'll analyze Beckett's legacy of absurdism.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Drama, Tragic to Absurd</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rita Much</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A close study of the social, historical and philosophical concerns of drama from classical Greek theatre to 20th c. modern theatre. We will consider the origins of drama as an art form and the cultural context in which Sophocles wrote. Then we'll examine Shakespeare's roots in medieval religious drama and Senecan tragedy and how and why the slice-of-life realism of Chekhov was constructed in the late 19th c. Finally, we'll analyze Beckett's legacy of absurdism.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Metamorphoses in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Liana Bellon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Webster’s Dictionary defines “metamorphosis” as “a transformation, as by magic or sorcery” or as “a marked change in appearance, character, condition, or function.”  As we will see, writers and artists throughout the centuries have been fascinated by the theme of physical and psychological change. Beginning with the ancient Roman poet Ovid’s collection of poems, written in 1 C.E. and entitled the Metamorphoses, we will analyze how this recurring theme is explored in Shakespeare’s Othello, Shaw’s Pygmalion, Wilde’s The Picture of Dorian Gray, and Kafka’s The Metamorphosis. Towards the end of term, we will read Neil LaBute’s play The Shape of Things, which is the culmination of our course’s theme since it includes many references and allusions to the transformations explored in the works above.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Lord of the Rings</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">J.R.R. Tolkien’s masterpiece, The Lord of the Rings, has undeniably been an important influence on the imagination of readers worldwide. Its imagined world and its characters and story have been reproduced and embellished in visual art, music, poetry and on film.Tolkien’s influence on the genre of Fantasy Literature is just as important. But far from being an escape from reality, we can see that these works, set in an imaginary realm and peopled by fantastic creatures, in fact deal with very real problems and ideas confronted by the 20th and 21st centuries: war, lust for power and its corrupting influence, abuse of the natural world, and the demand upon the individual to fight injustice and evil. By examining the genre of Fantasy Literature through this fundamental example, we will try to understand how fantasy reveals truths about the real world, and how it works as storytelling, connecting with readers at a deep level through the use of archetype and folklore.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Augustan Satire</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Gelineau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine themes of the satirists of the Augustan period. Through an examination of the work of Swift, Wycherley, and Pope, we will see how and why these satirists reacted with moral outrage to the encroaching of what has become the modern world, with its love of individualism, democracy, business, and science. The course will limit itself to the genre of satire in the period; so the study of that genre and its history, as well as the study of the broader historical period and the cultural context these authors were writing in, will be our concern.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Metamorphoses in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Liana Bellon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Webster’s Dictionary defines “metamorphosis” as “a transformation, as by magic or sorcery” or as “a marked change in appearance, character, condition, or function.”  As we will see, writers and artists throughout the centuries have been fascinated by the theme of physical and psychological change. Beginning with the ancient Roman poet Ovid’s collection of poems, written in 1 C.E. and entitled the Metamorphoses, we will analyze how this recurring theme is explored in Shakespeare’s Othello, Shaw’s Pygmalion, Wilde’s The Picture of Dorian Gray, and Kafka’s The Metamorphosis. Towards the end of term, we will read Neil LaBute’s play The Shape of Things, which is the culmination of our course’s theme since it includes many references and allusions to the transformations explored in the works above.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Quest Pattern</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-Thérèse Blanc</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The quest pattern, also known as the hero’s journey, details the passage or crossing of a story’s protagonist from the moment he/she leaves a certain comfort zone to a return to victory and normalcy after facing a number of harrowing obstacles. In this class, as we ponder the universality of this pattern, we will look closely at thematic passages from childhood to young adulthood, from single to married life, and from innocence to knowledge and transgression.The class format will consist of brief lectures, followed by work done in class.The goal of the course will be to develop student analytical autonomy. Films will occasionally be shown. Throughout the semester, a great deal of emphasis will be placed on the writing of sound and intelligent essays and on proper citation rules. Strong note-taking skills are vital to this class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Quest Pattern</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-Thérèse Blanc</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The quest pattern, also known as the hero’s journey, details the passage or crossing of a story’s protagonist from the moment he/she leaves a certain comfort zone to a return to victory and normalcy after facing a number of harrowing obstacles. In this class, as we ponder the universality of this pattern, we will look closely at thematic passages from childhood to young adulthood, from single to married life, and from innocence to knowledge and transgression.The class format will consist of brief lectures, followed by work done in class.The goal of the course will be to develop student analytical autonomy. Films will occasionally be shown. Throughout the semester, a great deal of emphasis will be placed on the writing of sound and intelligent essays and on proper citation rules. Strong note-taking skills are vital to this class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Grief, Loss, and Magic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tijana Stojkovic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“‘Tis better to have loved and lost/Than never to have loved at all.” (Tennyson) “Between grief and nothing, I will take grief.” (Faulkner) Losing something or someone important, and grieving that loss is a universal, unavoidable and formative human experience. The map of a lifetime can be traced through the intricate series of losses, small and big: we can lose other people, we can lose ideals, relationships, friendships, countries, identity, youth, dignity, freedom, beliefs, and all kinds of metaphoric battles. How do we deal with this? How do we grieve, do we talk about it, and how do we talk about it? What is it that allows Tennyson and Faulkner to proclaim the above confidently? What kinds of magic are humans capable of conjuring (and turning into a reality) in order to make sense of their losses? In this class, we’ll speculate on these and other questions with the help of a novella, a few short stories and poems, and a couple of films.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Lord of the Rings</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">J.R.R. Tolkien’s masterpiece, The Lord of the Rings, has undeniably been an important influence on the imagination of readers worldwide. Its imagined world and its characters and story have been reproduced and embellished in visual art, music, poetry and on film.Tolkien’s influence on the genre of Fantasy Literature is just as important. But far from being an escape from reality, we can see that these works, set in an imaginary realm and peopled by fantastic creatures, in fact deal with very real problems and ideas confronted by the 20th and 21st centuries: war, lust for power and its corrupting influence, abuse of the natural world, and the demand upon the individual to fight injustice and evil. By examining the genre of Fantasy Literature through this fundamental example, we will try to understand how fantasy reveals truths about the real world, and how it works as storytelling, connecting with readers at a deep level through the use of archetype and folklore.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Words of Love</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brent Devine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“Love” is among the most malleable words in the English language. We encounter the word on a near daily basis, but its definition is impossible to pin down. Love is at once universal and transcendent, and deeply personal and historical. This course, through the careful investigation of a range of texts from different genres and historical periods, asks you to contemplate diverse literary depictions of love and their consequences. We will consider the medieval romance and courtly love, the fairy tale and true love, queer literature and forbidden love. Students will be encouraged to understand, appreciate, and analyze works of literature, and to write critically about these works by developing their own ideas in the form of a literary essay. Class time will be divided between lectures, class discussions, group work, and in-class assignments. Assignments include reading quizzes, in-class brainstorming and writing exercises, homework (esp. reading), and major essays.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Words of Love</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brent Devine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“Love” is among the most malleable words in the English language. We encounter the word on a near daily basis, but its definition is impossible to pin down. Love is at once universal and transcendent, and deeply personal and historical. This course, through the careful investigation of a range of texts from different genres and historical periods, asks you to contemplate diverse literary depictions of love and their consequences. We will consider the medieval romance and courtly love, the fairy tale and true love, queer literature and forbidden love. Students will be encouraged to understand, appreciate, and analyze works of literature, and to write critically about these works by developing their own ideas in the form of a literary essay. Class time will be divided between lectures, class discussions, group work, and in-class assignments.
