Assignments include reading quizzes, in-class brainstorming and writing exercises, homework (esp. reading), and major essays.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Windrush: Caribbean British Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Frank Runcie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Windrush refers to the postwar generation of Caribbean people arriving in the United Kingdom. Beginning in 1948 and lasting until 1971, these migrants, who arrived as British subjects from part of the empire, would go on to make a huge impression on their new country. Their descendants now run into the fourth generation, and whether in sport, media, or the arts, have changed the U.K. and its idea of itself. This course will look at history, autobiography, and literature (poetry, short story and novel) to come to an understanding of this key element of 20th and 21st century Britain. Among the focuses that arise are identity, race, politics and gender. This course is part of the Women and Gender Studies Certificate.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Windrush: Caribbean British Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Frank Runcie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Windrush refers to the postwar generation of Caribbean people arriving in the United Kingdom. Beginning in 1948 and lasting until 1971, these migrants, who arrived as British subjects from part of the empire, would go on to make a huge impression on their new country. Their descendants now run into the fourth generation, and whether in sport, media, or the arts, have changed the U.K. and its idea of itself. This course will look at history, autobiography, and literature (poetry, short story and novel) to come to an understanding of this key element of 20th and 21st century Britain. Among the focuses that arise are identity, race, politics and gender. This course is part of the Women and Gender Studies Certificate.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Women with Agency</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gina Granter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">To have agency is to be able to exert some control over one’s life: to be an active subject rather than a passive object. Women in patriarchal societies have historically been denied equal agency to that of men, and still face barriers to fully realizing their goals for themselves, particularly if other factors such as racial prejudice, ableism, ageism, class discrimination, homophobia and/or transphobia are involved. In this course students will explore a number of themes related to women asserting their agency, often against norms of their times and places. Novels, essays, and short stories by a diversity of women and nonbinary authors (included because they were assigned female at birth and discuss that experience) are among the course's required works. The relevance of historical and cultural context will be  considered  in  our  discussion  of  works  in  the  course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Year Zero: Writing Around Punk Rock</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Williams</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In the 1970’s Britain was a bleak place for many, especially for the young. Unemployment was high, there seemed to be no hope. Your choices, particularly if you were of the working class, were largely (and perhaps stereotypically), unemployment, the army or a factory job; at least, so it seemed to many. This is the framework of Punk Rock, a musical movement and, in Britain particularly, a social movement as well.  This course will explore a variety of writing around this movement. Starting with 1976 (and a little before) and moving to 1978 (and a little after) we will investigate a selection of lyrics, videos, essays, journalism, biography and other fiction and nonfiction work in an attempt to define the movement and examine the resonance which is still felt to this day. Topics to be covered (amongst others) deal with questions of class, income equality, educational opportunities, race, gender discrimination, lgbqia2+ inclusion, and DIY philosophy.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Year Zero: Writing Around Punk Rock</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Williams</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In the 1970’s Britain was a bleak place for many, especially for the young. Unemployment was high, there seemed to be no hope. Your choices, particularly if you were of the working class, were largely (and perhaps stereotypically), unemployment, the army or a factory job; at least, so it seemed to many. This is the framework of Punk Rock, a musical movement and, in Britain particularly, a social movement as well.  This course will explore a variety of writing around this movement. Starting with 1976 (and a little before) and moving to 1978 (and a little after) we will investigate a selection of lyrics, videos, essays, journalism, biography and other fiction and nonfiction work in an attempt to define the movement and examine the resonance which is still felt to this day. Topics to be covered (amongst others) deal with questions of class, income equality, educational opportunities, race, gender discrimination, lgbqia2+ inclusion, and DIY philosophy.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Past: Memory, History, and Narrative</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luke Reid</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the complex and often fraught interplay between memory and narrative, particularly in the face of traumatic historical and personal events. How do we use memory to revisit and reconstruct the past, especially that which is difficult to face? How do we use narrative to understand but also evade these histories, both individual and collective? Looking at the work of such writers as Kazuo Ishiguro, W.G. Sebald, Colson Whitehead, Nona Fernandez, and Mariana Enriquez, we will pose these questions alongside specific historical milieus and events, from the Holocaust to post-World War II Japan, from the Jim Crow South to the Dirty War and “disappeared” of South America. In these texts, the past is never past, and the characters and narrators we encounter both retreat within and turn away from their own memories, in some cases grappling with their own complicity and guilt, in others finding moments of reckoning and even defiance.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing the Great War</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Weisberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine how the First World War (1914-1918) transformed Western society and played a significant role in shaping the culture, values, and geography of the modern world. After a brief introduction to the concept of warfare, students will move to an examination of the Great War’s literature — primarily poetry and excerpts from memoirs. The class will focus on how soldiers responded to the physical and psychological trauma of the War but will also examine writing by non-combatants to see how the effects of the War were felt well beyond its battlefields.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-603-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-213-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Poetry and Prosody</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry and Prosody</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan Elmslie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Poetry and Prosody is a required second-term course in the Literature Profile that focuses on the study and exploration of poetics. By engaging in the study of prosody, students will familiarize themselves with poetry’s formal components, including elements of versification such as meter, rhyme, and stanza forms, as well as the rhetorical and sonic effects of a poem’s composition. Developing and demonstrating their recognition and proper use of prosodic terminology, students may be asked to apply their understanding of these elements to close textual analysis, while also taking into account a poem’s ideas, structure, and tone. They may also consider various poetic traditions and critical approaches to poetry and poetics theory, and they may be asked to incorporate secondary sources in their exploration of poetry and poetry-writing practices. Students will be writing essays, shorter assignments, and possibly a creative project as well.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry and Prosody</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Gelineau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Poetry and Prosody is a required second-term course in the Literature Profile that focuses on the study and exploration of poetics. By engaging in the study of prosody, students will familiarize themselves with poetry’s formal components, including elements of versification such as meter, rhyme, and stanza forms, as well as the rhetorical and sonic effects of a poem’s composition. Developing and demonstrating their recognition and proper use of prosodic terminology, students may be asked to apply their understanding of these elements to close textual analysis, while also taking into account a poem’s ideas, structure, and tone. They may also consider various poetic traditions and critical approaches to poetry and poetics theory, and they may be asked to incorporate secondary sources in their exploration of poetry and poetry-writing practices. Students will be writing essays, shorter assignments, and possibly a creative project as well.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-413-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Creative Writing Workshop</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christian Charette</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Creative Writing Workshop is a required fourth-term course in the Literature Profile. This course is designed to develop students’ skills in creative writing.  Attention will be given to developing writers’ sense of craft through writing exercises, workshopping by peers, and critique.  Writers will have the opportunity to work within some traditional genres (poetry fixed forms, short story) as well as try their hands at other genres.  The ethos of the course will be writing as craft and as play, and workshop participants are encouraged to approach writing assignments with readiness and openness.  Active participation in the workshop is required; carefully reading and responding to other writers’ work are crucial components of the course.  At the end of the course, writers will submit a portfolio of work developed throughout the term, and they will be encouraged to submit to Creations, the Literature Profile journal.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrea Strudensky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Creative Writing Workshop is a required fourth-term course in the Literature Profile. This course is designed to develop students’ skills in creative writing.  Attention will be given to developing writers’ sense of craft through writing exercises, workshopping by peers, and critique.  Writers will have the opportunity to work within some traditional genres (poetry fixed forms, short story) as well as try their hands at other genres.  The ethos of the course will be writing as craft and as play, and workshop participants are encouraged to approach writing assignments with readiness and openness.  Active participation in the workshop is required; carefully reading and responding to other writers’ work are crucial components of the course.  At the end of the course, writers will submit a portfolio of work developed throughout the term, and they will be encouraged to submit to Creations, the Literature Profile journal.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-498-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Integrating Activity (IA)</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Liana Bellon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Integrating Activity is the required fourth-term course in the Literature Profile. In preparation for university studies, students research and write a major paper or project that integrates the knowledge they have gleaned from their two years of literature courses and related courses in other arts disciplines in the program. The course may culminate in an academic conference or related event presented by the graduating class that serves as the Literature Profile’s major contribution to the Arts, Literature and Communication program’s spring festival.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-914-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literary Currents</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literary Currents</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shalon Nicole Noble</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This section of Literary Currents will study Romanticism, with special emphasis upon the second generation most famously spearheaded by figures like Byron, the Shelleys, and Keats. We will study key Romantic texts of various genres, with special attention to poetry and the contemporary theories that motivate it, in order to understand core elements of the Romantic imagination. We will also situate these texts within the social context of their historical moment (including their relationship to the Enlightenment and the Victorian period/Modernism). Students will demonstrate their growing understanding of Romanticism through a variety of activities and will be encouraged to trace the continuing legacy of Romanticism in today’s art and culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-915-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literature and Creative Practice</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Burgoyne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Literature and Creative Practice, offered in the second term and open to all students in the ALC program, focuses on the process of writers in the development and dissemination of their work. The theory and practice of creative techniques and their application in different genres are components of the course. To this end, students may study primary texts (for instance, poems or poetry collections, fiction, drama, or work in other genres) as well as authors’ commentary on the creative process, in the form of published articles, books, letters, or interviews. Students will respond to literary works through careful analysis and experimentation. Engaging with aspects of creative practice considered in the course, students will develop their own critical and creative work. Creative practices students will engage in may include, but are not limited to, theatrical productions, the creation of an anthology, and creative writing, all of which may be incorporated into the ALC Festival.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-917-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literature and Borders</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pauline Morel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Literature and Borders, offered in the fourth term of the Literature Profile and open to all students in the ALC program, is a study of literature that explores notions of place and identity. The texts studied may include, but are not limited to, such themes and topics as national identities, cross-cultural exchanges, First Peoples’ perspectives, gender and cultural difference, travel narratives, the immigrant experience, and Canadian and world politics. Students may be encouraged to write at least one essay that incorporates secondary research as well as literary analysis.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-BXE-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Themes in English</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">47 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Rhetoric</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Roy Cartlidge</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to develop students' proficiency in producing well-structured texts and oral reports that will prepare them for the writing challenges they will encounter in their chosen careers. An important aim of the course is to show that academic writing, literary criticism, business writing, scientific reporting and journalism are not wholly distinct disciplines, but depend on the same criteria of clearly formulated purpose, awareness of audience, exactness and economy of expression, and internal cohesion that characterize all good writing. Consequently, the course will be divided between understanding argument through analysis and practising argument through composition.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Jordan Peterson's Rules for Life</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Paul Hawkins</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to the ideas of Jordan Peterson, a Canadian psychologist and internationally known author whose work combines self-help, psychology, and cultural history (in Winter 2023, the one-course text will be Peterson’s Beyond Order: 12 More Rules for Life). Peterson offers fascinating insights into life issues grounded in a bibliography referencing contemporary scholarship and great books of the past. As a public intellectual, Peterson has generated significant controversy for challenging what he sees as the left-wing bias within universities and the general culture. I hope that considering the book in the context of some of Peterson’s other public statements and the reaction that his thinking has generated — pro, con, and in between — will make for an exciting interdisciplinary course, in which students will complete a project linking some of Peterson’s themes to their program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Jordan Peterson's Rules for Life</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Paul Hawkins</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to the ideas of Jordan Peterson, a Canadian psychologist and internationally known author whose work combines self-help, psychology, and cultural history (in Winter 2023, the one-course text will be Peterson’s Beyond Order: 12 More Rules for Life). Peterson offers fascinating insights into life issues grounded in a bibliography referencing contemporary scholarship and great books of the past. As a public intellectual, Peterson has generated significant controversy for challenging what he sees as the left-wing bias within universities and the general culture. I hope that considering the book in the context of some of Peterson’s other public statements and the reaction that his thinking has generated — pro, con, and in between — will make for an exciting interdisciplinary course, in which students will complete a project linking some of Peterson’s themes to their program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing about the Novel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Simon Fanning</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a survey of the novel. After discussing the rise of the genre in the eighteenth century and considering representative excerpts from authors such as Defoe, Richardson, and Fielding, we will study two nineteenth-century novels, two modernist works, and a novel by a contemporary author. Particular attention will be paid to the historical contexts of the books and the connections between the development of the novel form and social, historical, philosophical, and technological developments in Western society.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Food for Thought: From Farm to Table</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Wendy Thatcher</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we are going to look at many aspects of food ? the good, the bad, and the ugly ? and read some important contemporary texts about the implications of diet for humans and the planet. Readings will vary from short stories, essays, articles and to longer works; they will include selections from Lolis Eric Elie, Anthony Bourdain, Michael Pollan, T.C. Boyle, various chefs, Anna Lappe, Adam Gopnik, Sonia Faruqi, and Sarah Elton, the latter three being Canadian. Some of the issues covered will be food choices, fast food vs. slow food, factory farms vs. the organic alternative, animal welfare, the local food movement, and food waste, amongst others. We will be looking at rhetorical strategies used by these writers and at ways to improve reading, writing and presentation skills. Student responses will include a personal essay, restaurant and film reviews, letters, an analytical essay, a presentation, and culminating in a research essay of 1000 words related to your program.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Food for Thought: From Farm to Table</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Wendy Thatcher</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we are going to look at many aspects of food ? the good, the bad, and the ugly ? and read some important contemporary texts about the implications of diet for humans and the planet. Readings will vary from short stories, essays, articles and to longer works; they will include selections from Lolis Eric Elie, Anthony Bourdain, Michael Pollan, T.C. Boyle, various chefs, Anna Lappe, Adam Gopnik, Sonia Faruqi, and Sarah Elton, the latter three being Canadian. Some of the issues covered will be food choices, fast food vs. slow food, factory farms vs. the organic alternative, animal welfare, the local food movement, and food waste, amongst others. We will be looking at rhetorical strategies used by these writers and at ways to improve reading, writing and presentation skills. Student responses will include a personal essay, restaurant and film reviews, letters, an analytical essay, a presentation, and culminating in a research essay of 1000 words related to your program.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Reading of Digital Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lee Scott Young</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will examine a number of the forces shaping society in the post-millennial cultural landscape, particularly the Internet and how it is affecting our notions of literacy, identity, knowledge, and our common cultural experience. The approach will be to examine how new forms of digital media are changing the way that we deliver, receive, create and experience text. Emphasis will be on social networking, blogging, and other forms of user-generated content, as well as journalism, advertising, privacy and copyright issues. Each student will do a research project that will ultimately be developed into an oral presentation and final paper and which will allow the student to explore how her or his specific discipline intersects with some of the main themes of the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Creative Nonfiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Syba</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">At its best, creative nonfiction is both perceptive and precise in its descriptions, seeking to capture a surprising truth about a particular person, experience, issue, or phenomenon. We will read a number of models, from genres that include memoir, feature articles, and profiles. Ultimately, you will write your own work of creative nonfiction. Over the term, you will do a series of exercises towards a revised piece of 1500 to 2000 words — from brainstorming to narrowing your focus, research, an exploratory draft, a full draft, and a revised work. The topic is up to you. The requirement is to produce a work that: 1) is related to your program of study, even if tangentially; 2) indicates significant research; 3) uses a range of creative formal strategies (sensory detail, dialogue, etc.) to engage a general reader; 4) (not least!) interests YOU.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Women and Anger</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Slater</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">While women's anger is not a new phenomenon, fiction and non-fiction books chronicling and channelling women's anger have been coming fast and furious in recent years. In Rage Becomes Her (2018), Soraya Chemaly notes that “It is easier to criticize angry women than to ask the questions ‘What is making you so angry?’ and ‘What can we do about it?’” This course will explore these questions through selected recent fiction and non-fiction. The non-fiction texts provide data and report many women's lived experiences; the fictional texts offer sometimes satiric social commentary and/or revenge fantasy, but also serious consideration of Chemaly's second question: what to do in the face of these conditions? Heads up: some course material includes violence against women and girls, including rape, and violence against men, including dismemberment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Women and Anger</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Slater</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">While women's anger is not a new phenomenon, fiction and non-fiction books chronicling and channelling women's anger have been coming fast and furious in recent years. In Rage Becomes Her (2018), Soraya Chemaly notes that “It is easier to criticize angry women than to ask the questions ‘What is making you so angry?’ and ‘What can we do about it?’” This course will explore these questions through selected recent fiction and non-fiction. The non-fiction texts provide data and report many women's lived experiences; the fictional texts offer sometimes satiric social commentary and/or revenge fantasy, but also serious consideration of Chemaly's second question: what to do in the face of these conditions? Heads up: some course material includes violence against women and girls, including rape, and violence against men, including dismemberment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing Work</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan Elmslie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on writing about work and the work of writing. What is “the work of writing”? It deals with the complex issues of purpose, audience, genre, and voice that all writers face” (Elizabeth Rankin, The Work of Writing). And writing about work? We will read and listen to stories and essays about various kinds of work and, by responding to these texts, further develop skills in reading, writing, speaking, and researching. Because the BXE course includes a program-specific major assignment, you will employ in this writing terminology and rhetorical strategies pertinent to your field of study. Your writing about work will comprise various forms of communication, including some creative writing, which engages a reader’s imagination and emotions. Revising and editing are key to constructing writing that works. You will learn to harness the power of precision and persuasion to close the gap between what you want to communicate and what your reader or listener apprehends.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Inquiry-Based Writing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Todd Starke-Meyerring</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will focus on the concept of inquiry-based writing, which is to say in order to be an informed speaker on a given issue or topic, you will need to inquire deeply into the issue. Only from a position of understanding can we stake a claim to a position and argue for that position. As a consequence, our focus will be on not only understanding a text from its rhetorical position, but also focus on asking questions of the text as well as ourselves. In addition, there are issues of information, credibility, and authority that must be considered and questioned. Ultimately, inquiry-based writing will ask you to ask questions of yourself and to seek information. A healthy dose of skepticism will also be needed — we cannot simply accept what has been said simply because it has been said. In the end, we want to be authoritative, informed individuals. From that position, we can write with confidence, confidence that will be evident to a reader.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Robot Visions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ursula Misztal</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will explore the concept of robots/automatons both in terms of the line between human/non-human categories, as well as a promise of future and present technological possibilities. A combination of fiction and non-fiction readings, this course aspires to have a broader, interdisciplinary appeal to students studying in different programs, and will offer the possibility to write a research paper (summative assessment) on AI technology, as it relates to their programs of study. Some essays & assignments will have a more literary scope & purpose. In our attempt to read both fiction & non-fiction related to robots, some of which spans over a hundred years of time, we will try to establish a broader historical context for thinking about a topic that is so provoking to our imagination today!</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Robot Visions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ursula Misztal</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will explore the concept of robots/automatons both in terms of the line between human/non-human categories, as well as a promise of future and present technological possibilities. A combination of fiction and non-fiction readings, this course aspires to have a broader, interdisciplinary appeal to students studying in different programs, and will offer the possibility to write a research paper (summative assessment) on AI technology, as it relates to their programs of study. Some essays & assignments will have a more literary scope & purpose. In our attempt to read both fiction & non-fiction related to robots, some of which spans over a hundred years of time, we will try to establish a broader historical context for thinking about a topic that is so provoking to our imagination today!</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Rhetorical Strategies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sabine Sautter-Leger</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students further strengthen their reading and writing skills.  Through careful rhetorical analysis and regular writing practice, students will come to assess and appreciate different techniques, styles, and purposes of prose. Readings will be mostly — but not exclusively — recent non-fiction works addressing a variety of subjects relevant to contemporary concerns.  (Topics to be covered could include the media, sports, internet, art, food, culture, environment, writing, gender, ethics, jobs, cities, advertising, etc.). Classroom discussion and activities will be linked through a major project to issues central to students’ programmes of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Non-Fiction Workshop</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Weisberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Using Zinsser’s text as our guide, we will explore several areas of non-fiction: letters, writing about the arts, and travel writing. We will read some preeminent examples from each category, after which you will create your own. We will also use Zinsser’s book to improve your writing and reading skills to the point where you develop a fluency with the specialized vocabulary and conventions of non-fiction writing. Towards the end of the course, you will complete an oral presentation, and on the last day of classes, you will submit a major research paper that relates to your program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Non-Fiction Workshop</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Weisberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Using Zinsser’s text as our guide, we will explore several areas of non-fiction: letters, writing about the arts, and travel writing. We will read some preeminent examples from each category, after which you will create your own. We will also use Zinsser’s book to improve your writing and reading skills to the point where you develop a fluency with the specialized vocabulary and conventions of non-fiction writing. Towards the end of the course, you will complete an oral presentation, and on the last day of classes, you will submit a major research paper that relates to your program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Storytelling Animal</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrea Strudensky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">We use stories to make sense of our world and share that understanding with others. We use stories to entertain and educate, to argue and debate, to confess and understand. We will study some of the major genres of storytelling: epic, myth, tragedy, allegory, and romance in the realms of fiction, and non fiction and consider questions like: What are the formal elements that make for a great story? How do character, theme, plot, perspective, and style contribute to our understanding of a story? How does a story’s medium, as an oral, visual, virtual, or print-based text, change or alter our sense of its place and importance in our society? What hopes and desires, needs and anxieties, does it answer to? How do the representations of gender, sexuality, race, and class inform the art and practice of story-telling? As well, we will practice our own creative storytelling skills in order to gain a deeper understanding of how writers tell stories, and to help us define our own narrative voice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Culture and Rhetoric</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tavish McDonell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines rhetorical strategies in contemporary culture over three units:      1.	Reading images and consumer culture. What rhetorical strategies can we identify in ads and public service announcements? How should we conceptualize the position of the individual within consumer culture? Students will write a rhetorical analysis of an ad/brand or PSA.   2.	Conspiracy theories and moral panics. What are conspiracy theories and moral panics and how do they spread? How can we promote media literacy and limit their impact? Students will write an essay refuting a text/news story/podcast/viral video promoting a false idea.   3.	Personality and the individual. What insights can be gained from personality testing and psychoanalysis? How can we read films as rhetoric about the development of the individual? Students will write an essay about their personality, their experience in their program, a goal and a film.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Culture and Rhetoric</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tavish McDonell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines rhetorical strategies in contemporary culture over three units:      1.	Reading images and consumer culture. What rhetorical strategies can we identify in ads and public service announcements? How should we conceptualize the position of the individual within consumer culture? Students will write a rhetorical analysis of an ad/brand or PSA.   2.	Conspiracy theories and moral panics. What are conspiracy theories and moral panics and how do they spread? How can we promote media literacy and limit their impact? Students will write an essay refuting a text/news story/podcast/viral video promoting a false idea.   3.	Personality and the individual. What insights can be gained from personality testing and psychoanalysis? How can we read films as rhetoric about the development of the individual? Students will write an essay about their personality, their experience in their program, a goal and a film.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing about Film</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neil Hartlen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For this course, film will be considered as a broad category that includes the movies of classic and contemporary Hollywood cinema, scripted television comedies, documentary films, independent/art cinema, and world cinema. By screening various examples from these different areas, we will consider the general concerns of storytelling and argument in audiovisual media. Studying writing about film will also allow us to address the basics of argument in print and other verbal media. We will read and analyze various examples of nonfiction writing including film reviews, cultural journalism, scholarly film criticism, and scholarly writing in other academic fields. Readings will prepare each student for the major writing assignments for the course which will include critical essays on short and feature-length films as well as a rhetorical analysis of a scholarly article relevant to the student’s program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing about Film</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neil Hartlen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For this course, film will be considered as a broad category that includes the movies of classic and contemporary Hollywood cinema, scripted television comedies, documentary films, independent/art cinema, and world cinema. By screening various examples from these different areas, we will consider the general concerns of storytelling and argument in audiovisual media. Studying writing about film will also allow us to address the basics of argument in print and other verbal media. We will read and analyze various examples of nonfiction writing including film reviews, cultural journalism, scholarly film criticism, and scholarly writing in other academic fields. Readings will prepare each student for the major writing assignments for the course which will include critical essays on short and feature-length films as well as a rhetorical analysis of a scholarly article relevant to the student’s program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM -
