6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Text and the City: Writing Montreal</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Amanda Cockburn</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature and Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brent Devine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Is human morality natural and inherent, or is it invented and learned? What role does morality play in defining what it means to be human? Is it wise, or even possible, to follow absolute moral rules? Is narrative essential to the transmission of moral values? These questions, and many others, will be the focus of this course, which asks you to engage with challenging literary works and investigate their overt, implied, and unintended moral claims. Students will be encouraged to understand, appreciate, and analyze works of literature, and to write critically about these works by developing their own ideas in the form of the literary essay. Class time will be divided between lectures, class discussion, group work, and in-class assignments. Assignments include reading quizzes, in-class brainstorming and writing exercises, homework (esp. reading), literary essays, and a written and oral project related to students’ programs of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Rhetorical Strategies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tracie Gemmel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to teach students how to employ various rhetorical strategies used in written communication. Through the analysis of various essays and formal rhetoric, students will learn how to write a variety of professional and academically orientated texts with presentation, audience and purpose in mind. This course will also focus on strategies for generating ideas, conducting research, planning, organizing, revising and editing texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Rhetorical Strategies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tracie Gemmel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to teach students how to employ various rhetorical strategies used in written communication. Through the analysis of various essays and formal rhetoric, students will learn how to write a variety of professional and academically orientated texts with presentation, audience and purpose in mind. This course will also focus on strategies for generating ideas, conducting research, planning, organizing, revising and editing texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Humans, Animals, and the Environment</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gina Granter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students examine different manifestations of the human relationship with the natural world, both animate and inanimate, from the more obvious stories about humans surviving in the face of harsh weather or predatory animals to more subtle interrogations of humanity’s place within or separate from the natural world. The geographical focus will be on works from North America, and the class will study a broad range of works produced since the landing of Europeans in the Americas. The goal of the course is to introduce students to a range of ideas concerning the place of human beings in the context of other animals and the environment. Final projects in this course will be related to students’ programs of study and will explore some environmental issue in that context.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00029</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Trevor Rouse</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students to develop further their skills in reading, writing, speaking, and researching. Students will study and produce various forms of communication while strengthening their skills in argumentation. They will learn to recognize and use various rhetorical strategies in order to produce a program-specific major assignment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Dystopian Fictions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00030</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robin E. Feenstra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A “dystopia” is an imaginary place or state in which things are unpleasant or bad, as from some form of deprivation, oppression, or terror. Keith Booker defines dystopian fiction as “any imaginative view of a society that is oriented toward highlighting in a critical way negative or problematic features of that society’s vision of the ideal.” Our focus will be on the critical element of Booker’s definition—in novels like 1984 and The Hunger Games, short stories like “Harrison Bergeron” and “Caught in the Organ Draft,” films like V for Vendetta and Gattaca—and thus on extracting and analyzing the principal themes and sub-themes of these dystopian fictions: justice, freedom, individuality, morality, ethical behaviour, cognitive estrangement, power, surveillance, time, betrayal, the integrity of mind and body, children, the public and private, sexuality, religion, language, and history."</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Dystopian Fictions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robin E. Feenstra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A “dystopia” is an imaginary place or state in which things are unpleasant or bad, as from some form of deprivation, oppression, or terror. Keith Booker defines dystopian fiction as “any imaginative view of a society that is oriented toward highlighting in a critical way negative or problematic features of that society’s vision of the ideal.” Our focus will be on the critical element of Booker’s definition—in novels like 1984 and The Hunger Games, short stories like “Harrison Bergeron” and “Caught in the Organ Draft,” films like V for Vendetta and Gattaca—and thus on extracting and analyzing the principal themes and sub-themes of these dystopian fictions: justice, freedom, individuality, morality, ethical behaviour, cognitive estrangement, power, surveillance, time, betrayal, the integrity of mind and body, children, the public and private, sexuality, religion, language, and history."</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Bigger Picture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jeffrey Gandell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In The Bigger Picture, you will put on your journalist hat and work on one long feature story (like a magazine article) over the course of the semester. A feature story involves a deep dive into a recent event, trend, or phenomenon. You’ll discover the bigger picture of your story through research and interviews and puzzle the pieces together through several brainstorming and planning stages. The focus will be on finding the story behind the story — the greater social, cultural, political, and economic factors at play. This class will teach you how to write — to really write — to create the kind of prose that can move people and change the world. Of particular importance are a burning sense of curiosity and a dedicated work ethic. You will choose the topic of your feature story, allowing you to produce a moving and well-told story through your own unique voice and style.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Creativity</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charlotte Hussey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This cross-disciplinary course will provide the opportunity to explore what creativity means to you, as well as in your chosen field of practice. You will begin waking up your imagination via exercises designed by the visionary artist Alex Grey. You will record your explorations in a journal along with drawings, doodles, etc., as your creative process unfolds. At the heart of this hands-on, experiential course lies your own project; it can range from making a piece of art, to writing an academic essay, to drafting a work-place, problem-solving report. You will take your project through these stages—wishing, choosing, starting, working, completing, and showing.You will learn strategies from psychotherapist Eric Maisel for overcoming such blocks as hungry mind, confused mind, chaotic mind, or shy mind anxiety. By semester’s end, you will do an oral presentation and a written report on your “work-in-progress,” describing what you have learned about sustaining your own creative practice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Creativity</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00034</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charlotte Hussey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This cross-disciplinary course will provide the opportunity to explore what creativity means to you, as well as in your chosen field of practice. You will begin waking up your imagination via exercises designed by the visionary artist Alex Grey. You will record your explorations in a journal along with drawings, doodles, etc., as your creative process unfolds. At the heart of this hands-on, experiential course lies your own project; it can range from making a piece of art, to writing an academic essay, to drafting a work-place, problem-solving report. You will take your project through these stages—wishing, choosing, starting, working, completing, and showing.You will learn strategies from psychotherapist Eric Maisel for overcoming such blocks as hungry mind, confused mind, chaotic mind, or shy mind anxiety. By semester’s end, you will do an oral presentation and a written report on your “work-in-progress,” describing what you have learned about sustaining your own creative practice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literary Nonfiction and Social Critique</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francis Lardy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students read various literary nonfiction essays by contemporary writers who use their individual experiences to address broader social concerns. Using these essays as examples, along with instructional readings on the craft of personal essay writing, students then draw from their own experiences to engage in social critique by exploring forms of institutionalized violence—linguistic, economic, and gendered, for example. Students write essays intended for a non-specialized audience with the intent to enter real-world discourse. Final essays weave together personal experience and research to address a present-day problem related to students’ particular disciplines.  Ultimately, the course encourages students to recognize that their decisions can foster social justice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00036</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Seyed-Gholamreza Shafieesabet</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students to develop further their skills in reading, writing, speaking, and researching. Students will study and produce various forms of communication while strengthening their skills in argumentation. They will learn to recognize and use various rhetorical strategies in order to produce a program-specific major assignment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Stranger Than Fiction? Memoir and Autobiography</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00037</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leanne D'Antoni</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will read the memoirs of David Sedaris, Haven Kimmel, Amber Ruffin, and Catherine Gildiner, to name a few. The class will consist of lectures, class discussions, oral presentations, and the revision and editing of students’ work. Students will analyze and respond to recurring themes found within memoir and autobiography. They will investigate what these authors’ lives reveal about love, loss, relationships, childhood, identity, and why their stories need to be told. Students will engage in close readings and will respond in class discussions and in their written work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00038</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Trevor Rouse</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students to develop further their skills in reading, writing, speaking, and researching. Students will study and produce various forms of communication while strengthening their skills in argumentation. They will learn to recognize and use various rhetorical strategies in order to produce a program-specific major assignment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Storytelling Animal</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00039</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrea Strudensky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">We use stories to make sense of our world and share that understanding with others. We use stories to entertain and educate, to argue and debate, to confess and understand. We will study some of the major genres of storytelling: epic, myth, tragedy, allegory, and romance in the realms of fiction, and non fiction and consider questions like: What are the formal elements that make for a great story? How do character, theme, plot, perspective, and style contribute to our understanding of a story? How does a story’s medium, as an oral, visual, virtual, or print-based text, change or alter our sense of its place and importance in our society? What hopes and desires, needs and anxieties, does it answer to? How do the representations of gender, sexuality, race, and class inform the art and practice of story-telling? As well, we will practice our own creative storytelling skills in order to gain a deeper understanding of how writers tell stories, and to help us define our own narrative voice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Reading of Popular Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00040</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Bassel Atallah</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students improve their academic reading and writing skills in English. Students will read both academic and general-audience articles and texts that critically examine the relation between society and popular culture, with particular attention given to advertising, music, television, technology, and film. Students will learn how to perform a close reading and analysis of the rhetoric strategies used in those texts, and will form their own opinions and interpretations of the topics and issues discussed in class. By the completion of the course, students will research, write, document, edit, and present a research paper that links their program of study to the course material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00041</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Seyed-Gholamreza Shafieesabet</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students to develop further their skills in reading, writing, speaking, and researching. Students will study and produce various forms of communication while strengthening their skills in argumentation. They will learn to recognize and use various rhetorical strategies in order to produce a program-specific major assignment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Reading the Classic Horror Film</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00042</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jay Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will pursue the idea of “classic” horror as a way to designate films that articulate an important set of historical, psychological, philosophical, and political concerns. Divided up into a range of subgenres and special issues, this course will introduce students to the special versatility of horror as we explore the genre’s ongoing relevance and adaptability.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">World War II's Long Shadow</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00043</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chad Lowe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">World War II changed not just the arts, but the very ways in which people think about the world. The focus of this course is charting out how this alteration in individual human perspectives and broad historical perspectives ran in tandem after the enormity of the war’s trauma. We will read a sampling of short first-hand accounts from the war along with short historical accounts of key events. Elie Wiesel's Holocaust memoir Night (1960) and Robert Harris’s alternate-history detective novel, Fatherland (1992), will serve as the basis of the course’s major work, including an individual discipline-specific project using various episodes and events from the war as a backdrop.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literary Nonfiction and Social Critique</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00044</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francis Lardy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students read various literary nonfiction essays by contemporary writers who use their individual experiences to address broader social concerns. Using these essays as examples, along with instructional readings on the craft of personal essay writing, students then draw from their own experiences to engage in social critique by exploring forms of institutionalized violence—linguistic, economic, and gendered, for example. Students write essays intended for a non-specialized audience with the intent to enter real-world discourse. Final essays weave together personal experience and research to address a present-day problem related to students’ particular disciplines.  Ultimately, the course encourages students to recognize that their decisions can foster social justice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00045</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-603-B</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students to develop further their skills in reading, writing, speaking, and researching. Students will study and produce various forms of communication while strengthening their skills in argumentation. They will learn to recognize and use various rhetorical strategies in order to produce a program-specific major assignment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Investigating Story Value(s)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>12001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Katz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Individuals and groups across cultures and throughout history have long recognized that storytelling is a form of power. But what gives stories their power? Who gets to tell them? Who is impacted by them? And how are new technologies, such as social media and Artificial Intelligence, affecting the flow of stories of all kinds in our society? This paired course will explore the territories of both personal and public discourse across the disciplines and will consider the moral implications of the stories we tell. Students will discover how these territories are marked by good-faith discussion, argument and research as well as by censorship, propaganda and “fake news”, and how so much of our discourse is organized by a common device as old as the human species itself: story. Completion of the Investigating Story Value(s) paired course fulfills the foundational knowledge component of the SPACE: Arts and Sciences Certificate.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section. Students registering for this course MUST ALSO TAKE 345-BXH-DW 12001.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 8:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Welcome to the Machine: An Introduction to Ethics and Sci-Fi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Gregory Polakoff, Jay Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Are humans just wind-up toys? Do we control machines or live in the belly of one? Is so-called “reality” merely a simulation? Are our fates determined by our programming? If so, do choices matter? Welcome to the machine! Strap in as we travel through space and time and ponder questions foundational to Sci-Fi and Ethics. Our journey begins with myth and metaphysics in Ancient Greece. From there we’ll jump to the ethical implications of early mechanistic philosophers and of modern thinkers including Bentham, Nietzsche, and Freud. We’ll then turn to recent scholarship on the uncanny valley; cosmic dread; robot rights; alternate techno-histories; and black, queer, and Indigenous futures. Authors include: Philip K. Dick, H.P. Lovecraft, Octavia Butler, Sherman Alexie, and Seo-Young J. Chu. Directors include: Stanley Kubrick (2001), Alex Garland (Ex Machina) and the genre-bending David Lynch…We’ll also discuss the Pink Floyd song after which this course was named!</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>French</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Please refer to the Dawson College website for details on <a href="http://www.dawsoncollege.qc.ca/registrar/english-french-placement-tests" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">French placement testing requirements</a>.</p>
<p>Pratique du français oral et écrit pour les étudiants non francophones (602-03B-DW or 602-04B-DW): These courses are designed for students from OUTSIDE Quebec only and they are not available during the day (except for students registered in Journeys). If this is your placement, and you need more information or to register, please call the Registration Help Line (514-931-5701).</p>
<p><strong>French block B </strong>courses have been designed to meet students' needs in relation to their field of study. These courses will help develop vocabulary and communication skills related to their programs.  Programs have been divided into three "families".</p>
<p>You must take the block B course designed for your program and at your French level.  If you take a block B course this term, find which "family" you belong to, then look at the chart below to find the course number which corresponds to your level and to your "family".</p>
<p><strong><u>Arts et lettres</u></strong>: Arts, Literature and Communication (Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, Studio Arts), Graphic Design, Illustration, Industrial Design, Interior Design, Photography, Professional Theatre, Visual Arts, 3D Animation and Computer Generated Imagery.</p>
<p><strong><u>Sciences humaines</u></strong>: Accounting and Management Technology, Business Management (Marketing), Commerce, Community Recreation Leadership Training, Computer Science, Liberal Arts, Social Science, Social Science Profiles, Social Service.</p>
<p><strong><u>Sciences et techniques</u></strong>:  Biomedical Laboratory Technology, Civil Engineering Technology, Diagnostic Imaging, Electronics Technology, Laboratory Technology/Analytical Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering Technology, Nursing, Physiotherapy Technology, Radiation Oncology, Science.</p>

À ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thèmes culturels variés ainsi que sur les différents genres littéraires. Ceux-ci, en plus de développer l'aptitude de la rédaction, permettront aux étudiants d'améliorer leur sens critique. Par ailleurs, les étudiants seront initiés, lors de ces cours, à l'analyse littéraire.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Littérature contemporaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-Josée Roy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cadre de ce cours de littérature contemporaine, vous ferez la rencontre de Marie-Maude Pranesh-Lopez et constaterez son refus des compromis de médiocrité, pas banal du tout! Une ode à la liberté d'être ce qu'on est, ce qu'on «nait». Nous y aborderons les thèmes de la fatalité, de la marginalité, de la conscience mais aussi du mal être qui happe parfois nos vies avec ou sans résilience. Une aventure littéraire mais profondément ancrée dans une réalité trop souvent inexplorée. Nous suivrons les traces de l'auteur David Goudreaut et tenterons de comprendre son message.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature contemporaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leila Ephrem El Boustani-Safi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cadre de ce cours, nous étudierons différentes productions littéraires françaises et québécoises du XXe et du XXIe siècle qui mettent l'accent sur des thèmes aussi bien universels qu'actuels. Notre parcours se fera essentiellement par la lecture de romans, mais nous nous servirons également de films, de courts métrages, d’œuvres d’art, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature contemporaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leila Ephrem El Boustani-Safi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cadre de ce cours, nous étudierons différentes productions littéraires françaises et québécoises du XXe et du XXIe siècle qui mettent l'accent sur des thèmes aussi bien universels qu'actuels. Notre parcours se fera essentiellement par la lecture de romans, mais nous nous servirons également de films, de courts métrages, d’œuvres d’art, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Littérature contemporaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-Josée Roy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cadre de ce cours de littérature contemporaine, vous ferez la rencontre de Marie-Maude Pranesh-Lopez et constaterez son refus des compromis de médiocrité, pas banal du tout! Une ode à la liberté d'être ce qu'on est, ce qu'on «nait». Nous y aborderons les thèmes de la fatalité, de la marginalité, de la conscience mais aussi du mal être qui happe parfois nos vies avec ou sans résilience. Une aventure littéraire mais profondément ancrée dans une réalité trop souvent inexplorée. Nous suivrons les traces de l'auteur David Goudreaut et tenterons de comprendre son message.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laurent Duval</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce niveau de cours s'adresse aux étudiants qui maitrisent suffisamment le français écrit pour traiter de sujets d'ordre culturel et littéraire. À ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thèmes culturels variés ainsi que sur les différents genres littéraires. Ceux-ci, en plus de développer l'aptitude de la rédaction, permettront aux étudiants d'améliorer leur sens critique. Par ailleurs, les étudiants seront initiés, lors de ces cours, à l'analyse littéraire.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. À ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thèmes culturels variés ainsi que sur les différents genres littéraires. Ceux-ci, en plus de développer l'aptitude de la rédaction, permettront aux étudiants d'améliorer leur sens critique. Par ailleurs, les étudiants seront initiés, lors de ces cours, à l'analyse littéraire.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Esthétiques du scandale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lyane Henrichon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cours Esthétiques du scandale, nous étudierons différentes productions littéraires françaises et québécoises (depuis 1850 jusqu’à nos jours) en mettant l’accent sur leur caractère transgressif. Notre parcours se fera essentiellement par la lecture de textes littéraires, mais nous nous servirons également de chansons, de films, d’œuvres d’art, etc. En somme, notre réflexion portera sur des œuvres littéraires et artistiques qui auront bousculé les normes et scandalisé les différentes sociétés dans lesquelles elles ont été créées.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nadia Rezzag Lebza</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce cours vous mènera à découvrir, comprendre et critiquer l’Orientalisme, un courant artistique et littéraire qui a profondément marqué la peinture et la littérature du 19e siècle en Europe. L’Orientalisme témoigne d’une fascination de l’Occident pour l’Orient (Empire ottoman, Maghreb, Moyen-Orient et Al-Andalus). Dès lors, une question se pose : l’Orientalisme propose-t-il une représentation fidèle de l’Orient? Ou n’en trahit-il pas plutôt une vision occidentale purement fantasmée? Afin de répondre à cette « énigme » et d’alimenter notre réflexion, nous analyserons des tableaux orientalistes (Delacroix, Benjamin-Constant, etc.), nous étudierons des extraits de récits de voyage à Constantinople (Gautier, de Nerval), des poèmes choisis des Orientales de V. Hugo et Les Aventures du dernier Abencérage de F. – R de Chateaubriand. Ce cours se conclura par une création littéraire élaborée en équipe: vous rédigerez vous-même, de manière collaborative, une nouvelle orientaliste illustrée.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Séraphine Askari Chirazi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce niveau de cours s'adresse aux étudiants qui maitrisent suffisamment le français écrit pour traiter de sujets d'ordre culturel et littéraire. À ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thèmes culturels variés ainsi que sur les différents genres littéraires. Ceux-ci, en plus de développer l'aptitude de la rédaction, permettront aux étudiants d'améliorer leur sens critique. Par ailleurs, les étudiants seront initiés, lors de ces cours, à l'analyse littéraire.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laetitia Desanti</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce niveau de cours s'adresse aux étudiants qui maitrisent suffisamment le français écrit pour traiter de sujets d'ordre culturel et littéraire. À ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thèmes culturels variés ainsi que sur les différents genres littéraires. Ceux-ci, en plus de développer l'aptitude de la rédaction, permettront aux étudiants d'améliorer leur sens critique. Par ailleurs, les étudiants seront initiés, lors de ces cours, à l'analyse littéraire.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carmen-Silvia Cristea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce cours se propose d’engager une réflexion sur la manière dont la littérature raconte le monde et l’histoire, et sur sa légitimité et sa pertinence. Nous étudierons dans ce but trois œuvres littéraires qui puisent leur inspiration dans l’histoire contemporaine. Après avoir analysé, dans un premier temps, le contexte socio-historique qui représente la toile de fond de chaque œuvre, les thèmes abordés, ainsi que les stratégies narratives, nous pencherons plus particulièrement sur le mode d’énonciation de chaque texte (la scène énonciative) en nous posant les questions suivantes: Qui est le narrateur? Quel éthos, adopte-il pour raconter des événements qui dépassent la sphère de l’intime pour se greffer dans l’histoire contemporaine? Comment la forme d’énonciation du roman façonne le récit ainsi que le mode de réception de l’œuvre?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Adeline Caute</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce niveau de cours s'adresse aux étudiants qui maitrisent suffisamment le français écrit pour traiter de sujets d'ordre culturel et littéraire. À ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thèmes culturels variés ainsi que sur les différents genres littéraires. Ceux-ci, en plus de développer l'aptitude de la rédaction, permettront aux étudiants d'améliorer leur sens critique. Par ailleurs, les étudiants seront initiés, lors de ces cours, à l'analyse littéraire.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction à la littérature contemporaine (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00050</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christine Murdock</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cadre de ce cours, nous étudierons différentes productions littéraires françaises et québécoises du XXe et du XXIe siècle qui mettent l'accent sur des thèmes aussi bien universels qu'actuels. 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00060</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-602-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce niveau de cours s'adresse aux étudiants qui maitrisent suffisamment le français écrit pour traiter de sujets d'ordre culturel et littéraire. À ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thèmes culturels variés ainsi que sur les différents genres littéraires. Ceux-ci, en plus de développer l'aptitude de la rédaction, permettront aux étudiants d'améliorer leur sens critique. Par ailleurs, les étudiants seront initiés, lors de ces cours, à l'analyse littéraire.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">602-413-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Questions d'identite</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christian Paré</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans ce cours, la présence de la langue française et d’une culture francophone mondiale seront étudiées grâce à la présentation de ses cinq pôles géographiques principaux. Au moins deux de ces pôles seront comparés, soit : l’Europe (la France, la Suisse et la Belgique), L’Amérique du Nord (le Québec, le Canada et les États-Unis), les Antilles (Haïti et Martinique), Le Maghreb (le Maroc, l’Algérie et la Tunisie), l’Afrique Sub-saharienne (Sénégal, Mali, Cameroun, etc.). L’objectif étant d’observer des différences et des ressemblances entre ces cultures et la norme française, on présentera : une histoire de la présence francophone et de la langue, les normes et principales institutions francophones et les représentations culturelles dans les domaines suivants : littérature (roman, théâtre, poésie, chanson, bande dessinée, etc.), arts vivants et visuels (peinture, sculpture, performance, etc.), productions audiovisuelles (cinéma de fiction, documentaire, production télévisuelle, etc.).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christian Paré</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans ce cours, la présence de la langue française et d’une culture francophone mondiale seront étudiées grâce à la présentation de ses cinq pôles géographiques principaux. L’objectif étant d’observer des différences et des ressemblances entre ces cultures et la norme française, on présentera : une histoire de la présence francophone et de la langue, les normes et principales institutions francophones et les représentations culturelles dans les domaines suivants : littérature (roman, théâtre, poésie, chanson, bande dessinée, etc.), arts vivants et visuels class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Production théâtre francophone: Domaine médical (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00050</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jacques Mélançon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce cours permettra à l’étudiant de réaliser une courte production théâtrale en lien Ce cours jumelé de français et d’éducation physique s’adresse aux étudiants qui ont réussi le cours de français 602-101-MQ en plus d’avoir réussi les cours d’éducation physique 109-101-MQ et 109-102-MQ. Le thème unissant les deux cours est Living on the land : Regards sur la vie autochtone. La portion intensive inclut un séjour de trois (3) jours, du 30 mai au 1er juin, dans la communauté autochtone de Manawan, au Québec. Les élèves auront l’occasion d’explorer les techniques et les savoir-faire traditionnels avec les guides autochtones de la communauté. Les élèves apprendront comment la nature énergise et permet une gestion efficace du stress, tout en pratiquant le français de manière intensive au sein d’un territoire traditionnel atikamekw.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section. 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Regards sur la vie traditionnelle autochtone (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>12001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lysanne Audy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">THIS COURSE DESCRIPTION IS AVAILABE IN ENGLISH BY REQUEST.  Ce cours jumelé de français et d’éducation physique s’adresse aux étudiants qui ont réussi le cours de français 602-101-MQ en plus d’avoir réussi les cours d’éducation physique 109-101-MQ et 109-102-MQ. Le thème unissant les deux cours est Living on the land : Regards sur la vie autochtone. La portion intensive inclut un séjour de trois (3) jours, du 30 mai au 1er juin, dans la communauté autochtone de Manawan, au Québec. Les élèves auront l’occasion d’explorer les techniques et les savoir-faire traditionnels avec les guides autochtones de la communauté. Les élèves apprendront comment la nature énergise et permet une gestion efficace du stress, tout en pratiquant le français de manière intensive au sein d’un territoire traditionnel atikamekw.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section. L’élève améliore et parfait ses habiletés linguistiques et approfondit sa maîtrise de la grammaire et de l’écriture. L’élève se sensibilise à l’apprentissage du français comme langue seconde pour être en mesure de réussir une relation d’aide tout en intégrant des notions de pédagogie, de didactique et de psychologie. Le rapport d'une recherche reliée au programme spécifique de l'étudiant forme la composante de français de l'épreuve synthèse (Comprehensive Assessment).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Ce cours s'adresse aux étudiants et étudiantes qui ont réussi le cours 602-103 avec une note d’au moins 75 % ou qui ont une très bonne maîtrise du français oral et écrit, et qui désirent aider des élèves en difficulté à se perfectionner en français oral et écrit. Pour pouvoir s’inscrire à ce cours, les étudiants doivent communiquer avec V. Millet par MIO [Message in Omnivox, My Dawson Portal].</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Relation d'aide à l'apprentissage</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00041</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Véronique Millet</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce cours s'adresse aux étudiants et étudiantes ayant réussi un cours 602-103 ou son équivalent ou qui ont une très bonne maîtrise du français oral et écrit et qui désirent aider des élèves en difficulté à se perfectionner en français oral et écrit. 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-320-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment encompasses the natural world, of which we are a part, and the built world, which we have created. Geography studies both the changes taking place within the natural world and the changes in the way people organize their activities spatially in the social world. This course introduces students to the dynamic character of society and its interaction with the natural environment. The course will introduce basic geography skills such as map reading, mapmaking and the usefulness of geographic information systems (GIS). It will then explore key concepts relating to the geographic study of climate, environment, and of society, culture, demography and development.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-320-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment encompasses the natural world, of which we are a part, and the built world, which we have created.
