10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Koopman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Cultural Identity and Cultural Rights</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anjali Choksi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine how and why societies accommodate, protect and penalize cultural difference. Students will identify and analyse the historical development of world views on the rights and status of different minority groups in Canada. They will learn to identify and to understand distinctions between race, ethnicity and nationality, with a focus on world views in Canada. The relationships between Canada and Indigenous nations, and the concepts and world views arising from those relationships, are a key area of study during the first half of the course. The second half of the course will focus more on cultural identity and how it shapes and is shaped by world views. Racism in the American and Canadian justice systems will be an important focus of readings and films as well as issues of identity, justice and influence and appropriation of African-American culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews of Indigenous Peoples</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Aditya Kumar Dewan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course describes how indigenous peoples perceive and interpret reality and events, their images of themselves and how they relate to the world around them. The first half of the course will focus on religious beliefs, health and illnesses, the position of men and women in society, sexual attitudes, rites and rituals, forms of arts, etc. The second half of the course will examine their notion of ownership of land, environment, development, aboriginal rights, self-determination, and the notion of cultural survival. At the conclusion of the course, students will acquire the following learning skills: reading and writing with clarity, listening, speaking, note-taking, and building vocabulary relevant to materials on world views in general and world views of indigenous peoples in particular.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Classic Ideas Revisited through the Contemporary Lens</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eric Van Der Wee</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">There have been many great thinkers and philosophers who have contributed great insights to how we see the world and our place in it: Nietzche, Descartes, Mach, Kant and others have put forward notions of the nature of humanity and the planet we live on.  Science, however, continues to provide us with new discoveries and emerging disciplines provide a new lens from which we can examine some of these classical world views. Students will learn to appreciate the world views and ideas put forward by some of the great western thinkers in history and then examine them from the modern outlook of the 21st century with the all the advances made in various fields of learning.  Students will understand the historical context from which these ideas came and how they remain useful in constructing a modern world view.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Public Stories: Journalism, Democracy, and the Media</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joseph Rosen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course looks at journalism as a form of public storytelling that shapes our world views. Worldviews structure our reality: they are stories that we live by. We begin by looking at how non-fiction stories determine our sense of the shared world and orient individual ways of acting and being. Then we investigate concepts of democracy, media, and the public sphere to investigate the power of ‘public’ stories. Next students analyze examples of literary journalism and personal non-fiction to understand how new stories can shift readers’ world views. Finally we shift from reading to writing. Writing exercises help students develop their individual voices and engage current topics that they feel are important. These exercises lead to the final project: students research and write a feature article, non-fiction story or personal essay with the goal of contributing their individual voice to a relevant contemporary public conversation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Nietzsche and Dostoevsky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maia Johnson-Stepenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the interplay of two immensely influential world views as developed by two literary giants: Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) and Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821-1881). Although they never met, Nietzsche and Dostoevsky wrestled with the same issues surrounding God and morality. However, while Nietzsche announced the "death of God" as something positive enabling the liberation of man, Dostoevsky pointed to the same decline as something that must be surmounted and replaced with a still stronger faith in God. Students will thus learn to compare and contrast the world views of both Nietzsche and Dostoevsky (that is, life against God versus life with God), as both literature and philosophy.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Money</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Brender</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Money makes the world go round. Every time you take cash out at an ATM, use a credit card, or buy something at the cafeteria, you are taking part in a global web of economic relations. When things go wrong in this global system, as they did in the 2008 financial crisis, all our lives are affected. And yet, few of us understand how the economy works. In this course, we will learn about the economic world we live in by studying the origins of the capitalist world view. Our textbook will be Adam Smith’s landmark 1776 work, The Wealth of Nations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Enlightenment and Romanticism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Coléno</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">All of us have been profoundly shaped by two conflicting world views: the Enlightenment world view, which emphasizes objectivity, science, and reason, and the Romantic world view, which challenges Enlightenment assumptions by emphasizing subjectivity and strong feelings. This course explores key figures of the Enlightenment such as Locke, along with key figures of Romanticism such as Rousseau, Blake, Coleridge, and Kleist. It also examines famous works of visual art that are linked with these two intellectual movements, and one ancient play (Euripides’s The Bacchae) that anticipates many of the themes emphasized by the Romantics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Weird, Wonderful, and Persuasive: The World Views of Western Philosophers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Derrick Farnham</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This second Humanities course will teach students to think critically about world views. Having come to an understanding of what a world view is, students will examine the world views of great philosophers. The course will trace the development of philosophy since the Renaissance. Philosophers have produced intricate and complex theories explaining the world and proving what is. In a broad sense, this course explores the human condition, and the ways we humans have tried to understand and define ourselves, our world and our possibilities.   This course will examine some of the philosophical theories of Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, Kant and some recent philosophers. The course will focus on their arguments. In doing so, we will discuss some of the world views of philosophy: Dualism, Pantheism, Logical Atomism, Idealism, Skepticism and Existentialism. We will also question whether another’s world view can even be understood.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Nietzsche and Dostoevsky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maia Johnson-Stepenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the interplay of two immensely influential world views as developed by two literary giants: Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) and Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821-1881). Although they never met, Nietzsche and Dostoevsky wrestled with the same issues surrounding God and morality. However, while Nietzsche announced the "death of God" as something positive enabling the liberation of man, Dostoevsky pointed to the same decline as something that must be surmounted and replaced with a still stronger faith in God. Students will thus learn to compare and contrast the world views of both Nietzsche and Dostoevsky (that is, life against God versus life with God), as both literature and philosophy.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews in 1968</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eliza Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In 1968 nations across the world erupted in fits of youthful rage and democratic populism on a scale that has not been seen before or since. On the streets of Paris, Chicago, Prague, New York, Beijing, Berlin, Warsaw, Mexico City, Rio de Janeiro, and London, the youth commanded attention. They rebelled for several reasons — some protested American racism, some the division of their nation, and most rejected the American War in Vietnam, the established authority, and the conservative status quo. These movements were captured by television crews who were newly able to simultaneously broadcast the unrest into living rooms. Disruption, upheaval, and violence were widespread as protesters and revolutionaries clashed with the police, the army, or invading foreign powers. In this course we will be examining, comparing, and contrasting the worldviews of those who protested and those who held power; and we will consider the degree to which our own worldviews have changed since 1968.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Public Stories: Journalism, Democracy, and the Media</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joseph Rosen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course looks at journalism as a form of public storytelling that shapes our world views. Worldviews structure our reality: they are stories that we live by. We begin by looking at how non-fiction stories determine our sense of the shared world and orient individual ways of acting and being. Then we investigate concepts of democracy, media, and the public sphere to investigate the power of ‘public’ stories. Next students analyze examples of literary journalism and personal non-fiction to understand how new stories can shift readers’ world views. Finally we shift from reading to writing. Writing exercises help students develop their individual voices and engage current topics that they feel are important. These exercises lead to the final project: students research and write a feature article, non-fiction story or personal essay with the goal of contributing their individual voice to a relevant contemporary public conversation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Classic Ideas Revisited through the Contemporary Lens</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00029</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eric Van Der Wee</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">There have been many great thinkers and philosophers who have contributed great insights to how we see the world and our place in it: Nietzche, Descartes, Mach, Kant and others have put forward notions of the nature of humanity and the planet we live on.  Science, however, continues to provide us with new discoveries and emerging disciplines provide a new lens from which we can examine some of these classical world views. Students will learn to appreciate the world views and ideas put forward by some of the great western thinkers in history and then examine them from the modern outlook of the 21st century with the all the advances made in various fields of learning.  Students will understand the historical context from which these ideas came and how they remain useful in constructing a modern world view.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Diversity in Women’s Movements</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00030</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gloria Lalonde</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Death of Homo Economicus</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">“What are you going to do when you graduate?” “Get a job.” "What is your single most important goal for living your best life?” “To do well for myself financially!” A stereotype of college and university students has taken shape in which young people are assumed to be mostly materialistic in their world views. But is this stereotype true? In cognitive psychology and some areas of philosophy, the focus has shifted to the ways in which humans are driven by deep emotional forces. In behavioral economics, scholars have started to unearth the irrationality underlying much of economic decision-making. Some of these perspectives point to a dark future of irrational fears and inflamed passions. Others are more optimistic and illuminate how human social and emotional interconnection has always been the key to human flourishing. This course will track the evolution of this world view through a diverse set of readings.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews in 1968</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eliza Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In 1968 nations across the world erupted in fits of youthful rage and democratic populism on a scale that has not been seen before or since. On the streets of Paris, Chicago, Prague, New York, Beijing, Berlin, Warsaw, Mexico City, Rio de Janeiro, and London, the youth commanded attention. They rebelled for several reasons — some protested American racism, some the division of their nation, and most rejected the American War in Vietnam, the established authority, and the conservative status quo. These movements were captured by television crews who were newly able to simultaneously broadcast the unrest into living rooms. Disruption, upheaval, and violence were widespread as protesters and revolutionaries clashed with the police, the army, or invading foreign powers. In this course we will be examining, comparing, and contrasting the worldviews of those who protested and those who held power; and we will consider the degree to which our own worldviews have changed since 1968.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Political Worldviews</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shi Chen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to political world views through a study of key central problems:  What is the state of nature?  Could the state be justified? Who should rule?  What should be the place of liberty in society?  What is the just way of distributing property?  Also, we will analyze and assess the most interesting arguments made by political thinkers to solve these problems as well as investigate how these arguments are influenced by their world views.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Public Stories: Journalism, Democracy, and the Media</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00034</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joseph Rosen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course looks at journalism as a form of public storytelling that shapes our world views. Worldviews structure our reality: they are stories that we live by. We begin by looking at how non-fiction stories determine our sense of the shared world and orient individual ways of acting and being. Then we investigate concepts of democracy, media, and the public sphere to investigate the power of ‘public’ stories. Next students analyze examples of literary journalism and personal non-fiction to understand how new stories can shift readers’ world views. Finally we shift from reading to writing. Writing exercises help students develop their individual voices and engage current topics that they feel are important. These exercises lead to the final project: students research and write a feature article, non-fiction story or personal essay with the goal of contributing their individual voice to a relevant contemporary public conversation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Weird, Wonderful, and Persuasive: The World Views of Western Philosophers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Derrick Farnham</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This second Humanities course will teach students to think critically about world views. Having come to an understanding of what a world view is, students will examine the world views of great philosophers. The course will trace the development of philosophy since the Renaissance. Philosophers have produced intricate and complex theories explaining the world and proving what is. In a broad sense, this course explores the human condition, and the ways we humans have tried to understand and define ourselves, our world and our possibilities.   This course will examine some of the philosophical theories of Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, Kant and some recent philosophers. The course will focus on their arguments. In doing so, we will discuss some of the world views of philosophy: Dualism, Pantheism, Logical Atomism, Idealism, Skepticism and Existentialism. We will also question whether another’s world view can even be understood.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews of the Ancients</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00036</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rui De Sousa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will look at the world views of the ancient Maya, Greeks and Egyptians and study in detail their respective beliefs about the cosmos and man's place in it.  Students will first be introduced to the history of our knowledge of these past civilizations and how over time our vision of them has changed in fundamental ways.  We will then discuss some of the modern methodology for the study of ancient societies and the challenges that we face in trying to understand cultures different from our own. We will also study what we know today about the history, culture and intellectual achievements of the Maya, Greeks and Egyptians.  Finally, we will examine in detail the key themes and ideas that characterize the myths, religion and literature that make up the world views of each civilization.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Political Worldviews</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00037</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shi Chen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to political world views through a study of key central problems:  What is the state of nature?  Could the state be justified? Who should rule?  What should be the place of liberty in society?  What is the just way of distributing property?  Also, we will analyze and assess the most interesting arguments made by political thinkers to solve these problems as well as investigate how these arguments are influenced by their world views.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews of the Ancients</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00038</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rui De Sousa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will look at the world views of the ancient Maya, Greeks and Egyptians and study in detail their respective beliefs about the cosmos and man's place in it.  Students will first be introduced to the history of our knowledge of these past civilizations and how over time our vision of them has changed in fundamental ways.  We will then discuss some of the modern methodology for the study of ancient societies and the challenges that we face in trying to understand cultures different from our own. We will also study what we know today about the history, culture and intellectual achievements of the Maya, Greeks and Egyptians.  Finally, we will examine in detail the key themes and ideas that characterize the myths, religion and literature that make up the world views of each civilization.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews of Indigenous Peoples</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00039</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Aditya Kumar Dewan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course describes how indigenous peoples perceive and interpret reality and events, their images of themselves and how they relate to the world around them. The first half of the course will focus on religious beliefs, health and illnesses, the position of men and women in society, sexual attitudes, rites and rituals, forms of arts, etc. The second half of the course will examine their notion of ownership of land, environment, development, aboriginal rights, self-determination, and the notion of cultural survival. At the conclusion of the course, students will acquire the following learning skills: reading and writing with clarity, listening, speaking, note-taking, and building vocabulary relevant to materials on world views in general and world views of indigenous peoples in particular.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Political Worldviews</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00040</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shi Chen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to political world views through a study of key central problems:  What is the state of nature?  Could the state be justified? Who should rule?  What should be the place of liberty in society?  What is the just way of distributing property?  Also, we will analyze and assess the most interesting arguments made by political thinkers to solve these problems as well as investigate how these arguments are influenced by their world views.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Early Childhood Education</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00041</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Abid Bahar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is for students to develop an understanding of different views about child rearing and child education. Major theories of child development and education will be explored. Students will examine various  worldviews about child rearing practices and educational methods and how these worldviews shape the education of young children in different societies. Students will develop skills in the analysis and comparison of diverse world views.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Understanding Culture Through Artworks and Artifacts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00042</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Beverly Sing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This multidisciplinary course focuses on the examination of artworks and artifacts from different historical periods and places. Defining and examining components of a “world view” will be the common threads that run through the exploration of social perspectives from the Middle Ages through the present. Selected works will be discussed in the context of the cultural systems from which they came. Diverse examples chosen from the visual arts, literature, and music, as well as everyday objects will be used to determine how people defined themselves as individuals, groups or whole societies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Justice, Development, and Change</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00043</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mari Heywood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we study opposing world views in an increasingly globalized world.  These world views are made up of different ideas of justice, varied interpretations of what can be called development, and conflicting versions of how change takes place. Specifically, we consider meanings and ideas about feminism and equality, capitalism and fairness, environmentalism/consumerism and excess. These ideas are linked to how people understand gender, race, class, and how they understand those with whom they are not familiar or who are living far away, the outsiders. Such ideas lead to differing views about conditions in ‘first’ and ‘third’ worlds, what qualifies as discrimination, and whether change is possible. According to these conflicting world views, what can or does encourage or prevent justice?  What are appropriate action, legitimacy, reliability, and responsibility?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Justice, Development, and Change</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00044</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mari Heywood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we study opposing world views in an increasingly globalized world.  These world views are made up of different ideas of justice, varied interpretations of what can be called development, and conflicting versions of how change takes place. Specifically, we consider meanings and ideas about feminism and equality, capitalism and fairness, environmentalism/consumerism and excess. These ideas are linked to how people understand gender, race, class, and how they understand those with whom they are not familiar or who are living far away, the outsiders. Such ideas lead to differing views about conditions in ‘first’ and ‘third’ worlds, what qualifies as discrimination, and whether change is possible. According to these conflicting world views, what can or does encourage or prevent justice?  What are appropriate action, legitimacy, reliability, and responsibility?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM -
