11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00046</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-345-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The World Views course introduces students to the idea of using conceptual frameworks for understanding, from culturally and historically diverse standpoints, how the world is structured, functions and develops. Students are encouraged to increase their awareness and understanding of different views of humanity and its place in the world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Violence and Nonviolence</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>12001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Romano</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Beliefs about violence are important components of our world views, but, both as individuals and societies, we examine them far too rarely. In this course, we will question some of the common assumptions and justifications that support violence and war, while examining the ways in which these ideas are reinforced by powerful societal institutions. Then we will examine the perspective of an alternative world view that rejects violence on both ethical and practical grounds.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section. Students registering for this course MUST ALSO TAKE 365-BXP-DW 12001.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Signifying Nothing: Pessimism and the Tragic World View</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Jay Shea, Mikaela Bobiy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The unseen world: Magic in Ritual, Fairy Tale and Fantasy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles, Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">345-BXH-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Ethics in Humanities</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">46 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues in Medicine and Health</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mendel Kramer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to enable students to think, speak and write intelligently about ethical questions that arise in connection with health care. The course examines a number of ethical systems and considers how they might be applied to medicine and health. Among the issues considered are the autonomy of patients, the relationship between doctor and patient, informed consent, euthanasia, abortion and the distribution of health care.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues in Medicine and Health</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mendel Kramer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to enable students to think, speak and write intelligently about ethical questions that arise in connection with health care. The course examines a number of ethical systems and considers how they might be applied to medicine and health. Among the issues considered are the autonomy of patients, the relationship between doctor and patient, informed consent, euthanasia, abortion and the distribution of health care.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Universe on Your Plate</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Goldsmith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Many of us do not consider that we are making an ethical choice at every meal. We do not often realize that our food decisions have enormous consequences for the environment, the people who grow and process our food, and our health. All of these factors are important to consider if we want to determine the most ethical way to eat.    This course is designed to give you a basis for making ethical choices at your dinner (and lunch, and breakfast) table. During the first part of the course, we will examine several ethical theories, including utilitarianism, deontology, and Buddhist ethics. We will also consider whether our understanding of the universe, specifically that the atoms in our food and our bodies were forged in the bellies of exploding stars, could inform our ethical choices.    In the second part of the course, we will go over many of the facts about the industrial food system, and apply the ethical theories we’ve learned.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Science Fiction and Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gregory Polakoff</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Through the study of science fiction and related genres such as the Weird, magical realism, and manga, this course examines important modern ethical dilemmas. Technology, the media, artificial intelligence, sexuality, race, politics, war, and bioethics are some of the issues that we will explore. The course materials include examples of global science fiction and short readings in ethics, philosophy, and the social sciences. Students will be given the option to submit creative writing as part of their final project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Science Fiction and Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gregory Polakoff</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Through the study of science fiction and related genres such as the Weird, magical realism, and manga, this course examines important modern ethical dilemmas. Technology, the media, artificial intelligence, sexuality, race, politics, war, and bioethics are some of the issues that we will explore. The course materials include examples of global science fiction and short readings in ethics, philosophy, and the social sciences. Students will be given the option to submit creative writing as part of their final project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethics: Between the Self and Other</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joseph Rosen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Who are we talking about when we say ‘we’? What is the difference between ‘us’ and ‘them’? Am I responsible to others, and if so, who? This course introduces students to an understanding of ethics that is defined by the relationship between self and other. We will investigate the concept of the ‘Other,’ explore the egotistical and ethical dimensions of the self, and define the concept of responsibility as a relation between self and other that encourages diversity, curiosity and self-growth. Students will learn how to think critically about ethical issues using the concepts of self and other. We will learn how to identify, analyze, and critique the ways that certain groups are stereotyped and defined as ‘other’. EG: the demonization of death row prisoners, the vilification of Arabs & Muslims in Hollywood, stereotypes about ‘tough’ masculinity & the ‘othercide’ of indigenous culture in the Americas. Students are encouraged to bring their own examples and interests into class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Butorac</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Applied Ethics course is designed to provide students with the basic ideas and skills of moral reasoning so that they can identify and analyze various issues, including program related ones, from an ethical perspective. Students become acquainted with a number of ethical theories and learn how to analyze and evaluate ethical arguments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Society and the Other</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">John Hunting</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines how we relate to others and how we ought to relate to others. The distinction between ethos (world views) and ta ethika (fields and problems of knowledge) proves central to the inquiry into what it means to not only feel the weight of socially determined notions of what is good but to also feel the weight of universal obligations. Thus the course begins with sociological descriptions of self and other and it turns to traditional ethical theories about justice and the good, theories such as utilitarianism, Kant’s categorical imperative and the ethics of care. These ethical theories in mind students present and debate various ethical issues, including euthanasia, capital punishment, abortion, pornography, poverty, animal rights, global warming and others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics: Contemporary Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Braiden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Applied ethics is a branch of moral philosophy that uses ethical theory to resolve moral conflict at the level of the individual (should I use plastic straws?) and at the level of society as a whole (should we institute a ban on plastic straws?). By the end of this course, students will be able to define and apply the theories of ethical egoism, utilitarianism, virtue ethics, and deontology (rights discourse) in relation to contemporary environmental problems. Students will also consider concepts such as fairness, justice, respect for rights, human flourishing and the flourishing of nonhuman entities. Students will also learn to conduct ethical analysis and will be able to distinguish between anthropocentric, zoo centric, biocentric and ecocentric systems of ethical thought.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Universe on Your Plate</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Goldsmith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Many of us do not consider that we are making an ethical choice at every meal. We do not often realize that our food decisions have enormous consequences for the environment, the people who grow and process our food, and our health. All of these factors are important to consider if we want to determine the most ethical way to eat.    This course is designed to give you a basis for making ethical choices at your dinner (and lunch, and breakfast) table. During the first part of the course, we will examine several ethical theories, including utilitarianism, deontology, and Buddhist ethics. We will also consider whether our understanding of the universe, specifically that the atoms in our food and our bodies were forged in the bellies of exploding stars, could inform our ethical choices.    In the second part of the course, we will go over many of the facts about the industrial food system, and apply the ethical theories we’ve learned.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Buddhist Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julian Nemeth</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Approximately 2500 years ago, Siddhartha Gautama Shakyamuni developed teaching centered on understanding and ending suffering. This teaching served as the foundation of Buddhism, one of the most influential religious and philosophical traditions in world history. In this class, we will examine the foundations of Buddhist ethics; explore multiple lines of Buddhist thought; and compare Buddhist moral philosophy with "Western" approaches such as Kantianism and Utilitarianism. The course also surveys recent movements in "engaged Buddhism," examining how the tradition has been applied to issues such as environmental justice, anti-racism, and conflict resolution. We will also study instances where Buddhists have not always lived up to their teachings' lofty goals, considering how ideals and actualities sometimes clash. Finally, we will engage in meditation inspired by Buddhist practice--but open to those of all world views—to help understand how ethics may be supported by mindfulness.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Individual and State</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Slonosky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will examine both the ethics of how individual human beings should act towards one another, and what sort of rules and behaviour citizens of a state (in this case, Canada) should agree to follow and impose on each other. We will begin by examining different ethical theories, including but not limited to the Divine Command Theory, the Social Contract Theory, the Categorical Imperative, Utilitarianism and Relativism. After studying, understanding and critiquing these different approaches to ethics, we will apply our knowledge to an issue of perpetual importance: the balance between individual liberties and group security. This part of the course will include readings and discussions of issues such as online surveillance and data collection, torture and the imposition of the War Measures Act during the October Crisis of 1970.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics: Contemporary Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Braiden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Applied ethics is a branch of moral philosophy that uses ethical theory to resolve moral conflict at the level of the individual (should I use plastic straws?) and at the level of society as a whole (should we institute a ban on plastic straws?). By the end of this course, students will be able to define and apply the theories of ethical egoism, utilitarianism, virtue ethics, and deontology (rights discourse) in relation to contemporary environmental problems. Students will also consider concepts such as fairness, justice, respect for rights, human flourishing and the flourishing of nonhuman entities. Students will also learn to conduct ethical analysis and will be able to distinguish between anthropocentric, zoo centric, biocentric and ecocentric systems of ethical thought.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martine Gosselin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to explore three interrelated questions: (i) What is ethics? (ii) What ethical theories are available to us for distinguishing good from bad, and right from wrong? (iii) How can ethical theories help us to examine and resolve debated ethical issues in our society and everyday moral dilemmas in our own lives? We consider the nature of ethics itself, explore several major ethical theories in the history of ethics, and apply these ethical theories to reflections on current ethical issues such as: euthanasia, animal rights, and environmental issues. The specific topics covered in the last part of the class depend on the interests of the students taking the class in relation to their programs of study and future career choices.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Individual and State</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Slonosky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will examine both the ethics of how individual human beings should act towards one another, and what sort of rules and behaviour citizens of a state (in this case, Canada) should agree to follow and impose on each other. We will begin by examining different ethical theories, including but not limited to the Divine Command Theory, the Social Contract Theory, the Categorical Imperative, Utilitarianism and Relativism. After studying, understanding and critiquing these different approaches to ethics, we will apply our knowledge to an issue of perpetual importance: the balance between individual liberties and group security. This part of the course will include readings and discussions of issues such as online surveillance and data collection, torture and the imposition of the War Measures Act during the October Crisis of 1970.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics: Contemporary Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Braiden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Applied ethics is a branch of moral philosophy that uses ethical theory to resolve moral conflict at the level of the individual (should I use plastic straws?) and at the level of society as a whole (should we institute a ban on plastic straws?). By the end of this course, students will be able to define and apply the theories of ethical egoism, utilitarianism, virtue ethics, and deontology (rights discourse) in relation to contemporary environmental problems. Students will also consider concepts such as fairness, justice, respect for rights, human flourishing and the flourishing of nonhuman entities. Students will also learn to conduct ethical analysis and will be able to distinguish between anthropocentric, zoo centric, biocentric and ecocentric systems of ethical thought.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Butorac</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Applied Ethics course is designed to provide students with the basic ideas and skills of moral reasoning so that they can identify and analyze various issues, including program related ones, from an ethical perspective. Students become acquainted with a number of ethical theories and learn how to analyze and evaluate ethical arguments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Butorac</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Applied Ethics course is designed to provide students with the basic ideas and skills of moral reasoning so that they can identify and analyze various issues, including program related ones, from an ethical perspective. Students become acquainted with a number of ethical theories and learn how to analyze and evaluate ethical arguments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Koopman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Society and the Other</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">John Hunting</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines how we relate to others and how we ought to relate to others. The distinction between ethos (world views) and ta ethika (fields and problems of knowledge) proves central to the inquiry into what it means to not only feel the weight of socially determined notions of what is good but to also feel the weight of universal obligations. Thus the course begins with sociological descriptions of self and other and it turns to traditional ethical theories about justice and the good, theories such as utilitarianism, Kant’s categorical imperative and the ethics of care. These ethical theories in mind students present and debate various ethical issues, including euthanasia, capital punishment, abortion, pornography, poverty, animal rights, global warming and others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Happily Ever After</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Derrick Farnham</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will critically evaluate ethical theories and theories of happiness. Students will combine their abilities from their knowledge and world views courses and gain the ability to reason well and get themselves through ethical problems they might encounter. The course will investigate happiness. It will follow two parallel tracks through ethical theories and theories of happiness. The ethical theories dealt with will be Consequentialism, Deontology and the Categorical Imperative. Happiness will be viewed as pleasure, reward and finally, the contemplative life. Students will read classics in philosophy and literature in order to gain an understanding of these theories. Students will end the course by applying what they have learned to their area of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Buddhist Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julian Nemeth</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Approximately 2500 years ago, Siddhartha Gautama Shakyamuni developed teaching centered on understanding and ending suffering. This teaching served as the foundation of Buddhism, one of the most influential religious and philosophical traditions in world history. In this class, we will examine the foundations of Buddhist ethics; explore multiple lines of Buddhist thought; and compare Buddhist moral philosophy with "Western" approaches such as Kantianism and Utilitarianism. The course also surveys recent movements in "engaged Buddhism," examining how the tradition has been applied to issues such as environmental justice, anti-racism, and conflict resolution. We will also study instances where Buddhists have not always lived up to their teachings' lofty goals, considering how ideals and actualities sometimes clash. Finally, we will engage in meditation inspired by Buddhist practice--but open to those of all world views—to help understand how ethics may be supported by mindfulness.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Ethics of the Past: Archaeology, Ownership, and the Antiquities Trade</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Archaeology has over the last two centuries developed as a discipline that discovers and interprets the material remains of the past. This discipline emerged as a specific method of studying the past in a largely “imperialist landscape,” where scholars from wealthy and powerful Western countries examined the cultures of other often colonized peoples, in the Mediterranean, the Middle East, Asia, and the Americas. This course will focus on the contemporary ethical implications of the study of the past. Issues covered will include the ethics of how archaeology is carried out in the field, the physical ownership and cultural expropriation of the past and the distortion of historical narratives to serve present day political and economic interests. Attention will also be given to the illegal antiquities trade, a lucrative industry fueled by the looting of archaeological sites, often with the connivance of legitimate museums and auction houses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martine Gosselin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to explore three interrelated questions: (i) What is ethics? (ii) What ethical theories are available to us for distinguishing good from bad, and right from wrong? (iii) How can ethical theories help us to examine and resolve debated ethical issues in our society and everyday moral dilemmas in our own lives? We consider the nature of ethics itself, explore several major ethical theories in the history of ethics, and apply these ethical theories to reflections on current ethical issues such as: euthanasia, animal rights, and environmental issues. The specific topics covered in the last part of the class depend on the interests of the students taking the class in relation to their programs of study and future career choices.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Ethics of the Past: Archaeology, Ownership, and the Antiquities Trade</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Archaeology has over the last two centuries developed as a discipline that discovers and interprets the material remains of the past. This discipline emerged as a specific method of studying the past in a largely “imperialist landscape,” where scholars from wealthy and powerful Western countries examined the cultures of other often colonized peoples, in the Mediterranean, the Middle East, Asia, and the Americas. This course will focus on the contemporary ethical implications of the study of the past. Issues covered will include the ethics of how archaeology is carried out in the field, the physical ownership and cultural expropriation of the past and the distortion of historical narratives to serve present day political and economic interests. Attention will also be given to the illegal antiquities trade, a lucrative industry fueled by the looting of archaeological sites, often with the connivance of legitimate museums and auction houses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">From Cruelty to Forgiveness</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Romano</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses two extremes of human behavior by examining our responses, both individual and collective, to human brutality – our desire for vengeance and punishment, our search for acknowledgment and justice, and the possibility for remorse, forgiveness and reconciliation.  Students will be asked to consider their ethical responsibilities towards both victims and perpetrators, to righting old wrongs, and to reflect on how a concern with human suffering is relevant to their own field of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Individual and State</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Slonosky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will examine both the ethics of how individual human beings should act towards one another, and what sort of rules and behaviour citizens of a state (in this case, Canada) should agree to follow and impose on each other. We will begin by examining different ethical theories, including but not limited to the Divine Command Theory, the Social Contract Theory, the Categorical Imperative, Utilitarianism and Relativism. After studying, understanding and critiquing these different approaches to ethics, we will apply our knowledge to an issue of perpetual importance: the balance between individual liberties and group security. This part of the course will include readings and discussions of issues such as online surveillance and data collection, torture and the imposition of the War Measures Act during the October Crisis of 1970.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Buddhist Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julian Nemeth</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Approximately 2500 years ago, Siddhartha Gautama Shakyamuni developed teaching centered on understanding and ending suffering. This teaching served as the foundation of Buddhism, one of the most influential religious and philosophical traditions in world history. In this class, we will examine the foundations of Buddhist ethics; explore multiple lines of Buddhist thought; and compare Buddhist moral philosophy with "Western" approaches such as Kantianism and Utilitarianism. The course also surveys recent movements in "engaged Buddhism," examining how the tradition has been applied to issues such as environmental justice, anti-racism, and conflict resolution. We will also study instances where Buddhists have not always lived up to their teachings' lofty goals, considering how ideals and actualities sometimes clash. Finally, we will engage in meditation inspired by Buddhist practice--but open to those of all world views—to help understand how ethics may be supported by mindfulness.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Universe on Your Plate</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00029</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Goldsmith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Many of us do not consider that we are making an ethical choice at every meal. We do not often realize that our food decisions have enormous consequences for the environment, the people who grow and process our food, and our health. All of these factors are important to consider if we want to determine the most ethical way to eat.    This course is designed to give you a basis for making ethical choices at your dinner (and lunch, and breakfast) table. During the first part of the course, we will examine several ethical theories, including utilitarianism, deontology, and Buddhist ethics. We will also consider whether our understanding of the universe, specifically that the atoms in our food and our bodies were forged in the bellies of exploding stars, could inform our ethical choices.    In the second part of the course, we will go over many of the facts about the industrial food system, and apply the ethical theories we’ve learned.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00030</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martine Gosselin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Who Does the Law Serve?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mari Heywood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Moral Issues in Law (Liberal Arts)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert Stephens</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course encourages students to explore the connection between law and ethics as expressed in legal theories. We will relate these theories to elements of the world views which gave rise to them. Students will study legal reasoning as a way to analyze ethical issues from within a field of professional knowledge. The goal is to understand legal reasoning as one among many possible ways to ask questions and argue about moral issues. In this course, we will: 1. Critically examine the relationship between law and morality. 2. Identify ethical issues in the making and application of law. 3. Defend an opinion on an ethical issue using legal reasoning – and explain the limits of that reasoning. 4. Situate legal concepts such as individual rights and the rule of law in world views and fields of knowledge.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Ethics of the Past: Archaeology, Ownership, and the Antiquities Trade</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Archaeology has over the last two centuries developed as a discipline that discovers and interprets the material remains of the past. This discipline emerged as a specific method of studying the past in a largely “imperialist landscape,” where scholars from wealthy and powerful Western countries examined the cultures of other often colonized peoples, in the Mediterranean, the Middle East, Asia, and the Americas. This course will focus on the contemporary ethical implications of the study of the past. Issues covered will include the ethics of how archaeology is carried out in the field, the physical ownership and cultural expropriation of the past and the distortion of historical narratives to serve present day political and economic interests. Attention will also be given to the illegal antiquities trade, a lucrative industry fueled by the looting of archaeological sites, often with the connivance of legitimate museums and auction houses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Modern Mythology: Human Values through a Comic Book Panel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00034</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eric Van Der Wee</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Societies throughout history have established, questioned and expressed their values and identities through various disciplines, especially mythology. Much as the epic tales of mythical champions served to examine what a virtuous life should look like, so do the superhuman stories of modern heroes. This course will examine different models of the virtuous life and ethics through the contemporary mythology of the superhero genre. Students will learn to appreciate classical moral ethics theories through a popular and contemporary vehicle: learning about the philosophy of Aristotle, Plato, Kant, and Bentham through the actions of familiar heroes such as Batman, Wonder Woman, and the Watchmen. The students will adopt a critical approach to studying ethical theories. Using comparison, students will witness ethics in action through the narratives of the superhero characters.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Coléno</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to some of the most influential ethical theories and concepts. It relates these general theories and concepts to specific ethical issues and debates, and it familiarizes students with key controversies in the history of ethics. By the end of the term, students will be able to identify and compare some of the central beliefs and concepts in the history of ethics. They will be able to relate these beliefs and concepts to many current debates surrounding moral issues. They will also be able to analyze various influential arguments and texts in the history of ethics. Students who complete this course successfully will also improve their reading, writing, speaking, and critical thinking skills.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00036</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Koopman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00037</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Allen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to explore three interrelated questions: (i) What is ethics? (ii) What ethical theories are available to us for distinguishing good from bad, and right from wrong? (iii) How can ethical theories help us to examine and resolve debated ethical issues in our society and everyday moral dilemmas in our own lives? We will begin by considering the nature of ethics itself, defining the language and basic concepts of ethics as they apply to our everyday lives and the society we live in. We will then explore four major ethical theories in the history of ethics: (i) divine command ethics; (ii) virtue ethics; (iii) deontological ethics; and (iv) utilitarianism. In the final part of the course, we will apply these ethical theories to reflections on current ethical issues such as: abortion, euthanasia, the acceptable limits of scientific research, animal rights, feminism, moral relativism, and environmental issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00038</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Coléno</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to some of the most influential ethical theories and concepts. It relates these general theories and concepts to specific ethical issues and debates, and it familiarizes students with key controversies in the history of ethics. By the end of the term, students will be able to identify and compare some of the central beliefs and concepts in the history of ethics. They will be able to relate these beliefs and concepts to many current debates surrounding moral issues. They will also be able to analyze various influential arguments and texts in the history of ethics. Students who complete this course successfully will also improve their reading, writing, speaking, and critical thinking skills.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00039</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Allen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to explore three interrelated questions: (i) What is ethics?
