Students will combine their abilities from their knowledge and world views courses and gain the ability to reason well and get themselves through ethical problems they might encounter. The course will investigate happiness. It will follow two parallel tracks through ethical theories and theories of happiness. The ethical theories dealt with will be Consequentialism, Deontology and the Categorical Imperative. Happiness will be viewed as pleasure, reward and finally, the contemplative life. Students will read classics in philosophy and literature in order to gain an understanding of these theories. Students will end the course by applying what they have learned to their area of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Issues in Bioethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00043</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gabriel Tordjman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the social and ethical dimension of medical and biological research, practice and technology. This includes controversial issues such as health care, abortion, euthanasia, reproductive technology, surrogacy, “test tube babies”, genetic testing and genetic manipulation of plants and animals, including human beings. Through the examination of a number of bioethical issues, this course helps students acquire the knowledge and sensitivity necessary for ethical deliberation and action in the public sphere and in personal life. This course introduces students to the basic vocabulary used in bioethical discourse, and situates various bioethical issues in their historical and philosophical contexts, underlining both their local and global importance while helping students articulate their own personal ethical outlook.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00044</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-345-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Investigating Story Value(s)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>12001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Individuals and groups across cultures and throughout history have long recognized that storytelling is a form of power. But what gives stories their power? Who gets to tell them? Who is impacted by them? And how are new technologies, such as social media and Artificial Intelligence, affecting the flow of stories of all kinds in our society? This paired course will explore the territories of both personal and public discourse across the disciplines and will consider the moral implications of the stories we tell. Students will discover how these territories are marked by good-faith discussion, argument and research as well as by censorship, propaganda and “fake news”, and how so much of our discourse is organized by a common device as old as the human species itself: story. Completion of the Investigating Story Value(s) paired course fulfills the foundational knowledge component of the SPACE: Arts and Sciences Certificate.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section. Students registering for this course MUST ALSO TAKE 603-BXE-DW 12001.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Welcome to the Machine: An Introduction to Ethics and Sci-Fi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Gregory Polakoff, Jay Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Illustration</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-499-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">New Directions in Illustration: Alternative Techniques</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Chronopoulos, Stéphanie Aubin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is mixed media studio course that embraces the cross-pollination between contemporary illustration and fine art. Printmaking and assemblage will be used as the vehicles for the dissemination of contemporary imagery and practices in illustration such as the production of posters, t- shirt designs, zines and graphic novels. Students will engage in printmaking and assemblage processes within the context of print as a means to generate multiples and sustain the production of a small edition. Printmaking techniques will be explored for their graphic and reproducible qualities. Students will be asked to consider their relationship to society and culture through a set of projects that require experimentation and the questioning of conventions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Chronopoulos, Stéphanie Aubin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is mixed media studio course that embraces the cross-pollination between contemporary illustration and fine art. Printmaking and assemblage will be used as the vehicles for the dissemination of contemporary imagery and practices in illustration such as the production of posters, t- shirt designs, zines and graphic novels. Students will engage in printmaking and assemblage processes within the context of print as a means to generate multiples and sustain the production of a small edition. Printmaking techniques will be explored for their graphic and reproducible qualities. Students will be asked to consider their relationship to society and culture through a set of projects that require experimentation and the questioning of conventions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-202-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Drawing Principles and Practices</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neal Armstrong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation of Drawing Fundamentals, with enhanced treatment of the human figure and experience with sketching and drawing inanimate objects and environments, including landscape and architecture. Human figures will be engaged in a range of actions, seen from different points of view and placed in various contexts. There will be some sketching on location. Students will develop freehand drawing skills with an understanding of linear perspective. A range of traditional media will be used. Students will demonstrate intermediate level skills in these areas in order to progress successfully to the next term.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neal Armstrong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation of Drawing Fundamentals, with enhanced treatment of the human figure and experience with sketching and drawing inanimate objects and environments, including landscape and architecture. Students will sketch, draw and render subjects in organic or architectural environments observed and composed at different angles and viewpoints.  Emphasis will be placed on drawing sequential kinetic actions in context, as used in game design, graphic novels and storyboards. By using both traditional and digital tools, students will understand the practice of illustration for concept art applications and demonstrate an intermediate level skill in order to progress successfully to the next term.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Xin Ran Liu</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation of Illustrative Drawing I, anatomical drawing for both human and animal subjects, with enhanced anatomy components, proportions, balance, and movement. Perspective terminology is explained and exercised through object and environmental drawing. Students practice traditional colour rendering with markers and watercolour.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Sy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation of Technical Illustration 1. Students will learn essential basics of wet media - watercolour and acrylics - as well as Photoshop painting techniques. The course will start with drawing and painting from assigned photo references and will prepare for developing conceptual illustrations. Emphasis will be placed on a realist approach to picture making, respecting light, volume, colour and values, which will then lead to to a final project; the creation of imaginative illustrations with a thematic subject. Various surfaces and brushes will be demonstrated and exercised to give students a sense of how working illustrators practice their craft. Digital tools will be introduced to help ease the students into using Photoshop as a fundamental painting medium. These techniques will prepare the student for Illustration Techniques 3.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Paul Turgeon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation of Illustration Techniques 1, with an exploration of light and colour, traditionally and digitally. Students will apply acquired skills of organization, drawing, rendering, layout, type and design, to plan, develop and produce complete projects. Students will work collaboratively in teams, participate in the design and production of the Graduation Exhibition, curate their own artwork for display, and develop a brand to promote themselves in print, social media and on the web. All work completed will be according to professional standards and an emphasis is placed upon the student’s ability to solve problems in a professional manner.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stéphanie Aubin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to allow for synthesis of content learned in terms one through five and to complete the components of the Comprehensive Examination. All work completed will be according to professional standards and an emphasis is placed upon the student’s ability to solve problems in a professional manner.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-764-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Professional Practice</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marc-Andre Cright</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses topics which are critical to launching a career in illustration. Students will learn the fundamentals of starting a business, including self-promotion, business development, branding, market analysis, interviews, presentations, client research, legal and ethical practices. They prepare their resumes and cover letters and package their work for self promotion. Students become well versed in legal and accounting issues relevant to the field of illustration and examine industry standards in pricing and contract negotiation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marc-Andre Cright</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses topics which are critical to launching a career in illustration. 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-27B-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Material and Manufacturing II</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pascal Boissé</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will continue to learn about materials’ properties and manufacturing processes as they relate to product design through the analysis of a variety of existing consumer products. After dismantling and studying them students will document their findings by producing detailed reports consisting of 9 sketches and written descriptions of the products’ characteristics as they relate to forces, structure, materials, and manufacturing processes, among others. As a result of these observation and analysis activities, students will increase their understanding of the requirements necessary for creating appropriate product design solutions. Using a project-based approach, they will then demonstrate the level of their comprehension through the application of their knowledge toward the creation of improved design solutions for the same sets of parameters, while also taking other product design considerations into account.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2C</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; Students will be developing product concepts that will improve a product’s usage and the intrinsic organization or mapping of its functions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; They will learn to safely and accurately operate workshop machinery and power tools and to understand the importance of project planning and accurate technical documentation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Weeks</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will undertake the prototyping of their design studio projects.  They will learn to safely and accurately operate workshop machinery and power tools and to understand the importance of project planning and accurate technical documentation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-47B-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Presentation Layout IV</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlos Carpintero</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will learn to produce 3D computer renderings with realistic lighting, shadows, and material appearances, and to generate visual presentation material for their design studio projects.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-47D-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">3D Computer Modeling IV</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Weeks</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In order to keep a product design project on schedule, students will learn how to effectively manage their time while working on the same project in a team. New software tools will be introduced while they develop a teamwork system using the 3D software application. Students will also be introduced to file management (PDM), the production of technical documentation such as the tech pack, E-drawings, and specific technical drawings. Another interesting and relevant application of the software will be the exploration of the simulation module which will allow for virtual product design concept analysis in conjunction with the corresponding physical model to be built with the program’s rapid prototyping equipment. Students will be able to ‘reverse analyze’ their built concepts using the laser scanner and thereby subsequently adjust their design concepts. The course will support one project’s development from Design Studio IV and Technical Design Studio IV.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-47E-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Product Ergonomics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kim Anita Webb</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Products need to be designed so that they are comfortable for people to use them. During this course, students will learn how to analyze the ergonomic and anthropometric needs of product usage within a specific environment. This will be accomplished with the application of research, creative design problem solving and also with an emphasis on anthropometrical data research and testing as applied to the development process of their simultaneous design studio projects (PBL). Students will gain knowledge in the application of both qualitative and quantitative data during the product design process.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-670-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Design Studio VI</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlos Carpintero, Michael Santella, Véronique Bibeau-Poissant</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will develop the technical aspects of their chosen thesis concepts that were created in Design Studio 5.  They will build a virtual 3D computer model of their concept assembly as well as an actual hand-made scale model.  In order to communicate their proposal’s manufacturing materials and requirements, they will produce a tech pack and all required technical drawings.  All these elements together form the requirements to be assessed for the Comprehensive Examination, which is displayed in the Graduating Students Exhibition.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; The students will learn to research products and materials, compare products from various manufacturers, specify and calculate quantities for materials in residential and commercial spaces, and study materials (wood, plastic, metal, textiles, glass, composites) that were not covered in Materials and Furnishings I.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jill Hogan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course elaborates and builds upon the Materials and Furnishings I course with specifications of materials, furnishings, and finishes commonly, historically and sustainably used in the residential and commercial interior environments. Building upon knowledge and skills developed in the Visual Language of Design course, graphic standards specific to the design disciplines will be applied to 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional drawings. Digital modelling will be introduced as a conceptualization and visualization tool. Both traditional and digital media will be applied to communicate and generate design ideas. Students will learn how to assemble more complex sets of visual information to communicate in the language of design (in alignment with Interior Design II residential).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Philip Fontaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course continues to explore drawing as a tool for documenting observed environments, ideation, and communication. Building upon knowledge and skills developed in the Visual Language of Design course, graphic standards specific to the design disciplines will be applied to 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional drawings. Digital modelling will be introduced as a conceptualization and visualization tool. Both traditional and digital media will be applied to communicate and generate design ideas. Students will learn how to assemble more complex sets of visual information to communicate in the language of design (in alignment with Interior Design II residential).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-245-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">CAD I</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Lance Lipson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is a foundational course to CAD (Computer Assisted Drawing) software and introduces students to its application and integration into design and construction documentation. Students will learn methodologies to efficiently draft designs to communicate them effectively. The students will learn to use notes and dimensions to fully explain their work and ideas. Students will learn to output their work at proper scale through digital and print media.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Lance Lipson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is a foundational course to CAD (Computer Assisted Drawing) software and introduces students to its application and integration into design and construction documentation. Students will learn methodologies to efficiently draft designs to communicate them effectively. The students will learn to use notes and dimensions to fully explain their work and ideas. Students will learn to output their work at proper scale through digital and print media.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-246-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Colour & Lighting I</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Adolphe Tinling, James McCallan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to provide students with an introductory understanding of both colour and lighting as important design elements of the built environment. Students will learn how to use and apply colour theories, colour harmonies, create moods and spatial emphasis. Students will learn the importance of lighting (both natural and artificial) and how it plays a key role in interior spaces. The course will demonstrate how colour and lighting are explicitly interrelated and can be combined to psychologically impact users. Students will be introduced to basic lighting systems, daylighting components and equipment, relevant terminology and conventions, drawings, and documentation. The colour and lighting knowledge acquired from this course will guide students to develop viable residential concepts aligning with Interior Design II.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Adolphe Tinling, Philip Fontaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to provide students with an introductory understanding of both colour and lighting as important design elements of the built environment. Students will learn how to use and apply colour theories, colour harmonies, create moods and spatial emphasis. Students will learn the importance of lighting (both natural and artificial) and how it plays a key role in interior spaces. The course will demonstrate how colour and lighting are explicitly interrelated and can be combined to psychologically impact users. Students will be introduced to basic lighting systems, daylighting components and equipment, relevant terminology and conventions, drawings, and documentation. The colour and lighting knowledge acquired from this course will guide students to develop viable residential concepts aligning with Interior Design II.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-441-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Interior Design IV</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne-Marie Legault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This studio course introduces students to the process of designing workspaces for commercial use, addressing organizational and end-user needs, and representing the clients’ corporate mission. FF&E (furniture, fixtures, and equipment) and materials are selected to meet end-user needs, in collaboration with interdisciplinary professionals. In alignment with the Building Systems Environmental Design course, students explore parameters for workplace design by developing spaces that apply and integrate building code, HSW (Health Safety & Welfare) and sustainability standards. Students apply skills from earlier studio classes in the process of conceptualizing, developing, and validating ideas into viable design solutions. Effectively conveying the design intent through researched documentation, sketch and digital presentation materials.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jill Hogan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This studio course introduces students to the process of designing workspaces for commercial use, addressing organizational and end-user needs, and representing the clients’ corporate mission. This course correlates with the term 4 course, Building Systems Environmental Design. Construction drawing conventions will include both standard construction techniques, detail elements and millwork with clear organization of information and specifications.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Philip Fontaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course develops design projects into construction methodologies outlined in Construction Documents I with a focus on commercial construction, which is further applied in subsequent Construction Documents courses. Digital modelling skills will be further developed while integrating industry-sourced components. Lighting will be selected, specified, and integrated into digital models to address user needs, design concepts, and creative expression. Rendered outputs will simulate the effects of lighting on materials and finishes to evaluate and refine the design proposal for an interior space. Students will continue to advance their visual and written communication skills to address different audiences and project needs; including clients, stakeholders, consultants, and promotional material for the public. Course content is aligned with the Interior Design IV studio.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">James McCallan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">As the culminating Visual Communication course, a variety of rendering and visualization platforms will be explored to express design intent in relation to complex presentation documents. The role of the interior designer will be defined in relation to the responsibilities, skills, tasks, and interactions with other interdisciplinary professionals (architects, engineers, and consultant specialists). Throughout the course, students will be introduced to sustainability concepts, industry standards and ecological strategies which will be integrated with various building systems, that make up a healthy, safe, comfortable, and sustainable human interior environment. This course will introduce students to professional building systems documentation and terminology. From residential examples to large commercial or public projects, students will learn about the environmental impact of buildings. This course relates to course content in Construction Documents II, Interior Design IV and other course material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne-Marie Legault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the structural, electrical, and mechanical systems required for various interior environments. The role of the interior designer will be defined in relation to the responsibilities, skills, tasks, and interactions with other interdisciplinary professionals (architects, engineers, and consultant specialists). Throughout the course, students will be introduced to sustainability concepts, industry standards and ecological strategies which will be integrated with various building systems, that make up a healthy, safe, comfortable, and sustainable human interior environment. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-639-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Professional Practice: Experience</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">James McCallan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course gives students a specific introduction to professional practice within the office environment. Students will participate in a practicum by observing a design office.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: Weeks 1 to 7.5</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Thursday, February 2, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 18, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">May 11, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 18, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">May 11, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Italian</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Please note the prerequisites for each course.  Students in doubt of their level must contact the department chairperson at local 4244 or e-mail nlachance@dawsoncollege.qc.ca before registration.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">608-111-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Italian 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nicola Martino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Italian, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nicola Martino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Italian, formal or informal. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Laboratory Technology/Analytical Chemistry</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">210-211-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Analysis Techniques</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Yoon-Seo Uh</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course gives the first glimpse at physicochemical and instrumental analysis techniques, while continued emphasis is placed on traditional analysis techniques, such as titrimetry and gravimetry. The students are also exposed to the basic knowledge, use and maintenance of some chromatographic and spectroscopic instruments, all of which will be applied in all laboratory courses throughout the program. Quality assurance activities will be applied throughout this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.20</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Yoon-Seo Uh</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course gives the first glimpse at physicochemical and instrumental analysis techniques, while continued emphasis is placed on traditional analysis techniques, such as titrimetry and gravimetry. The students are also exposed to the basic knowledge, use and maintenance of some chromatographic and spectroscopic instruments, all of which will be applied in all laboratory courses throughout the program. Quality assurance activities will be applied throughout this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.20</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">210-441-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Instrumental Separations</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luc Lapierre</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the students will learn the basics of instrumental separations using liquid and gas chromatography and capillary electrophoresis. The basics of chromatographic separations, as well as the theory of different separation techniques are discussed. The students will learn to independently operate chromatography instruments, with consideration of the nature of the sample and the goal of the separation. Basic instrument maintenance is performed. Aspects of method development are introduced. The students will also perform quantitative analyses using calibrations common in chromatographic methods.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: January 18 to April 19, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, February 6, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luc Lapierre</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the students will learn the basics of instrumental separations using liquid and gas chromatography and capillary electrophoresis. They will apply some of the knowledge and skills acquired in the academic milieu, gain knowledge of the industry and lab hosting the stage, observe the functioning of industrial laboratories, their organization, and the diverse tasks of the technologist, demonstrate ability to integrate into a working team, gain knowledge and understanding of laboratory safety, acquire skills on writing a resume and develop presentation skills.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">INTENSIVE</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, May 3, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Apr 27, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Apr 27, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Stage</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">210-611-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Analytical Techniques 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Silja Makinen, Steven Gary Holden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the students will perform laboratory experiments in qualitative and quantitative chemical analysis using manual and instrumental techniques that have been learned earlier in the Program. For some of the experiments, the students will develop the procedure using given goals and guidelines. Emphasis is put on the overall process of analysis, from sample collection and preparation to the final result, with methods to estimate accuracy and precision. The students are expected to conduct themselves in the laboratory with a high degree of autonomy and professionalism.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">210-631-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Biomolecules</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elisabeth Cadieux</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course builds on the skills and competencies acquired in previous organic chemistry courses - Organic Chemistry I and both intro and advanced Organic Chemistry Techniques. The objective of the course is to familiarize the students with the properties, reactions, and characterization of different biological molecules. This is achieved through laboratory work, lectures, and homework assignments. In the laboratory component, the students will characterize different types of biomolecules using manual and instrumental methods.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">210-651-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Chemical Processes</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luc Lapierre</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will prepare the student to formulate and solve material and energy balances on chemical process systems. More fundamentally, it introduces the engineering approach to solving process-related problems: breaking a process down into its components, establishing the relations between known and unknown process variables, assembling the information needed to solve for the unknowns using a combination of experimentation, empiricism, and the application of natural laws, and, finally, putting the pieces together to obtain the desired problem solution. This course will begin with a qualitative discussion on problems chemical engineers must face in connection with several dissimilar processes, and the introduction to fundamental techniques of engineering calculations. The systematic development of elementary process analysis is also discussed: what process variables are and how they are expressed, measured and calculated.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">210-693-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Laboratory Technology Project</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Omar Behar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will provide experience in working independently in a laboratory utilizing the techniques and methods learned in the Program. The students will also learn how to design lab experiments specifying the equipment and supplies needed to execute a project. The course will also teach the students to take notes and keep a proper lab notebook according to GLP. Finally the students learn to interpret experimental results, write a technical report, work in a safe environment, give a final oral presentation and a critical assessment of the project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM -
