Major topics such as the nature of reality, truth, knowledge, justice, personal identity, freedom, responsibility, and meaning will be covered. In a broad sense, this course explores the human condition, and the ways we humans have tried to understand and define ourselves, our world and our possibilities. As this is an introductory course, students will also learn and practice the philosophical fundamentals of sound argumentation. By the end of the course, students will have an understanding of basic problems of philosophy and their development. They will also have a sense of philosophy’s relevance and importance for the social sciences, the natural sciences, and contemporary issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">340-219-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Topics in Philosophy</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetic Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gerardo Mosquera</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This philosophy course is an introduction to the Theories of Justice. It will analyze the various dimensions of the concept of justice by examining how Plato attempted to provide a unified theory of justice in The Republic and how subsequent philosophers responded to his proposals. Some of the questions that we will be considering are: What are the competing theories of justice and is a unified theory of justice possible? Is justice a virtue of individuals or of society, or of both? Or is justice only a property of laws? And since Plato is famous for stating that poetry, tragedy, and comedy are incompatible with a just society, this course will also analyze Plato’s theory of art and its links to justice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">340-303-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Philosophy: Thinking for Ourselves</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jessica Lim</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In a world which moves so quickly there often isn’t even time to think, it is imperative to develop the skills necessary to engage in critical reflection and interpretation, to reason effectively and creatively, to separate truth from illusion, and to judge, act and communicate in ways that lead to a meaningful and authentic life. In this course, we will pursue those skills by focusing on the art of doing philosophy — studying and practicing the critical and creative reasoning that philosophical thinking demands, and which is increasingly important to a fulfilling engagement with life in a modern, fast-paced technological culture. Through our study of philosophy and the philosophical method, we will be more prepared than ever to think for ourselves, to challenge and defend ideas, to find meaning and to articulate our identities and place in the world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture<br>This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">340-912-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Modern Philosophy</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan-Judith Hoffmann</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the meaning and scope of Western ideas and institutions. In order to grasp the scope of modern thought, this course will explore the differences between the main ideas and views of modern philosophy versus the main ideas and views of modern science. It will become clear that philosophy and science have distinct ways of addressing the essential problems and themes of modern thought. The course will analyze, compare and contrast these differences in order to clearly understand the particular way philosophy treats modern problems. Finally, this course will attempt to integrate philosophical ideas, concepts and analytical methods into the study of other fields.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">340-913-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Philosophy and Culture</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Friedrich Nietzsche: Philosophy, Mythology and Art</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan-Judith Hoffmann</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to philosophy and its cultural role through philosophical reflection on humour and comedy. Questions we’ll consider include: What makes something funny? To what extent is the comical objective, and to what extent is it culturally relative? The ethics of comedy: does the comedian have an ethical role to play in society? What makes a piece of comedy unethical or offensive? Is life itself a sort of joke? What is the difference between the comic and the tragic? Is comedy inherently philosophical? By thinking about such questions in light of what major philosophers have had to say about humour and comedy, students will be introduced to the practice of philosophy, as well as to central philosophical figures, areas and movements. Throughout the course we will see how philosophy and comedy develop and critique the surrounding culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature and Studio Arts<br>This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Friedrich Nietzsche: Philosophy, Mythology and Art</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan-Judith Hoffmann</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to philosophy and its cultural role through philosophical reflection on humour and comedy. Questions we’ll consider include: What makes something funny? To what extent is the comical objective, and to what extent is it culturally relative? The ethics of comedy: does the comedian have an ethical role to play in society? What makes a piece of comedy unethical or offensive? Is life itself a sort of joke? What is the difference between the comic and the tragic? Is comedy inherently philosophical? By thinking about such questions in light of what major philosophers have had to say about humour and comedy, students will be introduced to the practice of philosophy, as well as to central philosophical figures, areas and movements. Throughout the course we will see how philosophy and comedy develop and critique the surrounding culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts<br>This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">340-914-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Why Art Matters</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert Stephens</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Art plays a central role in defining culture – all culture, throughout all of human history.  But what exactly is art?  How do we decide what counts as art and what doesn’t?  Can there be any objective definition of “art”?  What would that definition look like?  This is the sort of question we begin with in a philosophical study of art or aesthetics.  Is art defined by the emotional reaction it inspires?  Does it require an audience?  Do the intentions of the artist matter?  Does art teach us anything?  Does art convey truths?  How do aesthetic values compare to ethical ones – and to what extent is art connected to ethics, or politics, or gender, or culture? Why, and on what basis do we value it?  How do we compare artworks?  And ought we preserve art for future generations?  In short, why does art matter? This is the question we will tackle in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">340-BWA-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Philosophy</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Why Art Matters</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert Stephens</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Art plays a central role in defining culture – all culture, throughout all of human history. But what exactly is art? How do we decide what counts as art and what doesn’t? Can there be any objective definition of “art”? What would that definition look like? This is the sort of question we begin with in a philosophical study of art or aesthetics. Is art defined by the emotional reaction it inspires? Does it require an audience? Do the intentions of the artist matter? Does art teach us anything? Does art convey truths? How do aesthetic values compare to ethical ones – and to what extent is art connected to ethics, or politics, or gender, or culture? Why, and on what basis do we value it? How do we compare artworks? And ought we preserve art for future generations? In short, why does art matter? This is the ultimate question we will tackle in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">340-BWS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Philosophy</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">7 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Philosophy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gerardo Mosquera</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will survey central philosophical questions and how influential philosophers have attempted to answer them. Major topics such as the nature of reality, truth, knowledge, justice, personal identity, freedom, responsibility, and meaning will be covered. In a broad sense, this course explores the human condition, and the ways we humans have tried to understand and define ourselves, our world and our possibilities. As this is an introductory course, students will also learn and practice the philosophical fundamentals of sound argumentation. By the end of the course, students will have an understanding of basic problems of philosophy and their development. They will also have a sense of philosophy’s relevance and importance for the social sciences, the natural sciences, and contemporary issues. </div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Philosophy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brian Redekopp</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will survey central philosophical questions and how influential philosophers have attempted to answer them. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Philosophy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-340-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will survey central philosophical questions and how influential philosophers have attempted to answer them. Major topics such as the nature of reality, truth, knowledge, justice, personal identity, freedom, responsibility, and meaning will be covered. In a broad sense, this course explores the human condition, and the ways we humans have tried to understand and define ourselves, our world and our possibilities. As this is an introductory course, students will also learn and practice the philosophical fundamentals of sound argumentation. By the end of the course, students will have an understanding of basic problems of philosophy and their development. They will also have a sense of philosophy’s relevance and importance for the social sciences, the natural sciences, and contemporary issues. </div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Physical Education</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>The following courses are required Physical Education courses: 109-101-MQ, 109-102-MQ, 109-103-MQ.</p>
<p>**  These courses <u>cannot </u>be used as complementary courses - no exceptions.  **  For complementary Physical Education courses see the complementary section of the timetable.</p>
<p>Students with medical problems who require placement in an appropriate course must contact either Richard Montreuil (local 4753), Layal Nakhle (local 4936), or Christine Bustamante (local 1194), prior to course allocation.</p>
<p>Attendance in Physical Education classes is compulsory.  Students must be dressed to participate for the first class.</p>
<p>Four hours of absence, for any reason, is the maximum allowed for Physical Education courses, except Outdoor Education where 100% attendance is required.</p>
<p>Students must complete both 109-101-MQ and 109-102-MQ before 109-103-MQ.</p>
<p>All 109-101-MQ sections are titled “Physical Activity and Health"; 109-102-MQ sections are titled “Physical Activity and Effectiveness"; and 109-103-MQ sections are titled “Physical Activity and Autonomy”.  Please take note of the subtitle as well as the course number when registering.</p>
<p><strong><u>Intensive Courses</u></strong><strong><br />
</strong>All intensive courses have one class scheduled prior to course change.  Verify lecture time and location.  All classes are compulsory.</p>
<p><strong><u>Showering and Changing Time</u></strong><br />
Students should allow ½ hour after scheduled classes for showering and changing.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">109-101-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Physical Activity and Health</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">54 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Outdoor Fitness (COMPRESSED)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Caroline Haddad</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This compressed course will use outdoor environments to explore and study the relationship between physical activity and the individual's health and wellness. Examples of activities include cycling, day hiking, orienteering, in-line skating, and shelter construction. Theoretical and practical sessions will provide the knowledge and skills necessary to promote health, wellness and positive lifestyle habits. All classes, training sessions, and activity days are mandatory. Students missing these sessions will be considered unprepared and may be denied permission to continue in the course. This course takes place off-campus. Verify facility location, and dates in the “Timetable & Registration Guide” prior to registering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Fee</label><div class="col-md-10"> $0.00</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED COURSE: TRAVEL TIME NOT INCLUDED</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, February 8, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Extra Information:</label><div class="col-md-10">This section requires you to understand the policies and procedures for <a href="/intensive-compressed-and-outdoor-education-courses/">Intensive / Compressed and Outdoor Education Courses</a></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 24, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 24, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Montreal Area</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Fitness Walking (COMPRESSED)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Venere Di Genova</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to cardiovascular and muscular conditioning through fitness walking and is offered in a compressed format. The compressed format includes several three-hour classes during the term and two full day classes, which are located around the Montreal area, and held on separate weekends. The primary focus of the course is to examine the role that physical activity plays in the promotion of health. This course takes place off-campus. Verify facility location and dates in the “Timetable & Registration Guide” prior to registering. All fees are waived until further notice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Fee</label><div class="col-md-10"> $0.00</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED COURSE: TRAVEL TIME NOT INCLUDED</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, January 30, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Extra Information:</label><div class="col-md-10">This section requires you to understand the policies and procedures for <a href="/intensive-compressed-and-outdoor-education-courses/">Intensive / Compressed and Outdoor Education Courses</a></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 20, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 20, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - It explores the benefits of mindfulness-based practices such as breathing, meditation, yoga, functional mobility, and movement in nature. The primary focus of this course is to raise awareness of how physical activity and other health-based practices impact long-term health and wellness. Verify facility location in the “Timetable & Registration Guide” prior to registering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Eco Landscaping (COMPRESSED)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00051</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Paul Wasacz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to eco-landscaping and gardening as a way to participate in physical activity leading to a healthy lifestyle. 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Mont Blanc</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sport Participation Contract (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew Potter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is open to members of a Dawson College intercollegiate team who practice regularly throughout two terms. Students are encouraged to select a 101 Physical Education course in their first fall term so that they may select this course in the winter term. This course is considered a winter term. Before first-year students can register through the Athletics office in October, they must first request permission from both the Phys. ed. department chairperson and the Athletic Director. The supervising teacher, coach and student athlete will work together to coordinate achievement of the competencies. Students will attend lecture sessions and be assigned learning tasks pertaining to the objectives of the course. Practices will be monitored regularly throughout the season (October to March) in order to observe the achievement of the activity-oriented elements of the competency. Verify facility location, dates and time in the “Timetable & Registration Guide” prior to registering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Fee</label><div class="col-md-10"> $0.00</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">ON CAMPUS<br>Plus additional hours per individual contract. Meet one-on-one and via MIO. Requires department approval. Contact mpotter@dawsoncollege.qc.ca</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Friday, March 24, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Extra Information:</label><div class="col-md-10">This section requires you to understand the policies and procedures for <a href="/intensive-compressed-and-outdoor-education-courses/">Intensive / Compressed and Outdoor Education Courses</a></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 19, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 19, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - Several pre-expedition lectures will help students develop the required skills (menu planning, equipment, shelter building, first aid) and mental attitudes. In addition to personal preparation for the excursion, students will plan and carry out an individualized fitness program outside of class time. All classes and training sessions are mandatory. Students missing these sessions will be considered unprepared and may be denied permission to participate on the expedition. Students are responsible for providing their own food and personal clothing. Sleeping: outdoors in snow shelters, basecamp with side excursions. Physical Challenge: Medium. This course takes place off-campus. Verify facility location, dates, and cost in the “Timetable & Registration Guide” prior to registering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Fee</label><div class="col-md-10"> $0.00</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">OUTDOOR EDUCATION INTENSIVE HELD ON THREE CONSECUTIVE DAYS, INCLUDING TWO OVERNIGHTS AT AN OUTDOOR EDUCATION CENTRE; TRAVEL TIME IS NOT INCLUDED</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 7, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Extra Information:</label><div class="col-md-10">This section requires you to understand the policies and procedures for <a href="/intensive-compressed-and-outdoor-education-courses/">Intensive / Compressed and Outdoor Education Courses</a></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 23, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 23, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - The 3-day intensive is split in two comprised of a 2-day canoe trip, with an overnight, followed on a separate weekend by a one-day hike taking place in the Laurentians north of Montreal. All classes and intensive days are mandatory. Students missing these sessions will be considered unprepared and may be denied permission to continue in the course. This course takes place off-campus. Verify facility location and dates in the “Timetable & Registration Guide” prior to registering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Fee</label><div class="col-md-10"> $0.00</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">OUTDOOR EDUCATION INTENSIVE HELD ON THREE CONSECUTIVE DAYS, INCLUDING TWO OVERNIGHTS AT AN OUTDOOR EDUCATION CENTRE; TRAVEL TIME IS NOT INCLUDED</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Friday, February 3, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Extra Information:</label><div class="col-md-10">This section requires you to understand the policies and procedures for <a href="/intensive-compressed-and-outdoor-education-courses/">Intensive / Compressed and Outdoor Education Courses</a></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 19, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 19, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - This 3-day retreat offers students the opportunity to disconnect with technology and society, and re-connect with nature and oneself. All classes and yoga sessions are mandatory. This course takes place off-campus. 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Manawan Quebec</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Physics</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-912-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Civil Engineering Physics I</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Stewart</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students of Civil Engineering Technology learn the basic principles of statics, forces and structures with an emphasis on applications. The basic laws of mechanics will be applied to a wide range of phenomena of importance to civil engineering. Modeling as a tool will be introduced to analyze experimental data. The course prepares students for more advanced courses such as structural analysis.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Civil Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-924-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Optics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Basim Assaf</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first physics course for students in the Analytical Chemistry program. The primary aim of the course is to acquaint students with the basic concepts required to understand the physical properties of the equipment used in Analytical Chemistry. In addition to both geometric and wave optics, the course will cover basic concepts in nuclear and modern physics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Lab Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-943-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Engineering Physics I</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jaime Sandoval</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is intended to introduce the student to the engineering approach for the solution of equilibrium problems. Topics covered include: units and unit conversions, vectors and forces, moments and couples, equilibrium, structures, friction, centroids and centre of gravity, moment of inertia.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Mech Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Baryliuk-Raimbert</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is intended to introduce the student to the engineering approach for the solution of equilibrium problems. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-BWT-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Science and technology: intro to the science of physics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Physics of Hollywood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Stewart</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This complementary course will be of interest to students with little or no background in science but who are curious about how things work and wonder if the science portrayed in the movies is correct or not. By watching movies, conducting simple experiments and following the scientific method students will learn about physics and science. Topics will include invisibility, time travel, parallel universes and more. From James Bond to Bugs Bunny, Spiderman to Jurassic Park the course is fun way to learn about the world and how it really works.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-BZA-05</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Astrophysics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nadim Boukhira</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course offers a calculus-level introduction to classical and modern astronomy. Students may choose to do the independent study project of the comprehensive examination in this course. Topics include: celestial coordinate systems, tides and eclipses, time and the calendar, the solar system, the motions, distances, magnitudes and spectra of the stars, galaxies, quasars and cosmology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rim Dib</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course offers a calculus-level introduction to classical and modern astronomy. The course involves extensive use of computers in the gathering and analysis of data as well as in using spreadsheets to model a variety of different physical phenomena. The topics covered include: kinematics and dynamics of rigid body motion; fluid mechanics; structural analysis of frames, trusses and beams; statics in three dimensions; strength of materials. Students may choose to do the independent study project of the comprehensive examination in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean-François Brière</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an option course for students in the Science Program who wish to pursue their interest in engineering and related fields. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-BZT-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Special Topics in Physics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Research in Brain Imaging</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Hélène Nadeau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Introduction to Research in Brain Imaging: The objective of this option course of the Science program is to develop research skills through projects and group investigations related to brain imaging. Topics covered include: the physics behind both magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalography, the processing and analysis of signals and images, the anatomy and connectivity of the brain, specialized software, the statistics involved in group comparison as well as the ethical considerations expected when working with human brain images. The students will work on the various stages of an authentic experiment: design, writing of proposal for ethic board approval, planning, data collection, data preprocessing, data analysis, and discussion of results. There will be group discussions, team work and several student presentations. Students having completed this course can apply to participate in the Summer Research in Neuroscience Internship program.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-NYA-05</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Mechanics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">7 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chris Roderick</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Mechanics is the first course in the physics sequence of the science program, covering the basic concepts of force, energy and momentum, and the laws governing motion. Students will be introduced to the acquisition and analysis of data by computer. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">203-NYB-05</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Electricity and Magnetism</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">9 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chris Roderick</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The third course in the physics sequence of the science program deals with electric and magnetic phenomena. Computers are used in the experimental work in this course. Topics include electrostatics, Coulomb's Law, electric field and potential, lines of force and equipotentials, Gauss's Law, capacitors and dielectrics, DC circuits, the magnetic field, the laws of Biot-Savart and Ampère, magnetic force on moving charges and currents, torque on a current loop, electromagnetic induction and Faraday's Law, inductance, energy density of electric and magnetic fields. Students may opt to do the independent study project of the comprehensive examination in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Enriched Science</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rim Dib</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The third course in the physics sequence of the science program deals with electric and magnetic phenomena. It introduces oscillations, mechanical waves, optics and modern physics. Students will extend their skills in using the computer to gather data. Topics include: simple harmonic motion; damping, forced oscillations and resonance; waves in material media, including sound waves; beats and the Doppler effect; ray and wave optics; introduction to modern physics.  Students in their third or fourth semester may opt to do the independent study project of their comprehensive examination in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Enriched Science</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Volodymyr Feshchenko</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the science program's second course in physics. It introduces oscillations, mechanical waves, optics and modern physics. Students will extend their skills in using the computer to gather data. Topics include: simple harmonic motion; damping, forced oscillations and resonance; waves in material media, including sound waves; beats and the Doppler effect; ray and wave optics; introduction to modern physics.  Students in their third or fourth semester may opt to do the independent study project of their comprehensive examination in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Volodymyr Feshchenko</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the science program's second course in physics. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">144-451-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Orthopedic Rehabilitation: Extremities</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Krista Gem Bulow</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines normal and abnormal function and various orthopedic pathologies of the upper and lower extremities. Making use of principles based on the previous terms, students will practice implementation of safe and effective rehabilitation protocols to address orthopedic dysfunction. This course will also introduce the students to various rehabilitation techniques specific to the extremities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Krista Gem Bulow</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines normal and abnormal function and various orthopedic pathologies of the upper and lower extremities. This course will also introduce the students to various rehabilitation techniques specific to these areas.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Erika Hasler</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines normal and abnormal function and various orthopedic pathologies of the hip, spine and pelvis of the human body. Making use of principles based on the previous terms, students will practice the implementation of safe and effective rehabilitation protocols to address orthopedic dysfunction. This course will also introduce the students to various rehabilitation techniques specific to these areas.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">144-453-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Neurology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gloria Thevasagayam</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn to rehabilitate clients with neurological problems within the physiotherapy technologist’s scope of practice. In lecture classes, students will learn about the various conditions and how clients with these conditions will present in various settings. Conditions that will be covered include stroke, Parkinson’s disease, multiple sclerosis, traumatic brain injury, and spinal cord injury among others. In labs, students will learn various assessment and treatment techniques that are used in the rehabilitation and maintenance of neurological clients. These techniques include but are not limited to collecting data on function, task-oriented intervention strategies and proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation, among others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gloria Thevasagayam</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn to rehabilitate clients with neurological problems within the physiotherapy technologist’s scope of practice. In lecture classes, students will learn about the various conditions and how clients with these conditions will present in various settings. Conditions that will be covered include stroke, Parkinson’s disease, multiple sclerosis, traumatic brain injury, and spinal cord injury among others. In labs, students will learn various assessment and treatment techniques that are used in the rehabilitation and maintenance of neurological clients. Martin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the nature and extent of democracy underlying the Canadian political system.  It focuses on the stresses and strains on the federal structure stemming from the often conflicting needs and demands of people with strong regional identities.  The course also examines the functioning of parliamentary government in terms of meeting the expectations of citizens and evaluates the democratic nature of political parties, interest groups, and the voting system.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michel Fournier-Simard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the nature and extent of democracy underlying the Canadian political system.  It focuses on the stresses and strains on the federal structure stemming from the often conflicting needs and demands of people with strong regional identities.  The course also examines the functioning of parliamentary government in terms of meeting the expectations of citizens and evaluates the democratic nature of political parties, interest groups, and the voting system.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">385-311-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Global Politics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Cynthia J. Martin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a study of politics among the nation-states in the world. It looks at the role of international organizations, such as the United Nations, NATO, OECD, as well as non-governmental organizations, and the emerging civil society in dealing with conflict and promoting cooperation. Particular attention will be given to the impact of globalization, in terms of both positive and negative effects, and to the growing opposition movements.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for International Business Studies.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">385-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Studies in Politics</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Abortion, Prostitution, and Drugs: Supreme Court and the Law</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marianne Pelton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will look at the political role and impact of the Supreme Court of Canada. Throughout the class we will focus on decisions made by the court (especially recent decisions) as a way of exploring the following themes: The structure and constitution of the Court in Canada; the impact of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms; the relationship of the Court to Canada’s federal, bijural and multicultural political system; the relationship of the Court to other branches of government, especially the Prime Minister.  Students are required to submit a final project that will demonstrate their acquired knowledge from this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for Law, Society and Justice.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - It introduces students to the study and practice of photography as an art form, covering photographic concepts and processes, photographic history, as well as studio/seminars on contemporary issues. Projects will investigate the creative use of long exposures, light as a modifier, and the procedures and aesthetics of ink jet printing. Students will be guided in the creation of a thematic portfolio.  This grounding in photographic practices prepares the student for New Media and Video (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.23</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martin Segal</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 2 photography course follows New Media in Term 1. Participants will learn to apply professional photography techniques with their own (required) cameras to make persuasive imagery.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Digital Photography: Art and Techniques of Persuasion</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patrizia Castiglione</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">NEW COURSE TITLE IS Digital Photography: The Art & Technique of Persuasion    This course looks at how photography is used as applied visual persuasion.
