Participants will learn to apply professional photography techniques with their own (required) cameras to make persuasive imagery.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Professional Theatre</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-201-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Movement for Actors 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Elissa Bernstein, Kimberley Barfuss</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Stage movement: This course is designed to further develop the student’s kinesthetic skills that can be applied to theatrical performance. Emphasis will be placed on continuing to develop within the student an understanding of his/her body as an instrument of expression and communication. Exercises and explorations will further concentrate on body awareness and physically conditioning the student for performance with a focus on incorporating text. (1.5 hours/week) Dance: Students will acquire familiarity with dance forms commonly required of an actor in the theatre today. (1.5 hours/week) Sword Fighting: This course will explore more advanced skills of generic sword techniques, more advanced fight choreographies and cardio/physical endurance exercises. (2 hours/week)</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Elissa Bernstein, Kimberley Barfuss</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Stage movement: This course is designed to further develop the student’s kinesthetic skills that can be applied to theatrical performance. Emphasis will be placed on continuing to develop within the student an understanding of his/her body as an instrument of expression and communication. Exercises and explorations will further concentrate on body awareness and physically conditioning the student for performance with a focus on incorporating text. (1.5 hours/week) Dance: Students will acquire familiarity with dance forms commonly required of an actor in the theatre today. (1.5 hours/week) Sword Fighting: This course will explore more advanced skills of generic sword techniques, more advanced fight choreographies and cardio/physical endurance exercises. (2 hours/week)</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-212-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Improvisation 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew Michael Enos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students continue to develop body awareness, imagination and the ability to create the imaginary space. Special emphasis will be placed on the Elizabethan script and the acting practices of Shakespeare and his contemporaries.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Movement for Actors 4</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kimberley Barfuss</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Stage movement: This course is designed to further develop the student’s kinesthetic skills that can be applied to theatrical performance. Emphasis will be placed on continuing to develop within the student an understanding of his/her body as an instrument of expression and communication. Exercises and explorations will further concentrate on body awareness and physically conditioning the student for performance with a focus on incorporating text. Dance: Students will acquire familiarity with dance forms commonly required of an actor in the theatre today. Sword Fighting: This course will explore more advanced skills of generic sword techniques, more advanced fight choreographies and cardio/physical endurance exercises. (2 hours/week)</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kimberley Barfuss</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Stage movement: This course is designed to further develop the student’s kinesthetic skills that can be applied to theatrical performance. They acquire clown and comedy-improvisation skills and perform in an improv show. Furthermore, they will use music, photographs, poetry and short stories to stimulate a creative group response.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Arianna Bardesono</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students continue to sharpen basic improvisational skills and develop and deepen their choices for character and relationship. They acquire clown and comedy-improvisation skills and perform in an improv show. Furthermore, they will use music, photographs, poetry and short stories to stimulate a creative group response.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-423-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Voice and Speech 4</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Elissa Bernstein, Matt Holland</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Voice and Speech: Students develop more sophisticated exercises in vocalization (including heightened emotion) and incorporate them into a personal warm-up. Dialect work continues hand in hand with the study of Vocal Qualities. Standard North American Speech is acquired through the performance of a monologue (3 hours/week).     Studio Voice: A continuation of the study of the voice in the recording studio with final production of an MP3 voice demo (2 hours/week).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Leslie Baker, Matt Holland</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Voice and Speech: Students develop more sophisticated exercises in vocalization (including heightened emotion) and incorporate them into a personal warm-up. Dialect work continues hand in hand with the study of Vocal Qualities. Standard North American Speech is acquired through the performance of a monologue (3 hours/week).     Studio Voice: A continuation of the study of the voice in the recording studio with final production of an MP3 voice demo (2 hours/week).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-434-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Acting 4</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leslie Baker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Acting styles: Early Modern & Shakespearean; History of playwrights of the Early Modern period; Early Modern and Shakespearean scenes. Theatre through the Enlightenment, Romanticism, the Age of Revolution and the Well-Made Play. Social forces and lives of the actors. Works by Behn, Gay, Sheridan, Diderot, Beaumarchais, Goethe, Buchner and Rostand (3 hours/week).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-465-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Make-up, Rehearsal, and Performance 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">George Tucci, Stefanie L Buxton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Studio production: (groups 1 and 2) This course will enable the student to apply his/her skills in auditioning for, rehearsing and performing a role in a full-length play. The play will be presented in a four-night run to a public audience (out-of-class rehearsal required). Make-up: Students learn to identify the various types of faces and facial characteristics, and to identify the ideal proportions of the face and the head as well as the skill to modify them when necessary with the help of prostheses (moustache/facial hair, etc.) and make-up (2 hours/week).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-601-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Movement for Actors 6</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Elissa Bernstein, Kimberley Barfuss</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">STAGE MOVEMENT: This final semester is a consolidation and clarification of the work of the previous five semesters as it applies to the body as an instrument for theatrical creativity and interpretation. Students will continue to hone their skills in combining movement techniques with that of other artistic disciplines in building a character. Exploring a variety of movement/ blocking choices in support of both character and the requirements of a text will further prepare the student to truthfully follow impulses so as to be more physically agile, adept, enlivened and present when performing on stage. (1.5 hours/week)  DANCE: This final semester allows for consolidation and a deepened understanding of the preceding work. The student will continue to develop refined control and nuanced expressiveness in the execution of advanced dance combinations that are coordinated with demanding singing challenges. (1.5 hours/week)</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-623-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Voice and Speech 6</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jonathan Monro</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students assimilate and integrate all acquired vocal skills and bring them to bear on practical performance. Students are encouraged to integrate vocal techniques into the acting process, and to master the tools of voice in order to make the technique automatic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-634-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Acting 6 - Rehearsal</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Edward Hughes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the focus is research, readings and text analysis in preparation for playing a role in the 3rd Major production. Working with the director, students will engage in character and dialect work(if required), as well as preliminary blocking.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-635-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Acting Before the Camera 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stefanie L Buxton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Advanced on-camera acting technique will continue, including deeper emotional connection, in-depth scene work and scene-partnership. This course will provide tools for the emerging actor to begin work in the competitive field of film and television acting.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-657-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">History and Literature 6</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leah Esau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In the final section of the course, a number of distinct theatrical cultures are opened up for the student: Japanese theatre, American drama in the twentieth century, and the history of Canadian theatre is given a major section. The course ends with an attempt to bring coherence to the kaleidoscopic world of the contemporary stage.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">561-665-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Rehearsal and Performance 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Leslie Baker, Michael Edward Hughes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Major stage productions (2 and 3): Two full-length plays, supported by full production elements, taken from audition, through rehearsal, to a two-week run in front of a public audience. While gaining exposure to two directorial approaches, the student will integrate all the skills acquired to this point in order to present a clear, consistent and believable character. (out-of-class rehearsal required)</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">THEATRE</td><td data-label="Type">Tutorial</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">THEATRE</td><td data-label="Type">Tutorial</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">THEATRE</td><td data-label="Type">Tutorial</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Psychology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; Arvanitidis</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course deals with human sexual development and response patterns. The course addresses itself to both the psychological, physiological and socio-cultural factors shaping and influencing human sexual behaviour. Topics include motivation, aptitude testing, opinion and market research, advertising, compensation systems, organizational behaviour, and the role of the individual in the work place.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for International Business Studies.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">350-323-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applications of Psychology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Social Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pavel Piterkin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course considers the complex relationships between individuals and the environment. The emphasis is on theory, research and applications. Possible topics include attitude formation, group structure and dynamics, leadership, affiliation, social perception, conformity, prejudice, obedience, romantic love, attraction, aggression and altruism.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Brain and Behavior</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stephane Gaskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">At the end of this course the student will be able to understand and recognize the research methods used in the study of biological psychology. They will also be able to understand, identify, explain, and explore the major findings of biological psychology. Students will learn about various neurological disorders, their causes and their possible treatments. They will be able to apply the concepts of biological psychology to real life situations and learn how to navigate through databases, references, and write a paper analyzing several journal articles.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">350-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Studies in Psychology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Thinking and Memory</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rajesh Malik</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will investigate the workings of the human mind by considering the topics of perception, memory, thinking, judgment, and decision making.  It will examine how these processes operate normally, as well as establishing when and how they are affected by biases we hold.  Some of the specific issues the course will look at include: problems of human memory and its implications for the law and justice system, how people make day-to-day decisions about their finances and shopping needs, and suggestions for becoming better thinkers and informed decision makers.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Fundamentals of Learning</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stephane Gaskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the theories of learning in humans and non-human animals. Advanced concepts in classical conditioning, instrumental conditioning and memory will be discussed at much greater depth than in a general psychology course. Students will also learn about the stimulus control of behaviour, self-control, types of memory, and observational learning. In addition, students will learn to apply the learning principles covered in the course to their everyday lives and learn about the behavioural methods used in research and therapy. In line with the elements of competency, they will acquire knowledge of the field of learning through 1) devising the outlines of a behavioural journal in which 2) they will be asked to keep track of their behaviours in the various contexts of their daily lives and 3) identifying them with the concepts learned in class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Fundamentals of Learning</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stephane Gaskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the theories of learning in humans and non-human animals. Advanced concepts in classical conditioning, instrumental conditioning and memory will be discussed at much greater depth than in a general psychology course. Students will also learn about the stimulus control of behaviour, self-control, types of memory, and observational learning. In addition, students will learn to apply the learning principles covered in the course to their everyday lives and learn about the behavioural methods used in research and therapy. In line with the elements of competency, they will acquire knowledge of the field of learning through 1) devising the outlines of a behavioural journal in which 2) they will be asked to keep track of their behaviours in the various contexts of their daily lives and 3) identifying them with the concepts learned in class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Thinking and Memory</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rajesh Malik</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will investigate the workings of the human mind by considering the topics of perception, memory, thinking, judgment, and decision making.  It will examine how these processes operate normally, as well as establishing when and how they are affected by biases we hold.  Some of the specific issues the course will look at include: problems of human memory and its implications for the law and justice system, how people make day-to-day decisions about their finances and shopping needs, and suggestions for becoming better thinkers and informed decision makers.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-350-B</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">All 401courses in Psychology are offered under Advanced Studies in Psychology.  Each subheaded course focuses on a particular area of interest in psychology. All sections fulfill the same competencies and have similar assignments. In all sections of 401 students are encouraged to design and complete a project based on the application of knowledge acquired in previous psychology courses.    Note: There are several subheadings for this course depending on who the instructor is for the term. Students can only take one 401 psychology course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">350-944-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Communication and Interpersonal Interaction</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan Finch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn about the proper professional skills and attitudes required when interacting with clients seeking physical rehabilitation therapy and/or with other health care professionals. To this effect, principles and methods of interpersonal communication will be analyzed. We study, among other things, verbal and nonverbal communication, people perceptions, interpersonal relationships, and effective conflict resolution strategies. 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Quantitative Methods</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-124-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Principles of Mathematics and Logic</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brian Redekopp</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course intends to introduce students to the nature of mathematical reasoning, and to certain theoretical considerations central to it, such as validity, proof, axiom, postulate, etc. Among the subjects included in this course are deductive systems, inductive logic, and axiomatic structures and their importance in much of ordinary mathematics (the decimal system, alternative number system, elementary arithmetic and algebra, Euclidian and non-Euclidian geometries, functions, calculus, etc.). The course also examines the distinction between “pure” and “applied” mathematics, and the reasons that mathematics seems to be virtually indispensable as the language of science.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-199-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Integrative Seminar for Liberal Arts</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Beverly Sing, Susan-Judith Hoffmann</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this final term seminar, students demonstrate their ability to draw together and integrate the knowledge and skills acquired in the disciplines and courses of the program. The seminar discusses between ten and fifteen mandatory readings: essays, stories, poems, plays, excerpts from larger works, etc., drawn from the variety of subject areas in the program, including the English and Humanities courses of the fourth term. Also, students may bring into their presentations relevant research from other courses in the fourth term. Groups of three to five students present their research on topics drawn from each reading, and lead the seminar. Each student's oral presentation is followed by questions from the class. A critical bibliography of the subject of the presentation is required.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4C.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-300-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Quantitative Methods</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">14 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Erin Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the second of the three (3) methodology courses. It builds on the introduction to social science research covered in Research Methods. This course teaches the student to apply statistical tools to the interpretation of data related to contexts of study in the field of social science. The focus of the course is on the analysis of quantitative data as part of the scientific approach. Areas examined are identification of variables, presentation of data, analysis of data using various forms of measurement, determining the nature and link between variables, and estimating the parameters of a given population based on the corresponding statistics obtained from a sample.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Erin Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the second of the three (3) methodology courses. It builds on the introduction to social science research covered in Research Methods. This course teaches the student to apply statistical tools to the interpretation of data related to contexts of study in the field of social science. The focus of the course is on the analysis of quantitative data as part of the scientific approach. Areas examined are identification of variables, presentation of data, analysis of data using various forms of measurement, determining the nature and link between variables, and estimating the parameters of a given population based on the corresponding statistics obtained from a sample.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anna De Aguayo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the second of the three (3) methodology courses. It builds on the introduction to social science research covered in Research Methods. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-321-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Field Experience in a Developing Country</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sara Louise Kendall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Through this course, students will apply concepts such as social justice, international and community development, and organizing, feminism, sustainability, and solidarity. These will be explored through a virtual exchange with community initiatives in the Global South (Cuba, Chile, Mexico, and Nicaragua). Through a series of webinars, students will engage with local community leaders from different localities and deepen their knowledge of the Global South as well as develop ties of solidarity. They will identify, describe, and explain some of the key economic and social issues facing the Global South and local community responses to food insecurity, education, health care, gender, and race relations. They will assess the present impact of non-governmental, community-based organizations on the development of the Global South. Students will engage in fund-raising activities to collaborate in supporting local development projects in the South and will strengthen their language skills.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">North South Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Environmental Studies</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sustenance, Sustainability, and the Sacred</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will analyse ethical, environmental, and health concerns related to food, nature, and notions of the sacred through the lenses offered by sociology, anthropology, and religious studies. Students will have the opportunity to focus on one modern day environmental food crisis and offer research-based viable solution(s) as to how one would promote and preserve biodiversity, cultural integrity, and sustainability. The emphasis is on providing students with the necessary skills to investigate significant environmental issues using knowledge, concepts, methods and tools necessary to allow them to prepare a pertinent final research based project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sustenance, Sustainability, and the Sacred</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will analyse ethical, environmental, and health concerns related to food, nature, and notions of the sacred through the lenses offered by sociology, anthropology, and religious studies. Students will have the opportunity to focus on one modern day environmental food crisis and offer research-based viable solution(s) as to how one would promote and preserve biodiversity, cultural integrity, and sustainability. The emphasis is on providing students with the necessary skills to investigate significant environmental issues using knowledge, concepts, methods and tools necessary to allow them to prepare a pertinent final research based project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-420-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Computer Programming in Engineering and Science</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Nasreddine Hallam, Sameer Bhatnagar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The computer science part of this course introduces students to the fundamentals of object-oriented programming. Students learn how to analyze problems and then design and implement both numerical and non-numerical algorithms to solve them. Students learn to create new abstract data types, i.e. classes, and how to instantiate objects of various class types.The engineering and science part of the course revisits material students have covered in previous science courses but does so in a way that begins to appreciate their true complexity. Students analyze real-world problems, develop models, and then solve the relevant equations using appropriate numerical methods via the programming techniques developed in the computer science component. The focus is on the process of modeling and problems will be taken from a wide range of fields.  IMPORTANT: Students who have successfully completed a complementary course with the course number 420-BWC or 420-BXC are not eligible to take this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Campbell, Sameer Bhatnagar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The computer science part of this course introduces students to the fundamentals of object-oriented programming. The course gives students knowledge of basic atomic and nuclear physics. Battista</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to give the student a basic comprehension of applied principles of imaging modalities and techniques in Radiation Oncology. The students will study the spread of disease, role of the lymphatic system, characteristics of normal and malignant cells, and clinical history and presentation. The student will also learn about the safety and the radiobiological effects on tissue including the principles of fractionation. Finally, the students will learn of the various treatment modalities, the prescription and basic principles of pharmacology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - The students will study the spread of disease, role of the lymphatic system, characteristics of normal and malignant cells, and clinical history and presentation. The student will also learn about the safety and the radiobiological effects on tissue including the principles of fractionation. Finally, the students will learn of the various treatment modalities, the prescription and basic principles of pharmacology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - The students will study the spread of disease, role of the lymphatic system, characteristics of normal and malignant cells, and clinical history and presentation. The student will also learn about the safety and the radiobiological effects on tissue including the principles of fractionation. Finally, the students will learn of the various treatment modalities, the prescription and basic principles of pharmacology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-421-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Dosimetry</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Radiation Oncology team McGill</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Applied Dosimetry course deals with radiation dosimetry and concentrates on beam measurement techniques, quality assurance issues in treatment planning, as well as the special techniques used in treatment planning and delivery. The basic quantities and units used in dosimetry are discussed in detail and their application in the calculation of clinical dose distributions is explained. The course starts with a discussion of single photon beams and progresses through dose distributions obtained with multiple photon beams to electron beams and dosimetry in brachytherapy. Students will produce and evaluate clinical treatment plans.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - The main goal is to review and reflect on the OTIMROEPMQ Standards of Practice, Entry Profile to the Profession, and the CAMRT Competency Profile. The course also includes lectures, workshops and presentations that will prepare the student for the profession such as: CV writing, the job interview process, the OTIMROEPMQ professional order, Hope and Cope patient support services, nursing and patient care services in Radiation Oncology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; The student will participate, for  planning purposes, in the production and use of accessories for treatment, (setup, imaging verification, post procedural responsibilities, and dosimetry). The student will also participate in the setup, imaging verification, and the administration of a treatment. Lastly,the student will participate in professional development activities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: January 23 to March 16, 2023 HOSPITAL</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, February 1, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 23, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Mar 16, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Hospital</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Religion</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-102-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to World Religions</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">8 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Calogero Miceli</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion.
