It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-215-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Religion and Popular Culture</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sonia Zylberberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Because popular culture both reflects and affects the society in which it is situated, it contains many references to the religions practiced within that society. These references can be explicit or implicit, conscious or unconscious. In this course we will focus on a number of particular cultural objects containing these references, examining the religious components inherent in the objects and analyzing the way in which their meanings have or have not changed with the transition from religious to secular context. This can help us analyze some of the transformations occurring within our society even as we live through those changes. In addition to examining some of these objects together as a class, students will choose an individual object to analyze and will present their findings in writing as well as sharing these with the rest of the class in an oral presentation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-318-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Exploring Religions</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Witches, Saints, Gurus, and Mystics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Philip Lagace</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will use a multimedia approach to the study of witches, saints, gurus and mystics from a variety of religious traditions. After examining the characteristics of a mystical experience, as discussed by William James, we will delve into the lives of controversial and influential historical figures, like Hildegard von Bingen, and other fascinating personages from Western, as well as Eastern religious cultures where the guru (spiritual teacher) occupies a significant position. The portrayal of witches during European witch hunts along with that of witches in popular culture will be considered, culminating in a study of Wicca’s development, and key beliefs and practices within this neo-pagan movement. Throughout the course we will apply concepts related to social science disciplines, including those of religion, sociology and history, to the understanding of the topics mentioned above.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-917-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Cults and Culture</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Johanne Rabbat</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course explores the origins, beliefs, rituals and social organizations of some of the new religious movements that contribute to the religious landscape of North America. Sociological, historical and psychological approaches will be employed in the study.  Among other subjects, the course will discuss theories of conversion, the “brainwashing”/deprogramming controversy, charismatic authority and the ritual processes within these sects. The contentious status of Scientology, the Wiccan and the Raelian traditions will be analyzed, as will their relationships to their host societies. This course represents a scientific and academic study of New Religious Movements and as such maintains a safe and structured environment for students.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Languages, Literature, Interactive Media Arts, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Johanne Rabbat</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course explores the origins, beliefs, rituals and social organizations of some of the new religious movements that contribute to the religious landscape of North America. Sociological, historical and psychological approaches will be employed in the study.  Among other subjects, the course will discuss theories of conversion, the “brainwashing”/deprogramming controversy, charismatic authority and the ritual processes within these sects. The contentious status of Scientology, the Wiccan and the Raelian traditions will be analyzed, as will their relationships to their host societies. This course represents a scientific and academic study of New Religious Movements and as such maintains a safe and structured environment for students.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Languages, Literature, Interactive Media Arts, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-BWS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Religion Studies</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">8 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to World Religions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion, and how it contributes to an understanding of contemporary issues. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to World Religions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion, and how it contributes to an understanding of contemporary issues. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to World Religions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-370-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion, and how it contributes to an understanding of contemporary issues. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-BXS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social science: applications in religion studies</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Contemporary Social Concerns: Sex, Gender and Religion</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sonia Zylberberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the relationships between religion, sexuality, and gender.  We will examine attitudes towards sexuality within different religions, and see how these attitudes form the basis for gender roles that, once entrenched, are very difficult to change.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Research Methodology & Integrated Seminar</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">300-300-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Research Methods</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">42 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-300-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. The goal of the course is to apply the scientific approach to the various social science disciplines. Students identify a research problem and follow the steps to select a research method appropriate to the problem, produce a data collection tool, collect, analyze and interpret the data. The culmination of the process is a research report that presents the research steps in the context of a brief literature review of the topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-300-A</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. The goal of the course is to apply the scientific approach to the various social science disciplines. Students identify a research problem and follow the steps to select a research method appropriate to the problem, produce a data collection tool, collect, analyze and interpret the data. The culmination of the process is a research report that presents the research steps in the context of a brief literature review of the topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Dan Loomer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. The culmination of the process is a research report that presents the research steps in the context of a brief literature review of the topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Cynthia De Luca</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. You will read, summarize and analyze academic sources on two different aspects of your passion and have a taste of multidisciplinary study in social sciences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Finding Your Passion</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marc-André Girouard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will have the opportunity to figure out what you are very passionate about, and make a scholarly research paper out of it. You will read, summarize and analyze academic sources on two different aspects of your passion and have a taste of multidisciplinary study in social sciences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Entrepreneurship</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Menouar Boulahfa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The entrepreneurial process involves the identification and evaluation of an opportunity; the decision whether or not to exploit it; the efforts to obtain the resources; the process for organizing those resources in some cases into an innovative combination and the development of a strategy for the new venture. Students will find out how innovative entrepreneurs created their businesses and will discuss their profitable undertakings. Students will write about one chosen innovative entrepreneur through the lenses of two self-chosen social disciplines to integrate, on an individual basis, the learning achieved during the DEC program.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elliot Kerr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students in the Social Science Program take this course in their final term after having passed Research Methods (300-300-DW) and Quantitative Methods (360-300-DW). The Integrative Seminar provides the student with an opportunity to consider how the various social sciences can work together to contribute to understanding social phenomena. Using at least three (3) social science disciplines, students will explore a topic related to the seminar theme in a series of distinct stages, ultimately producing a long essay on this exploration. This integrative project will address some of the linkages and differences among social sciences and show how their combined use makes for a deeper understanding of the selected topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elliot Kerr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students in the Social Science Program take this course in their final term after having passed Research Methods (300-300-DW) and Quantitative Methods (360-300-DW). Through the lens of history, philosophy, psychology, religion, etc. this course will explore conventional and unconventional hypotheses about these questions, evaluate their plausibility and attempt to delineate the similarities and differences between “belief,” “truth” and “knowledge”. Part of this process will be the opportunity for students to step into and out of the conceptual “box” in order to dissect commonplace assumptions about who we are, as a species, and whereto we are heading.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Controversial Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Melanie Doyle</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The general theme for this IS class is “Controversial Issues” and this can apply to so many things: poverty, abuse, addiction, global warming, porn-culture, gender, social media, cryptocurrencies – and even happiness: the list goes on. Over the course of the semester, you will complete a research paper, drawing on peer-reviewed research from at least three social science disciplines, which takes a position on a debate within the field. The theme of this course is deliberately broad to allow students to focus on an issue that interests them; I leave it to each student to define “Issue” and apply the theme to whatever most intrigues them. The principal aim of the course is for you to develop a well-reasoned and well-researched argument on your topic</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Controversial Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Melanie Doyle</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The general theme for this IS class is “Controversial Issues” and this can apply to so many things: poverty, abuse, addiction, global warming, porn-culture, gender, social media, cryptocurrencies – and even happiness: the list goes on. The principal aim of the course is for you to develop a well-reasoned and well-researched argument on your topic</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Victuals</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Caroline Chochol</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Integrative Seminar provides students with an opportunity to consider how the various social sciences can work together to contribute to understanding the complex nature of the theme "Victuals," or food. This course covers a spectrum of issues, from production, transport and accessibility, to marketing, and to the historical, biological, and psychological importance of food. Students will prepare a project related to the theme in a series of distinct stages, using at least three (3) social science disciplines.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Vaccine Hesitancy and Belief in Conspiracy Theories</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robin Joseph Gagnon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This IS section will be devoted to an exploration of the causes of human irrationality and belief in unsubstantiated phenomena. Possible avenues of exploration will be examining the contribution of cognitive biases, propaganda, and persuasion, as well as the effects of personality types, normal psychological characteristics, and mental disorders. Students will use a multidisciplinary approach drawing from at least three different social science disciplines.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues in Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Calogero Miceli</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course deals with the social science phenomenon of the processes and procedures in the sphere of Psychology. The areas of research may include issues in clinical and social psychology. The students will select three disciplines related to their subject of research and will use appropriate methodological approaches from these disciplines to define the process of integration. As part of the methodology students will evaluate academic sources and databases, including those available on the Internet. Students will present their research findings in an oral presentation to the class. Next, by integrating feedback from teacher based on their written and oral work, students will produce a final paper to complete the integrative project by writing a paper of 4000 words.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues in Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Calogero Miceli</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course deals with the social science phenomenon of the processes and procedures in the sphere of Psychology. How should children be educated? What are the goals of education? How has education changed over time? What should the job of educator entail? Where should funding for educational resources come from? And these questions merely scratch the surface. Students will get the chance to explore the topic cross-culturally, sociologically, psychologically, historically, and/or economically. Ultimately, we will take this opportunity to explore many facets of education.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Fashion Your Passion</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ahmad Banki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will have the opportunity to figure out what you are really passionate about, and fashion a scholarly research paper out of it. You will read, summarize and analyze academic sources on three different aspects of your passion and have a taste of multidisciplinary study in social sciences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Fashion Your Passion</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ahmad Banki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will have the opportunity to figure out what you are really passionate about, and fashion a scholarly research paper out of it. You will read, summarize and analyze academic sources on three different aspects of your passion and have a taste of multidisciplinary study in social sciences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Contemporary Threats to Liberal Democracy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Donal Gill</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course seeks to investigate the stability of governing institutions across liberal democracies in the 21st century. Contemporary challenges facing liberal democracies around the world today will be analyzed through a multidisciplinary social scientific perspective. The course will engage social science disciplines such as political science, sociology, history, psychology, economics etc. to assist in the writing of a research paper that investigates a core issue related to democratic values, governance and consolidation. Students will write a research paper on liberal democracy and democratic consolidation/deconsolidation before pursuing independent research on a related topic of their choosing.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Global Justice Issues?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00034</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Braithwaite</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In today’s 21st century, issues of social justice, equity, and human rights for all have become an overriding concern for countries and communities around the globe. Issues as diverse and wide-ranging as racial equity, hunger and food security, gender equality, decolonization, and access to healthcare have increasingly driven government policy and citizen activism. Sometimes together, sometimes in opposition, nations and their populations have worked to effect change in the face of diverse global challenges. In this course, students will undertake an integrative multidisciplinary research project examining issues of global (in)justice in countries ranging from Canada to Brazil, Somalia, New Zealand, and the United States, and the steps we take in our attempts to create a just world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Indigenous Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Duckett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students choose their own topic under the category of Canada’s First Nations, Inuit, and Metis. The course begins with an overview of a number of possible topics, from the earliest, pre-contact period to the present day. Students will choose topics that interest them and that they find are important for people to understand more fully. For their social science disciplines to be used, students may choose whichever three they want as long as they can explain their relevance to their chosen topic and can find sufficient material when doing their preliminary research report.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Indigenous Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00036</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Duckett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students choose their own topic under the category of Canada’s First Nations, Inuit, and Metis. The course begins with an overview of a number of possible topics, from the earliest, pre-contact period to the present day. Students will choose topics that interest them and that they find are important for people to understand more fully. For their social science disciplines to be used, students may choose whichever three they want as long as they can explain their relevance to their chosen topic and can find sufficient material when doing their preliminary research report.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Youth and Neighborhood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00037</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nancy Rebelo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Neighbourhood is where home, school, services, and even friendships converge. As such, our most basic experiences and identities are often linked to the neighbourhood in which we grow up. In this course, students will explore how experiences of neighbourhood impact child development through three different social science disciplines. Students may choose to investigate themes such as social housing, food access, community support (health, social, recreational), urban vs. suburban, causes and consequences of neighbourhood-based social inequalities, etc. They may also choose a particular neighbourhood, in Montreal or elsewhere, to investigate its strengths and weaknesses related to child development. Students interested in pursuing careers in social services, education, or urban studies will have a chance to take a deeper look at these key issues related to how to create neighbourhoods that promote health, safety, inclusion, and happiness for children and families.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">World Cities</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00038</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Cynthia De Luca</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">New York, London, Beijing — such cities are hubs of commercial, information, and cultural exchanges. Well over half of the world’s population now lives in cities, but what exactly makes a “world city”? How do changes in the flows of people, consumption, capital, and culture affect the identities of those living in the cities? Such are the questions that will be examined in this course. Each student will choose a city and, throughout the semester, study from the perspective of three disciplines of its development and status as a global city.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Social Justice Movements</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00039</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Beauchamp</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The world as we know it exists in large part because of the forced movement of people across space. In this course, we will think about how different bodies have been moved by larger structures of power, at different points in our history. We’ll learn about the transatlantic slave trade, the displacement of Indigenous peoples, and the historical and continued exploitation of immigrant labour. An exploration of these histories will help us to develop our understandings of race, labour, land and power. From this foundation, we’ll embark on multidisciplinary investigations of contemporary issues, asking: how are today’s struggles for social justice rooted in the legacies of these histories?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Indigenous Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00040</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Duckett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students choose their own topic under the category of Canada’s First Nations, Inuit, and Metis. Contemporary challenges facing liberal democracies around the world today will be analyzed through a multidisciplinary social scientific perspective. The course will engage social science disciplines such as political science, sociology, history, psychology, economics etc. to assist in the writing of a research paper that investigates a core issue related to democratic values, governance and consolidation. Students will write a research paper on liberal democracy and democratic consolidation/deconsolidation before pursuing independent research on a related topic of their choosing.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00043</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">TBA-300-C</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students in the Social Science Program take this course in their final term after having passed Research Methods (300-300-DW) and Quantitative Methods (360-300-DW). The Integrative Seminar provides the student with an opportunity to consider how the various social sciences can work together to contribute to understanding social phenomena. Using at least three (3) social science disciplines, students will explore a topic related to the seminar theme in a series of distinct stages, ultimately producing a long essay on this exploration. This integrative project will address some of the linkages and differences among social sciences and show how their combined use makes for a deeper understanding of the selected topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">On Reserve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Social Service</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-102-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Intervention</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Murphy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course helps students to apply the knowledge and skills gained in first-year courses to a practice context. Students develop the ability to conduct beginning helping interviews and to assess individuals' needs and resources using a social service theoretical framework.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Graça Fontes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course helps students to apply the knowledge and skills gained in first-year courses to a practice context. This provides students with the opportunity to begin applying professional skills and make links between their developing social service knowledge and the direct experience of social service practice. Students also participate in a two hour weekly seminar where the connections between theory and practice are facilitated and there is opportunity for critical reflection on field practice issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Off Campus Location</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Off Campus Location</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Yaffa Elling</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students have their first fieldwork experience in the second semester of the program by spending one day per week in a supervised social service setting. Basic learning related to the components of an effective group session consists in examining the different types of groups encountered in the field, planning for a group, knowing rules of procedure, and identifying the tasks, roles and processes involved in groupwork. Students will engage in role-play activities to develop their group animation skills and to learn about the ways in which groupwork is used by social service workers with different populations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">INTENSIVE</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, January 11, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Jan 09, 2023</td><td data-label="End Date">Jan 09, 2023</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-215-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Addressing Social Problems 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marti Miller</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Addressing Social Problems 2 builds on the knowledge acquired in Addressing Social Problems 1 and the focus will be on an in-depth examination of the impact of particular social problems on individuals, family and community. Students will analyze some of the major social problems that are experienced by social service clients such as: gender issues and violence, child abuse, delinquency and legislative response to young offenders, sexuality and sexual difference, health and mental health issues, substance abuse, ageism and disability. The course continues to develop the students' understanding of the root causes of social problems, their historical development, social policy and links to economic and political factors.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2B</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marti Miller</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Addressing Social Problems 2 builds on the knowledge acquired in Addressing Social Problems 1 and the focus will be on an in-depth examination of the impact of particular social problems on individuals, family and community. Students will analyze some of the major social problems that are experienced by social service clients such as: gender issues and violence, child abuse, delinquency and legislative response to young offenders, sexuality and sexual difference, health and mental health issues, substance abuse, ageism and disability. The course continues to develop the students' understanding of the root causes of social problems, their historical development, social policy and links to economic and political factors.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-411-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social Service Research</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Yaffa Elling</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students examine the role of research in social service practice and learn basic skills that enable them to participate in simple research projects and to understand social service research literature.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2B</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; Offered in the last semester of the program, the student will continue their supervised internship, and increase their hours in field to 3 days per week.  This experience together with a weekly 2 hour seminar at the college prepares the student to further consolidate their intervention skills and social service practice from a generalist perspective.
