text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-624-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Community Intervention</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyssa Kuzmarov</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course allows students to develop the skills of working with geographic communities and with communities of people who share an identity or a common interest. This involves selecting, planning and carrying out collective projects in ways that respect people's autonomy and self-determination. Some skills include using media, organizing events, developing strategies and tactics and using various advocacy techniques to defend individual and collective rights.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2B</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-920-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Communication and Wellbeing in the Medical Ultrasound Profession</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Graça Fontes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Through the course Communication and Well-being in the Medical Ultrasound Profession, students will gain knowledge and skills to become effective communicators as future medical ultrasound technologists. The elements of interpersonal communication, the impact of diversity on communication, as well as active listening will be explored, incorporating elements of trauma-informed practice and emphasizing cultural sensitivity and competence. Expressing oneself assertively to meet one's own needs while being “other-oriented” and respecting the needs and rights of others will be practiced. An important part of the course is to develop more awareness of oneself as a communicator, and students will learn to assess their own communication style and the impact of this style on others. Students will learn principles of self and collective care as well as management of professional boundaries to prevent risks of harm and promote ethical practice in the workplace.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Medical Ultrasound Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-BWS-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social Science 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Power of Non-Violent Communication</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyssa Kuzmarov</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will help you to build non-violent communication skills at both personal and community levels. From a social (service) work perspective, the issue of non-violence and how we can promote a society based on valuing dignity and respect of individuals and groups will be explored. Looking at how individuals and groups can meet their needs using alternatives to violence will be a focus. Students will then be introduced to, and practice, non-violent communication skills including assertiveness, listening, conflict-resolution and emotional management. The course will then ask students to explore how the issue of non-violence is being addressed at the community level. Students will familiarize themselves with community initiatives both within Dawson College and Montreal as well as other parts of the country and the world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Sociology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Individual and Society</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">10 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francine Small</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the basic ideas and perspectives of sociological investigation and interpretation. It focuses on the ways individuals are shaped by and respond to culture and social organization. Students are introduced to the major areas of sociological research, including representative studies and their findings about Canada, Quebec and other societies, in order to provide a systematic understanding of the contemporary social world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laura Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the basic ideas and perspectives of sociological investigation and interpretation. We will also examine larger social structures such as the State and Capitalism as social problems. Although we will discuss these issues within a broad Canadian context, we will focus on these social problems in relation to Indigenous-Settler relations in Canada.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Dan Loomer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will analyze important social problems in Canada such as poverty, racism, and gender inequities. We will also examine larger social structures such as the State and Capitalism as social problems. Although we will discuss these issues within a broad Canadian context, we will focus on these social problems in relation to Indigenous-Settler relations in Canada.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-216-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Education</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elliot Kerr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Whether student, teacher, parent, or taxpayer, we are all affected by our education system and many of us have strong opinions about that system. This course provides a broad examination of education and the education  system from a variety of perspectives: as a set of activities; as an institutional form; as a set of ideologies, values, and beliefs; and as a setting within which people such as students and teachers come to terms with one another and  learn to understand themselves and others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-219-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sociology of Law</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Sigouin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the law as a social phenomenon. Particular areas of focus are on the evolution of modern legal systems, the emergence of the modern legal profession, current controversies with respect to such matters  as civil rights or the regulation of sexuality, and the implications of post-industrialization and globalization on legal systems and issues such as human rights and citizenship.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Sigouin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the law as a social phenomenon. Particular areas of focus are on the evolution of modern legal systems, the emergence of the modern legal profession, current controversies with respect to such matters  as civil rights or the regulation of sexuality, and the implications of post-industrialization and globalization on legal systems and issues such as human rights and citizenship.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-229-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Work and Society</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Sigouin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For better or worse, most of us must spend a good deal of our lives at work. It seems reasonable, then, to understand work not only as a personal issue, but also as a social one. This course examines the place of work in modern life. It explores the organization of various types of workplaces, shifts in types of work and occupations, and our experiences of work. This course will also consider topics such as the relations between work and the family,  work and gender, and work and politics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for Liberal Arts.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-314-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sexuality and Society</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Beer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores sexual attitudes, behaviours, and ideologies. The course will focus on the social construction of masculine and feminine sexuality in Quebec and Canada. Topics covered in the course include, sexual violence, romantic love and dating, sexual life cycle, homosexuality, sex education, and the data on health and sexuality.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for Liberal Arts.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Beer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores sexual attitudes, behaviours, and ideologies. The course will focus on the social construction of masculine and feminine sexuality in Quebec and Canada. Topics covered in the course include, sexual violence, romantic love and dating, sexual life cycle, homosexuality, sex education, and the data on health and sexuality.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Studies in Sociology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Food and the Environment</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anna-Liisa Aunio</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we take an in-depth approach to our social world and topics such as culture, health, and the environment by studying one essential, everyday question: what should I eat? Why food? In short, decisions about what to eat and why permeate our everyday experience. While it is a topic usually considered profoundly individual, this course begins with the premise that the subject of food is deeply sociological. Moreover, as we will discover throughout the course, it serves as a nexus by which we can explore the relationship between what we consider quite personal decisions to broad and societal issues. Students will have the opportunity to carry out individual studies on a broad range of topics, from the relationship between food and health to the effect of culture and what you eat to the effects of food insecurity on children. Students will also have the opportunity to participate in an ongoing research project in Montreal directed at studying our local food system.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Indigenous Resurgence</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laura Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will provide the basis for a more in-depth look at key issues facing Indigenous Peoples including racism, colonization and its practices, representation of Indigenous people in media and popular culture, Indigenous resistance and protest. Through engagement with readings, discussions, guest speakers, films, critical self-reflection and the production of a project, we will move toward a deeper understanding of Indigenous resurgence in Canada, and the possibilities for healing and social justice in the 21st century. Indigenous pedagogies and knowledge(s) will also be incorporated at various moments throughout the semester.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-903-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Multicultural Montreal</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francine Small</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Montreal neighbourhoods are noteworthy for their multiethnic population.  The aim of the course is to explore this ethnic diversity in an effort to better understand the characteristics of ethnic groups and their place in Montreal. During the course, the experiences of various ethnic groups in Montreal will be examined, as will the implications of these for the practice of social service work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Social Service</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-BWS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social science: introduction to sociology</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Individual and Society</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marian Misdrahi Flores</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the contribution sociology can make to the understanding of the issues of current social, cultural and political discourse. Students will be introduced to the fundamental elements of the sociological perspective, and they will be taught to use sociological data to deepen their understanding of debates concerning ongoing changes in the structure and function of major social institutions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Individual and Society</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kelly Phipps</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the contribution sociology can make to the understanding of the issues of current social, cultural and political discourse. Students will be introduced to the fundamental elements of the sociological perspective, and they will be taught to use sociological data to deepen their understanding of debates concerning ongoing changes in the structure and function of major social institutions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Spanish</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Please note the prerequisites for each course.  Students in doubt of their level must contact the department chairperson at local 4244 or e-mail nlachance@dawsoncollege.qc.ca before registration.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">607-111-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Spanish 1</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christina Chough</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Spanish, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nelly Muresan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Spanish, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Fernanda Benavides</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Spanish, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Spanish 1</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Fernanda Benavides</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Spanish, formal or informal. Subject matter will be varied, from live models, to objects and structures, to interior and exterior spaces. A greater understanding of depth cues through the use of linear perspective, as well as varying line qualities, textures, value relationships and other optical devices, will enable students to create the convincing illusion of volume and depth in their drawings. Students will mediate drawing from observation with an imaginative sensibility.  They will experiment with materials and techniques, make sketches and produce large drawings.  Students will begin to consider the symbolic and expressive potential of drawing in preparation for a deeper inquiry into the use of metaphor that will be developed further in Drawing 3 (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Philip Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 2 course continues to focus on drawing from observation, building and expanding upon the technical and interpretive skills acquired in Drawing 1. Subject matter will be varied, from live models, to objects and structures, to interior and exterior spaces. A greater understanding of depth cues through the use of linear perspective, as well as varying line qualities, textures, value relationships and other optical devices, will enable students to create the convincing illusion of volume and depth in their drawings. Students will mediate drawing from observation with an imaginative sensibility.  They will experiment with materials and techniques, make sketches and produce large drawings.  Students will begin to consider the symbolic and expressive potential of drawing in preparation for a deeper inquiry into the use of metaphor that will be developed further in Drawing 3 (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-214-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Painting 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kristi Ropeleski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 2 course builds on the knowledge of colour and colour mixing acquired in Colour and Painting 1. The focus throughout the course will be on learning the appropriate techniques, skills and approaches for painting from observation. Students will explore compositional structures and learn to depict form and space through colour, mark, and shape. Students will learn to prepare canvas supports and grounds, to set-up their palettes, and to use a variety of paint applications (opaque, transparent) and techniques. During the term paintings will be executed on medium and large size canvases, finishing with an extended study of two models executed on a large (48” x 60”) canvas. Knowledge acquired in this course will be applied in Painting 3 (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kristi Ropeleski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 2 course builds on the knowledge of colour and colour mixing acquired in Colour and Painting 1. The focus throughout the course will be on learning the appropriate techniques, skills and approaches for painting from observation. Students will explore compositional structures and learn to depict form and space through colour, mark, and shape. Students will learn to prepare canvas supports and grounds, to set-up their palettes, and to use a variety of paint applications (opaque, transparent) and techniques. During the term paintings will be executed on medium and large size canvases, finishing with an extended study of two models executed on a large (48” x 60”) canvas. Knowledge acquired in this course will be applied in Painting 3 (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-215-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sculpture 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Baumflek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 2 sculpture course continues the three dimensional explorations begun in Sculpture 1. It further develops technical knowledge in wood and metal fabrication using power tools and stationary equipment. Through research and preparatory work students will investigate 3D composition in the creation of their projects. The course continues to elaborate the heath and safety issues and protocol begun in Sculpture 1. This is integrated to the learning process and applied while working in the studios and workshops. The technical and conceptual knowledge gained in this course prepares students for further investigation of 3D practices in Sculpture 3 (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Baumflek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 2 sculpture course continues the three dimensional explorations begun in Sculpture 1. It further develops technical knowledge in wood and metal fabrication using power tools and stationary equipment. Through research and preparatory work students will investigate 3D composition in the creation of their projects. The course continues to elaborate the heath and safety issues and protocol begun in Sculpture 1. This is integrated to the learning process and applied while working in the studios and workshops. The technical and conceptual knowledge gained in this course prepares students for further investigation of 3D practices in Sculpture 3 (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-293-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sculpting Human Anatomy</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nina Dubois</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to develop an understanding of three-dimensional form as described by the human body. The course will include life modelling sessions along with studio practice as a way of studying the principles of three dimensional forms, with the aim of producing a 3-D likeness. The student will also conduct preliminary research using varied visual resources and exploratory work using drawing techniques, photographs, maquettes, and proposals in clay. Students learn to use clay and the techniques of modelling. Topics include: three dimensional form and composition, modeling feet, hands and head, anatomy, gesture, movement, bone structure, proportion, and balance, and major muscle groups.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rachel Echenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to develop an understanding of three-dimensional form as described by the human body. The course will include life modelling sessions along with studio practice as a way of studying the principles of three dimensional forms, with the aim of producing a 3-D likeness. The student will also conduct preliminary research using varied visual resources and exploratory work using drawing techniques, photographs, maquettes, and proposals in clay. Students learn to use clay and the techniques of modelling. Topics include: three dimensional form and composition, modeling feet, hands and head, anatomy, gesture, movement, bone structure, proportion, and balance, and major muscle groups.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-296-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Creative Process</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joe Becker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is intended to introduce students to the creative potential of form and content. Heath and safety issues and protocol continue to be a concern with the use of new techniques and processes. Research and projects are developed using a conceptual and thematic approach emphasising individual creativity and current approaches in sculpture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Naomi London</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 4 sculpture course builds upon technical knowledge gained in previous sculpture courses. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-416-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Printmaking 2</div> <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Chronopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 4 printmaking course builds upon the knowledge and practice acquired in Printmaking 1. Printmaking processes learned previously will be expanded to include the use of photography and the new technologies as applied to printmaking. Students will learn to generate source imagery using the appropriate tools and software. The focus throughout the course will be on learning the techniques, skills and approaches for transferring and printing source images onto and from a sensitized matrix.  Students will learn to identify current print media based artwork and varied presentation modes to display their work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Visual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, February 14, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Chronopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 4 printmaking course builds upon the knowledge and practice acquired in Printmaking 1.
